EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the mid afternoon a strong storm moved over eastern Red Willow county.  The largest hail size reported was nickel near Cambridge.

A small cluster of strong to severe storms moved southeast across Northwest Kansas.  Hail up to nickel size was reported between Oakley and Grinnell.  The main hazard was the high winds produced by the thunderstorm outflow ahead of the cluster.  The highest measured wind gust was 80 MPH at Oakley.  These high winds snapped a power pole near Angelus on Highway 40.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A power pole was snapped on old Highway 40 from the high winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms moved across portions of Northwest Kansas during the afternoon.  The largest hail reported was ping-pong ball size near Almena with the first round of storms.  The second round involved a very strong storm moving south out of Nebraska.  Large hail up to baseball size fell for several minutes in the Almena area and near Reager.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to ping-pong ball size has fallen.  Information passed through a spotter.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail fell along with 1.10 inches of rainfall.

During the afternoon a thunderstorm moved over McCook, producing wind gusts up to 66 MPH.

Two rounds of severe storms occurred during the afternoon and evening of April 8th, 2015. Storms first developed over Southern Kansas and quickly raced into Southeast Kansas during the afternoon. These storms produced 70 to 80 mph winds along with hail up to the size of golf balls. A second round of supercell thunderstorms eventually fired back to the west along a retreating dry line during the early evening over South Central Kansas and Northern Oklahoma. These storms produced several reports of  very large hail and eventually tracked into Kingman county where hail over 3 inches was reported which is larger than the size of baseballs. A brief tornado touchdown occurred southeast of Zenda, Kansas. ||Another supercell thunderstorm formed over eastern Kingman county. Rotating wall clouds were reported near the town of Cheney and a tornado touched down in extreme northwest Sedgwick County and tracked into Southeast Reno county.  The tornado was rated an EF0.

A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported quarter size hail across the east side of town, which was piling up like snow.

This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager reported heavy damage to a boat and camper storage building. Several power lines were also knocked down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter measured the gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late evening a severe thunderstorm moved south through Sherman county.  As the storm approached Goodland wind speeds increased to 58 MPH.

A strong tornado moved southwest from Rice into Reno county causing significant damage to two different homesteads.  One home was completely demolished while another took a glancing blow.  Numerous trees were uprooted and those that were not had a significant amount of debarking.  Several other storms moved across the area producing severe wind and hail.
A small episode of severe weather occurred in Central Kansas during the afternoon of May 7th, 2015.   A few large hail reports occurred.

A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mobile home was rolled by a channeled microburst and completely destroyed.  Three people were inside the home and climbed out of the rumble. All three were injured in the damage and transported to the hospital with minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong wind event moved across portions of Greenwood and Chase counties causing some minor structural damage and wind gusts to near 60 mph.  The main story was the heavy rains that moved across the southern half of the state producing widespread minor flooding to virtually every county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of minor street flooding was noted at many low water crossings across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of severe storms moved across central Kansas dropping large hail up to golf ball sized.
A series of severe storms moved across central Kansas dropping large hail up to golf ball sized.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains had caused some nuisance flooding on county roads with a few being covered by shallow water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong tornado moved southwest from Rice into Reno county causing significant damage to two different homesteads.  One home was completely demolished while another took a glancing blow.  Numerous trees were uprooted and those that were not had a significant amount of debarking.  Several other storms moved across the area producing severe wind and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown across the road about two miles east of Nickerson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager reported two mobile homes just northeast of town were destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The report was received via Twitter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another small cluster of storms moved across Central KS and produced a minimal amount of severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured 58 mph wind reported was recorded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms produced torrential rains across parts of South-Central Kansas for much of the afternoon and evening. Major flooding occurred. The most serious was that of a flash flood that occurred in Wichita. In parts of South and Southeast Wichita as well as West Wichita vehicles were submerged. Most of the parking lots at the Towne West Mall were flooded to depths around 3 feet. Rainfalls from 3-6 inches were widespread. Many streets were barricaded. Among them was Maple Avenue from I-235 to West Streets. The situation was exacerbated by heavy thunderstorms that produced torrential rains early in the morning. In fact, a staggering 5.60 inches was measured in Harper that morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KAKE Channel 10 reported that Maple Avenue is closed from I-235 to West Street. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low spun around the Southwest United States during this time frame with weak upper level shortwaves being ejected eastward across the Central Rockies into the Central High Plains. This caused diffluent westerly flow above the Central High Plains. A strong upper level jet was also in place above the area of concern. Mid-level Isentropic lift of saturated air was present during this event and was the main lifting mechanism. A dome of high pressure shifted eastward as the weekend approached allowing southeast upslope winds to be felt across western Kansas. Light to moderate rain started to fall across far western Kansas by late Saturday morning, spreading eastward as the afternoon progressed. Precipitation then changed over to snow by evening, first across west central Kansas, then the remainder of southwest Kansas by midnight. Moderate snow showers were observed throughout the night with occasional light snow reported throughout Sunday. Light to moderate snow fell once again across portions of western Kansas Sunday night before ending by late Monday morning. By the time the snow ended, snowfall amounts of 6-10 inches were reported across west central Kansas, 3-7 inches across southwest Kansas, and 1-4 inches across central and south central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 4 to 6 inches fell across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 13th a very unstable atmosphere was in place as a boundary stretched across the area. Once storms were able to develop they were explosive and quickly became severe. Given all the instability the storms produced large hail up to golf ball sized.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an 8 inch diameter tree limb down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of the 15th a severe bow echo rolled through eastern KS causing wind damage. That evening a left over boundary allowed a supercell to form. This storm was long lived and produced large hail and severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor tree damage in Clay Center.

Arctic high pressure, associated with record or near record surface pressure, settled into the mid Missouri River Valley during the early morning on the 7th. The combination of arctic air with actual air temperatures from 5 below to 5 above zero, and winds of 15 to 30 mph with gusts to near 40 mph created wind chill values of 15 to 25 below zero starting in the early morning on the 7th continuing through the early afternoon in many areas.

Snowfall of 1 to 3 inches combined with winds gusting to over 40 mph to cause near zero visibilities in blowing snow for a few hours in extreme northeast Nebraska from the evening of January 3rd to just after midnight on January 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 1 to 3 inches while winds were gusting to over 40 mph caused widespread near zero visibilities during much of the evening of January 3rd. Travel in open areas was temporarily brought to a halt.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 1 to 3 inches combined with winds gusting to over 40 mph to cause near zero visibilities in blowing snow for a few hours in extreme northeast Nebraska from the evening of January 3rd to just after midnight on January 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong winds accompanying decreasing snowfall resulted in areas of blowing snow with visibility reduced to less than a mile in places after blizzard conditions abated.

An upper level low spun around the Southwest United States during this time frame with weak upper level shortwaves being ejected eastward across the Central Rockies into the Central High Plains. This caused diffluent westerly flow above the Central High Plains. A strong upper level jet was also in place above the area of concern. Mid-level Isentropic lift of saturated air was present during this event and was the main lifting mechanism. A dome of high pressure shifted eastward as the weekend approached allowing southeast upslope winds to be felt across western Kansas. Light to moderate rain started to fall across far western Kansas by late Saturday morning, spreading eastward as the afternoon progressed. Precipitation then changed over to snow by evening, first across west central Kansas, then the remainder of southwest Kansas by midnight. Moderate snow showers were observed throughout the night with occasional light snow reported throughout Sunday. Light to moderate snow fell once again across portions of western Kansas Sunday night before ending by late Monday morning. By the time the snow ended, snowfall amounts of 6-10 inches were reported across west central Kansas, 3-7 inches across southwest Kansas, and 1-4 inches across central and south central Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 8 to 10 inches fell across the western part of the county and 4 to 6 across eastern sections.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic high pressure, associated with record or near record surface pressure, settled into the mid Missouri River Valley during the early morning on the 7th. The combination of arctic air with actual air temperatures from 5 below to 5 above zero, and winds of 15 to 30 mph with gusts to near 40 mph created wind chill values of 15 to 25 below zero starting in the early morning on the 7th continuing through the early afternoon in many areas.
A few severe thunderstorms were observed during the afternoon.
A few severe thunderstorms were observed during the afternoon.
A few severe thunderstorms were observed during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were blown down at the 4H building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms were observed during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An electrical line was blown down by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms were observed during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be at least 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms were observed during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 65 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulating up to 7 inches was accompanied by blowing snow as a result of northwest winds 20 to 35 mph. The main impact of the storm was to cause difficulties in weekend travel for those who did not delay their travel plans. The storm began on January 31st and continued into the new month through much of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 4 to 7 inches, including 5.1 inches at Wakefield. Accompanying northwest winds gusting to 35 mph caused areas of blowing snow, reducing visibility to 1/4 mile at a few places.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and early evening thunderstorms produced strong winds and large hail across portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed two miles south of Melbeta.  A corn field was destroyed by the large hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to quarter size hail was observed at Lyman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. Five tornadoes occurred over Jewell County. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. It was about this time that a short line formed from the Jewell-Smith County line south into Osborne County. Supercells were embedded within this line and several discrete supercells developed ahead of it over Mitchell and Jewell counties. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary, with new storms repeatedly developing over north central Kansas and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 4-8 inches of rain over portions of Jewell County. The highest amount reported was 7.92 inches near Webber. ||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 ft. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE was around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down southeast of Formoso, traveling about 4 miles before lifting northeast of Formoso. This tornado was rated an EF1, with an estimated peak wind speed of 110 MPH. Tree and power pole damage was noted along its path, and one home sustained roof, window and siding damage. An outbuilding was also destroyed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado started west of Mankato, traveling north and passing approximately 1 mile to the west of Burr Oak before turning more to the northeast and lifting. One woman was injured at her home approximately 4 miles south-southwest of Burr Oak. This tornado was rated an EF2, with an estimated peak wind speed of 130 MPH.||Along the path of this tornado, at least 4 homes sustained damage, including roof, window and siding damage. One home lost a large section of its roof. A garage was destroyed, with the vehicles inside moved 30-50 feet from their original location. Other outbuildings, grain bins, power poles and trees were damaged or destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. Five tornadoes occurred over Jewell County. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. It was about this time that a short line formed from the Jewell-Smith County line south into Osborne County. Supercells were embedded within this line and several discrete supercells developed ahead of it over Mitchell and Jewell counties. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary, with new storms repeatedly developing over north central Kansas and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 4-8 inches of rain over portions of Jewell County. The highest amount reported was 7.92 inches near Webber. ||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 ft. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE was around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down west-northwest of Webber in Jewell County, KS, traveling northeast through the very northwest corner of Republic County, KS, before entering Nebraska near the town of Hardy in Nuckolls County. It continued traveling northeast into Thayer County, lifting northwest of Deshler. This tornado was rated an EF2, with an estimated peak wind speed of 122 MPH. EF2 damage was noted in both Jewell County, KS and Nuckolls County, NE.||Damage along this tornado path included numerous pivots overturned and snapped power poles. There was a large amount of tree damage noted. In addition, in Jewell County, grain bins and outbuildings were destroyed, and a home lost a portion of its roof.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells rapidly lifted north into south central Nebraska and began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. Most of the tornadoes occurred over Nuckolls and Thayer counties. One tornado did occur over Adams county and a brief spin-up also occurred over Hall county. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary. New storms repeatedly developed over north central Kansas and lifted northeast along the boundary, through Nuckolls and Thayer counties and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 5-11 inches of rain over portions of Nuckolls and Thayer counties. The highest amount reported was 10.91 inches just west of Hebron. This amount of rainfall in 24 hours typically occurs once in 1,000 years at any given location, or stated another way, has a .1% chance of occurrence in a given 24 hour period. Cooperative observers in Hebron and Superior reported 8.59 and 7.13 inches, respectively. These were the highest 24-hour rainfall amounts ever recorded at these locations, dating back to 1893. Flash flooding damaged roads and some bridges were washed out. U.S. Highways 81 and 136 were closed for a time due to the flooding.||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 feet. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down between Bostwick and Superior, and was rated an EF1 with an estimated peak wind speed of 100 MPH. Trees were damaged, pivots were overturned and power poles were snapped. A home northwest of Superior sustained porch damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in central Cherry County and moved southeast producing large hail, heavy rain, and gusty winds. Other thunderstorms developed in the southeast Nebraska Panhandle and southwest that also produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain. The heavy rainfall led to localized flash flooding in portions of Keith, Perkins, Lincoln, and Hayes counties.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported running over Hershey Dickens Road due to heavy rainfall.

Scattered to numerous, semi-discrete and multicell thunderstorms blossomed across much of South Central Nebraska on this Saturday afternoon and evening, with a few storms becoming severe and producing hail ranging from 1-2 in diameter. The first severe storm of the afternoon developed near Kearney around 5 p.m. CDT, and was likely the most prolific hail-producer as it slowly drifted north-northwest through central and northwest Buffalo County for nearly two hours. Just north of Kearney, a few vehicles slid off of Highway 10 as it became hail-covered and slick. This storm also produced the largest reported hail of the day (2) north of Riverdale. Between 6-9 p.m. CDT, several other storms either flared up over various parts of the area or pushed northward out of Kansas, with quarter size hail reported near the state line south of Red Cloud and also in Wood River. Even though the mesoscale environment was potentially supportive of a somewhat greater severe weather threat, the fairly rapid development of plentiful convection and resultant storm-scale outflow interference likely mitigated this. With the loss of diurnal heating, storms steadily weakened and diminished in coverage within a few hours after nightfall. Although most affected areas received less than 1 of rainfall, much of northern Kearney County along with adjacent portions of southeast Buffalo, southwest Hall and northwest Adams counties received higher amounts to around 2. ||In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was an expansive closed low churning slowly eastward through eastern Colorado, with several smaller-scale disturbances shifting northward into the Central Plains along its eastern flank. At the surface, there were no distinct synoptic features within South Central Nebraska, only fairly weak, broad low pressure and prevailing light southerly to easterly breezes. Despite afternoon temperatures only rising into the low-70s F, the combination of surface dewpoints in the low to mid-50s and notably cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -18 C) yielded surface-based CAPE around 1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of thunderstorms led to significant river flooding along many river in southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa during the early part of June. The first episode of heavy rainfall came during the early morning hours on June 4th when thunderstorms lifted north across southeast Nebraska into southwest Iowa to the north of a warm front. Additional thunderstorms moved along this warm front during the morning on the 4th, followed by even heavier and slower moving thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of the 4th. The combination of these repeated rainfalls on already saturated ground led to river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several heavy rain events in early to mid June brought the the Big Blue River near Crete into flood. The combination of the repeated events allowed for each crest of the river to be a bit higher than the last, finally crested in moderate flood stage at 26.05 feet on June 12th. Besides significant agricultural flooding along both sides of the river, some areas on the east side of Crete near Tuxedo Park on the north side of Highway 33.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of thunderstorms led to significant river flooding along many river in southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa during the early part of June. The first episode of heavy rainfall came during the early morning hours on June 4th when thunderstorms lifted north across southeast Nebraska into southwest Iowa to the north of a warm front. Additional thunderstorms moved along this warm front during the morning on the 4th, followed by even heavier and slower moving thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of the 4th. The combination of these repeated rainfalls on already saturated ground led to river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Repeated episodes of heavy rainfall resulted in a long duration flood along the Big Blue River near Beatrice with multiple crests observed. The initial crest on the 6th of June was the most significant, with a second significant crest on the 17th. Besides significant agricultural flooding along both banks of the river, several rural roads were closed near the river as well as State Highway 136.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant agricultural flooding was observed along the Big Blue River near Barneston as the river crested 6.59 feet above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed two miles west of Morrill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two brief tornadoes occurred in Harlan County on this Saturday evening, with a couple reports of severe hail as well nearby. Scattered thunderstorms developed over north central Kansas between 530 and 600 p.m. CST. Several small thunderstorms lifted north, into and through Harlan County, over the following two hours. The last storm to move through produced a couple brief, weak tornadoes around 730 p.m. CST. This storm also produced one inch hail in a couple locations over Phelps County, just after 8 p.m. CST. Other small thunderstorms continued across south central Nebraska, and just before 11 p.m., a storm briefly became strong enough to produce a few one inch hailstones in Kearney. However, most of the hail was the size of nickels or smaller.||A continental polar air mass was over the region, but lee cyclogenesis was underway. By midnight, low pressure had migrated from northwestern Kansas and into south central Nebraska. The associated warm front had also lifted north along with it. At upper-levels, a deep trough was over the Rockies with a closed low over Colorado, and a coupled jet streak configuration. A ridge was downstream over the eastern United States. South central Nebraska had been shrouded in low stratus and fog all day, with temperatures struggling to rise through the 50s. Dewpoints depressions were very low. MUCAPE was only 500 J/kg, but deep layer shear was around 45 knots. Strengthening and significantly veering low-level wind fields resulted in 0-1 km SRH of 200-300 m2/s2.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

Scattered to numerous, semi-discrete and multicell thunderstorms blossomed across this six-county North Central Kansas area on this Saturday afternoon, with a few storms briefly becoming severe and producing quarter size hail. Even though radar data suggested there were likely additional pockets of severe-criteria hail, the only limited ground-truth reports emanated from Zurich, from near Cedar and from rural northwestern Phillips County. Although the mesoscale environment was potentially supportive of a somewhat greater severe weather threat, the fairly rapid development of plentiful convection and resultant storm-scale outflow interference likely mitigated this. Despite the widespread activity, rainfall amounts across the vast majority of the local area averaged well-under 1. ||The first storms of the afternoon affected the local area between 3-4 p.m. CDT, as already-developed activity pushed into Mitchell County from the south and an isolated severe storm formed over southern Smith County. Over the course of the next few hours, several additional strong to marginally severe storms either popped up within, or pushed into the six-county area from the south, before convection steadily weakened and diminished in coverage between 6-7 p.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was an expansive closed low churning slowly eastward through eastern Colorado, with several smaller-scale disturbances shifting northward into the Central Plains along its eastern flank. At the surface, there were no distinct synoptic features within North Central Kansas, only fairly weak, broad low pressure and prevailing light southerly to easterly breezes. Despite afternoon temperatures only rising into the low-70s F, the combination of surface dewpoints in the mid-50s and notably cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -18 C) yielded mixed-layer CAPE values around 1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.

Widespread wind, hail, and flooding occurred, starting overnight on the 24th into the 25th. While flooding was the biggest problem, mainly in Missouri for the morning of the 25th, severe weather moved in and brought a wide area of severe reports across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Olathe (OJC) recorded a 63 mph wind gust as storms moved through.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 6 foot diameter tree was uprooted as a result of strong winds that moved through the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large part of a tree snapped off and fell on a car and the adjacent house. Report was received via social media.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell over into the power lines in West Leavenworth, causing the transformer to blow.

Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swath of 5 to 9 inches of rain, with locally higher amounts, was reported primarily across the southeastern half of the county. The Republican River along the southern edge of the county was flooded. Numerous bridges and many miles of county roads were damaged by the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells rapidly lifted north into south central Nebraska and began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. Most of the tornadoes occurred over Nuckolls and Thayer counties. One tornado did occur over Adams county and a brief spin-up also occurred over Hall county. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary. New storms repeatedly developed over north central Kansas and lifted northeast along the boundary, through Nuckolls and Thayer counties and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 5-11 inches of rain over portions of Nuckolls and Thayer counties. The highest amount reported was 10.91 inches just west of Hebron. This amount of rainfall in 24 hours typically occurs once in 1,000 years at any given location, or stated another way, has a .1% chance of occurrence in a given 24 hour period. Cooperative observers in Hebron and Superior reported 8.59 and 7.13 inches, respectively. These were the highest 24-hour rainfall amounts ever recorded at these locations, dating back to 1893. Flash flooding damaged roads and some bridges were washed out. U.S. Highways 81 and 136 were closed for a time due to the flooding.||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 feet. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Central portions of Thayer County was the hardest hit in the NWS Hastings coverage area. A swath of 5 to 9 inches of rain, with locally higher amounts of 10 to 11 inches, was reported across the the county. Portions of Highways 81, 136 and 53 were closed for a period of time during the evening. In Hebron, a bridge was washed out, reducing the access to the local hospital and nursing/assisted living facilities down to just one road. In Deshler, water at least 6 inches deep resulted in the evacuation of 6 homes as well as a nursing home. A total of 43 residents were taken to a shelter at the local high school. At least 4 bridges and many miles of county roads were damaged by the flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the latter half of May, an unusually long-lasting, roughly six-week period of generally minor flooding commenced along the Platte River in South Central Nebraska, impacting local areas from Gothenburg downstream to near Grand Island. This event was spurred by a combination of heavy May rainfall over upstream portions of northeast Colorado and the southern Nebraska Panhandle, coincident with above normal Rocky Mountains snow melt. Although the initial flooding within South Central Nebraska was largely tied to these upstream factors, it then perpetuated through much of June thanks to heavy rain falling directly over the local Platte basin, especially between the Kearney and Grand Island areas. Although peak water levels and impacts during this May-June event closely resembled those which occurred during the Platte River flooding of late-September to early-October 2013, this event was considerably more prolonged. The vast majority of local flooding impacts were noted within Dawson, Buffalo and Hall counties, mainly affecting pastures and lowlands immediately adjacent to the river, with very little impact to infrastructure. That being said, a few locations did experience legitimate disruptions. One of these was the Blue Heron Campground near Gothenburg, and another being the area around the south side of the Interstate 80 exit 312/Highway 281 interchange area near Grand Island, where water occasionally encroached into the parking lots of businesses. Water levels and resultant flooding concerns decreased downstream from the Grand Island area, largely due to the widening of the main river channel. ||Taking a closer look at the onset and timing of Platte River flooding within South Central Nebraska during May, the stage was set by heavy upstream rainfall coinciding with above normal snow melt. For the month of May as a whole, the vast majority of northeast Colorado and the southern Nebraska Panhandle received 5-10 of precipitation, or about 200-400 percent of normal. The Platte started creeping out of its banks in southwest Nebraska during the May 10-15 time frame. Within the local area, minor flooding got underway in the Dawson County area around May 16th, with the automated gauge near Cozad initially cresting around 6.7 feet (flood stage 6.5 feet) on the 20th. Downstream at the gauge near Kearney, flood stage of 6.0 feet was initially exceeded on the 18th, with a pair of crests around 7.0 feet occurring on the 22nd and again on the 31st. Farther east near Grand Island, the river initially crept above the 6.5 ft. flood stage between the 22nd-24th, then briefly dropped below flood for a few days before starting a more persistent rise above flood stage on the 31st. All three of these automated gauges either periodically reached, or consistently stayed above flood stage well into June (please refer to the June Storm Data entry for more specific information regarding the latter stages of this Platte River flooding).

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were broken out of house with cars stuck on Highway 97 due to the hail.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were broken out on north side of house, damaged vehicles, stripped tree leaves and hay crop damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous, semi-discrete and multicell thunderstorms blossomed across this six-county North Central Kansas area on this Saturday afternoon, with a few storms briefly becoming severe and producing quarter size hail. Even though radar data suggested there were likely additional pockets of severe-criteria hail, the only limited ground-truth reports emanated from Zurich, from near Cedar and from rural northwestern Phillips County. Although the mesoscale environment was potentially supportive of a somewhat greater severe weather threat, the fairly rapid development of plentiful convection and resultant storm-scale outflow interference likely mitigated this. Despite the widespread activity, rainfall amounts across the vast majority of the local area averaged well-under 1. ||The first storms of the afternoon affected the local area between 3-4 p.m. CDT, as already-developed activity pushed into Mitchell County from the south and an isolated severe storm formed over southern Smith County. Over the course of the next few hours, several additional strong to marginally severe storms either popped up within, or pushed into the six-county area from the south, before convection steadily weakened and diminished in coverage between 6-7 p.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was an expansive closed low churning slowly eastward through eastern Colorado, with several smaller-scale disturbances shifting northward into the Central Plains along its eastern flank. At the surface, there were no distinct synoptic features within North Central Kansas, only fairly weak, broad low pressure and prevailing light southerly to easterly breezes. Despite afternoon temperatures only rising into the low-70s F, the combination of surface dewpoints in the mid-50s and notably cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -18 C) yielded mixed-layer CAPE values around 1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.

Thunderstorms developed in central Cherry County and moved southeast producing large hail, heavy rain, and gusty winds. Other thunderstorms developed in the southeast Nebraska Panhandle and southwest that also produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain. The heavy rainfall led to localized flash flooding in portions of Keith, Perkins, Lincoln, and Hayes counties.

Two brief tornadoes occurred in Harlan County on this Saturday evening, with a couple reports of severe hail as well nearby. Scattered thunderstorms developed over north central Kansas between 530 and 600 p.m. CST. Several small thunderstorms lifted north, into and through Harlan County, over the following two hours. The last storm to move through produced a couple brief, weak tornadoes around 730 p.m. CST. This storm also produced one inch hail in a couple locations over Phelps County, just after 8 p.m. CST. Other small thunderstorms continued across south central Nebraska, and just before 11 p.m., a storm briefly became strong enough to produce a few one inch hailstones in Kearney. However, most of the hail was the size of nickels or smaller.||A continental polar air mass was over the region, but lee cyclogenesis was underway. By midnight, low pressure had migrated from northwestern Kansas and into south central Nebraska. The associated warm front had also lifted north along with it. At upper-levels, a deep trough was over the Rockies with a closed low over Colorado, and a coupled jet streak configuration. A ridge was downstream over the eastern United States. South central Nebraska had been shrouded in low stratus and fog all day, with temperatures struggling to rise through the 50s. Dewpoints depressions were very low. MUCAPE was only 500 J/kg, but deep layer shear was around 45 knots. Strengthening and significantly veering low-level wind fields resulted in 0-1 km SRH of 200-300 m2/s2.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to nickel size hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

A swath of damaging winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas early this Friday evening. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours. Between 4 and 5 p.m. CST, several storms combined into a very small bow echo configuration over Furnas County Nebraska. This storm entered northwestern Phillips County Kansas around 5 p.m. and subsequently raced east-southeast across north central Kansas, exiting Mitchell County by 730 p.m. CST. This cluster of storms was responsible for a swath of wind damage across Phillips, Smith and Mitchell counties. Multiple wind gusts were measured at 58 mph or above. The highest wind speed recorded was 73 mph at the Smith Center airport. Large tree limbs were also reported down in several locations. A separate isolated storm, tracking along the Nebraska-Kansas border, intensified over northeastern Jewell County. This storm also produced wind damage, overturning an irrigation pivot and scattering irrigation pipes.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A swath of damaging winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas early this Friday evening. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours. Between 4 and 5 p.m. CST, several storms combined into a very small bow echo configuration over Furnas County Nebraska. This storm entered northwestern Phillips County Kansas around 5 p.m. and subsequently raced east-southeast across north central Kansas, exiting Mitchell County by 730 p.m. CST. This cluster of storms was responsible for a swath of wind damage across Phillips, Smith and Mitchell counties. Multiple wind gusts were measured at 58 mph or above. The highest wind speed recorded was 73 mph at the Smith Center airport. Large tree limbs were also reported down in several locations. A separate isolated storm, tracking along the Nebraska-Kansas border, intensified over northeastern Jewell County. This storm also produced wind damage, overturning an irrigation pivot and scattering irrigation pipes.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.

Between 6-9 p.m. CDT on this late Sunday afternoon and evening, a fairly compact-but-intense supercell storm tracked eastward across mainly central sections of Smith and Jewell counties. This storm yielded several reports of large hail and also the first tornado of 2015 within this six-county North Central Kansas area, an EF-0 that touched down three miles north of Smith Center and tracked for about one mile, damaging the roof of an outbuilding. Prior to this brief tornado, there had been several reports of a funnel cloud or multiple funnels as the storm traversed west-central Smith County. For most of its path, this supercell was primarily a hail-producer, as quarter size stones fell in Lebanon, Burr Oak and Formoso, and larger stones up to golf ball size rained down on Mankato for several minutes. ||Focusing on event timing, this storm initiated over the Smith-Phillips County line around 6 p.m. CDT, just ahead of an approaching cold front. At first, it appeared storm mode might assume a southwest-northeast oriented line segment, but a more discrete supercell structure quickly evolved as it tracked east down the Highway 36 corridor. As this storm reached eastern Jewell County around 8 p.m. CDT, it began morphing into a more linear structure that expanded southwestward into Mitchell County for a time. However, there were no further severe weather reports as all thunderstorms exited the local area by 930 p.m. CDT, in tandem with the passing cold front. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was provided by the southern reaches of a broad shortwave trough tracking east across the Central and especially Northern Plains, with this trough ushering in increasing west-southwest flow aloft. At the surface, the well-defined, northeast-southwest oriented cold front steadily swept through North Central Kansas during the evening. Ahead of this boundary, afternoon temperatures across most of the local area topped out between 75-80 F as dewpoints rose into the mid-upper 50s on gusty south winds. The presence of a weak surface low and attendant warm front in the immediate area likely contributed to tornado development, as local surface observations revealed a backing of wind direction to southeasterly ahead of the storm. As for basic severe weather parameters, mixed-layer CAPE values peaked in the 1000-1500 J/kg range in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 40-50 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An EF-0 rated tornado occurred north-northeast of Smith Center, KS. Damage was mainly limited to minor roof damage on an outbuilding, and the path was most likely intermittent. Maximum wind speed was estimated at 75 mph. A combination of radar data, storm survey, photos, and personal accounts were used to determine the approximate location and time of the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite marginal convective instability, the first severe thunderstorms of 2015 rumbled across mainly the eastern two-thirds of South Central Nebraska on this Wednesday evening, resulting in several reports of mostly marginally severe hail and wind gusts along an advancing cold front. Nearly all thunderstorms focused east of a Greeley-Kearney-Alma line, and assumed primarily a quasi-linear, multicell mode. In terms of hail, most was only up to quarter size, including several reports from the vicinities of Boelus, Ravenna, Alma, Doniphan, Trumbull and Deshler. The largest reported stones of half dollar size fell in Waco. As for wind gusts, speeds up to around 60 MPH were reported in or near Franklin, Blue Hill, Edgar and Ayr, with a home weather station northwest of Red Cloud clocking a peak gust of 73 MPH. Although no tornadoes occurred, the environment was conducive for a few gustnadoes along thunderstorm outflow, including one captured on storm chaser video east of Alma. On another severe weather side note, an intense lightning bolt struck a large tree in Hastings around 915 p.m. CDT, setting the tree on fire and scattering limbs as far as 100 feet. Rainfall-wise, the vast majority of the local area received well under 1, with the main exception of higher amounts concentrated in Nuckolls and Thayer counties, where a NeRAIN observer near Nora measured 1.77. ||Breaking down event timing, storms first flared up along the well-defined surface cold front between 6-7 p.m. CDT, with convection then expanding in coverage and tracking east through the evening. Although most strong to severe storms exited east of the local area by 10 p.m. CDT, regenerative development of stronger cores along the southern end of the complex persisted through around midnight CDT, mainly in Nuckolls/Thayer counties. All in all, this was a fairly standard issue first severe weather event of the season, primarily driven by low-level frontal forcing. Early in the evening, this northeast-southwest oriented front stretched across the heart of the local area, tied into a 998 millibar low pressure center in north central Kansas. Although afternoon temperatures ahead of the boundary warmed well into the 80s F, rather meager dewpoints only in the 40s likely precluded a potentially greater severe weather threat. Nonetheless, the presence of steep low-mid level lapse rates promoted sufficient mixed-layer CAPE of 500-1000 J/kg in the presence of decent 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-50 knots. In the mid-upper levels, southwesterly flow was fairly modest for this time of year, as the primary large scale trough shifted from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains.

Despite marginal convective instability, the first severe thunderstorms of 2015 rumbled across mainly the eastern two-thirds of South Central Nebraska on this Wednesday evening, resulting in several reports of mostly marginally severe hail and wind gusts along an advancing cold front. Nearly all thunderstorms focused east of a Greeley-Kearney-Alma line, and assumed primarily a quasi-linear, multicell mode. In terms of hail, most was only up to quarter size, including several reports from the vicinities of Boelus, Ravenna, Alma, Doniphan, Trumbull and Deshler. The largest reported stones of half dollar size fell in Waco. As for wind gusts, speeds up to around 60 MPH were reported in or near Franklin, Blue Hill, Edgar and Ayr, with a home weather station northwest of Red Cloud clocking a peak gust of 73 MPH. Although no tornadoes occurred, the environment was conducive for a few gustnadoes along thunderstorm outflow, including one captured on storm chaser video east of Alma. On another severe weather side note, an intense lightning bolt struck a large tree in Hastings around 915 p.m. CDT, setting the tree on fire and scattering limbs as far as 100 feet. Rainfall-wise, the vast majority of the local area received well under 1, with the main exception of higher amounts concentrated in Nuckolls and Thayer counties, where a NeRAIN observer near Nora measured 1.77. ||Breaking down event timing, storms first flared up along the well-defined surface cold front between 6-7 p.m. CDT, with convection then expanding in coverage and tracking east through the evening. Although most strong to severe storms exited east of the local area by 10 p.m. CDT, regenerative development of stronger cores along the southern end of the complex persisted through around midnight CDT, mainly in Nuckolls/Thayer counties. All in all, this was a fairly standard issue first severe weather event of the season, primarily driven by low-level frontal forcing. Early in the evening, this northeast-southwest oriented front stretched across the heart of the local area, tied into a 998 millibar low pressure center in north central Kansas. Although afternoon temperatures ahead of the boundary warmed well into the 80s F, rather meager dewpoints only in the 40s likely precluded a potentially greater severe weather threat. Nonetheless, the presence of steep low-mid level lapse rates promoted sufficient mixed-layer CAPE of 500-1000 J/kg in the presence of decent 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-50 knots. In the mid-upper levels, southwesterly flow was fairly modest for this time of year, as the primary large scale trough shifted from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains.

A swath of damaging winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas early this Friday evening. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours. Between 4 and 5 p.m. CST, several storms combined into a very small bow echo configuration over Furnas County Nebraska. This storm entered northwestern Phillips County Kansas around 5 p.m. and subsequently raced east-southeast across north central Kansas, exiting Mitchell County by 730 p.m. CST. This cluster of storms was responsible for a swath of wind damage across Phillips, Smith and Mitchell counties. Multiple wind gusts were measured at 58 mph or above. The highest wind speed recorded was 73 mph at the Smith Center airport. Large tree limbs were also reported down in several locations. A separate isolated storm, tracking along the Nebraska-Kansas border, intensified over northeastern Jewell County. This storm also produced wind damage, overturning an irrigation pivot and scattering irrigation pipes.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs between 6 and 8 inches in diameter were knocked down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated thunderstorm moved into northern Sheridan County and produced quarter size hail. A few hours later, damaging wind gusts occurred across portions of northern Sheridan County from additional thunderstorms.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement was notified that a metal windmill frame was damaged 4 miles southeast of Hay Springs with large tree limbs snapped off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous, semi-discrete and multicell thunderstorms blossomed across this six-county North Central Kansas area on this Saturday afternoon, with a few storms briefly becoming severe and producing quarter size hail. Even though radar data suggested there were likely additional pockets of severe-criteria hail, the only limited ground-truth reports emanated from Zurich, from near Cedar and from rural northwestern Phillips County. Although the mesoscale environment was potentially supportive of a somewhat greater severe weather threat, the fairly rapid development of plentiful convection and resultant storm-scale outflow interference likely mitigated this. Despite the widespread activity, rainfall amounts across the vast majority of the local area averaged well-under 1. ||The first storms of the afternoon affected the local area between 3-4 p.m. CDT, as already-developed activity pushed into Mitchell County from the south and an isolated severe storm formed over southern Smith County. Over the course of the next few hours, several additional strong to marginally severe storms either popped up within, or pushed into the six-county area from the south, before convection steadily weakened and diminished in coverage between 6-7 p.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was an expansive closed low churning slowly eastward through eastern Colorado, with several smaller-scale disturbances shifting northward into the Central Plains along its eastern flank. At the surface, there were no distinct synoptic features within North Central Kansas, only fairly weak, broad low pressure and prevailing light southerly to easterly breezes. Despite afternoon temperatures only rising into the low-70s F, the combination of surface dewpoints in the mid-50s and notably cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -18 C) yielded mixed-layer CAPE values around 1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.

A swath of damaging winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas early this Friday evening. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours. Between 4 and 5 p.m. CST, several storms combined into a very small bow echo configuration over Furnas County Nebraska. This storm entered northwestern Phillips County Kansas around 5 p.m. and subsequently raced east-southeast across north central Kansas, exiting Mitchell County by 730 p.m. CST. This cluster of storms was responsible for a swath of wind damage across Phillips, Smith and Mitchell counties. Multiple wind gusts were measured at 58 mph or above. The highest wind speed recorded was 73 mph at the Smith Center airport. Large tree limbs were also reported down in several locations. A separate isolated storm, tracking along the Nebraska-Kansas border, intensified over northeastern Jewell County. This storm also produced wind damage, overturning an irrigation pivot and scattering irrigation pipes.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Irrigation pipes were moved and a irrigation pivot was tipped over.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite marginal convective instability, the first severe thunderstorms of 2015 rumbled across mainly the eastern two-thirds of South Central Nebraska on this Wednesday evening, resulting in several reports of mostly marginally severe hail and wind gusts along an advancing cold front. Nearly all thunderstorms focused east of a Greeley-Kearney-Alma line, and assumed primarily a quasi-linear, multicell mode. In terms of hail, most was only up to quarter size, including several reports from the vicinities of Boelus, Ravenna, Alma, Doniphan, Trumbull and Deshler. The largest reported stones of half dollar size fell in Waco. As for wind gusts, speeds up to around 60 MPH were reported in or near Franklin, Blue Hill, Edgar and Ayr, with a home weather station northwest of Red Cloud clocking a peak gust of 73 MPH. Although no tornadoes occurred, the environment was conducive for a few gustnadoes along thunderstorm outflow, including one captured on storm chaser video east of Alma. On another severe weather side note, an intense lightning bolt struck a large tree in Hastings around 915 p.m. CDT, setting the tree on fire and scattering limbs as far as 100 feet. Rainfall-wise, the vast majority of the local area received well under 1, with the main exception of higher amounts concentrated in Nuckolls and Thayer counties, where a NeRAIN observer near Nora measured 1.77. ||Breaking down event timing, storms first flared up along the well-defined surface cold front between 6-7 p.m. CDT, with convection then expanding in coverage and tracking east through the evening. Although most strong to severe storms exited east of the local area by 10 p.m. CDT, regenerative development of stronger cores along the southern end of the complex persisted through around midnight CDT, mainly in Nuckolls/Thayer counties. All in all, this was a fairly standard issue first severe weather event of the season, primarily driven by low-level frontal forcing. Early in the evening, this northeast-southwest oriented front stretched across the heart of the local area, tied into a 998 millibar low pressure center in north central Kansas. Although afternoon temperatures ahead of the boundary warmed well into the 80s F, rather meager dewpoints only in the 40s likely precluded a potentially greater severe weather threat. Nonetheless, the presence of steep low-mid level lapse rates promoted sufficient mixed-layer CAPE of 500-1000 J/kg in the presence of decent 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-50 knots. In the mid-upper levels, southwesterly flow was fairly modest for this time of year, as the primary large scale trough shifted from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains.

Late afternoon thunderstorms produced damaging winds and large hail across portions of Kimball and Cheyenne counties in the southern Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer at the Kimball Airport reported quarter size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon thunderstorms produced damaging winds and large hail across portions of Kimball and Cheyenne counties in the southern Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated at 60 mph east of Sidney.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half dollar size hail was observed at the Wildcat Hills State Recreation Area south of Gering.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ping pong ball size hail was reported two miles north-northeast of Henry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail was reported two miles east-northeast of Henry.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail accumulated four inches deep.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tennis ball size hail destroyed hay bales and corn crops.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail accumulated four inches deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail accumulated two inches deep.  Leaves were stripped from trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail broke windows at a residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 mph occurred in Venango.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds estimated at 50 mph winds as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported quarter size hail and winds estimated at 50 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A swath of damaging winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas early this Friday evening. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours. Between 4 and 5 p.m. CST, several storms combined into a very small bow echo configuration over Furnas County Nebraska. This storm entered northwestern Phillips County Kansas around 5 p.m. and subsequently raced east-southeast across north central Kansas, exiting Mitchell County by 730 p.m. CST. This cluster of storms was responsible for a swath of wind damage across Phillips, Smith and Mitchell counties. Multiple wind gusts were measured at 58 mph or above. The highest wind speed recorded was 73 mph at the Smith Center airport. Large tree limbs were also reported down in several locations. A separate isolated storm, tracking along the Nebraska-Kansas border, intensified over northeastern Jewell County. This storm also produced wind damage, overturning an irrigation pivot and scattering irrigation pipes.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.

Widespread wind, hail, and flooding occurred, starting overnight on the 24th into the 25th. While flooding was the biggest problem, mainly in Missouri for the morning of the 25th, severe weather moved in and brought a wide area of severe reports across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a 70 mph wind gust in Olathe.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.

Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

A couple storms briefly produced sub-severe hail on this Friday evening and night. Just after 7 p.m. CST, a string of isolated showers, and a couple embedded thunderstorms, developed along the Highway 136 corridor. Around 9 pm, the storm on the western end of the string strengthened over northwestern Franklin county. This storm maintained its strength as it moved east-northeast, and over southwestern Clay county, it dropped hail up to the size of dimes. The storm then weakened over Fillmore county around midnight. Shortly thereafter, a new line of scattered thunderstorms formed from Fillmore county northwest across Clay, Hall, and Buffalo counties. As this line drifted east, one of the embedded storms briefly intensified, producing hail up to the size of nickels near Grand Island.||Late in the day on Thursday, April 30th, a very weak Canadian cold front moved into Nebraska. This front became stationary across the central third of Nebraska Friday and eventually dissipated by evening. There was very little forcing for these storms aloft. Seasonably strong high pressure was over the Desert Southwest, with zonal flow from the Pacific Northwest into the Northern Plains. All this convective activity formed in an area of low-level convergence, near the frontal remnants, at the terminus of a 35 knot low-level jet. Mid-level lapse rates and instability were low. MUCAPE was around 500 J/kg. Shear in the cloud-bearing layer was 20 to 30 knots. However, this environment was sufficient to produce storms strong enough for small hail.

Two brief tornadoes occurred in Harlan County on this Saturday evening, with a couple reports of severe hail as well nearby. Scattered thunderstorms developed over north central Kansas between 530 and 600 p.m. CST. Several small thunderstorms lifted north, into and through Harlan County, over the following two hours. The last storm to move through produced a couple brief, weak tornadoes around 730 p.m. CST. This storm also produced one inch hail in a couple locations over Phelps County, just after 8 p.m. CST. Other small thunderstorms continued across south central Nebraska, and just before 11 p.m., a storm briefly became strong enough to produce a few one inch hailstones in Kearney. However, most of the hail was the size of nickels or smaller.||A continental polar air mass was over the region, but lee cyclogenesis was underway. By midnight, low pressure had migrated from northwestern Kansas and into south central Nebraska. The associated warm front had also lifted north along with it. At upper-levels, a deep trough was over the Rockies with a closed low over Colorado, and a coupled jet streak configuration. A ridge was downstream over the eastern United States. South central Nebraska had been shrouded in low stratus and fog all day, with temperatures struggling to rise through the 50s. Dewpoints depressions were very low. MUCAPE was only 500 J/kg, but deep layer shear was around 45 knots. Strengthening and significantly veering low-level wind fields resulted in 0-1 km SRH of 200-300 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief touchdown north-northeast of Stamford. No damage was reported with this tornado.
