Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The 911 call center reported that thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 mph occurred in Chappell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A swath of damaging winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas early this Friday evening. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours. Between 4 and 5 p.m. CST, several storms combined into a very small bow echo configuration over Furnas County Nebraska. This storm entered northwestern Phillips County Kansas around 5 p.m. and subsequently raced east-southeast across north central Kansas, exiting Mitchell County by 730 p.m. CST. This cluster of storms was responsible for a swath of wind damage across Phillips, Smith and Mitchell counties. Multiple wind gusts were measured at 58 mph or above. The highest wind speed recorded was 73 mph at the Smith Center airport. Large tree limbs were also reported down in several locations. A separate isolated storm, tracking along the Nebraska-Kansas border, intensified over northeastern Jewell County. This storm also produced wind damage, overturning an irrigation pivot and scattering irrigation pipes.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An outbuilding suffered roof damage approximately 9 miles north of Phillipsburg. This was on the east side of Highway 183 just south of Hunter Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi-linear convective system moved through east central Kansas and west central Missouri producing multiple QLCS tornadoes and significant damage associated with numerous mesovortices. Interestingly, there was a supercell ahead of the line that also produced a tornado. Also, this line of storms produced extreme rain rates and widespread flash flooding was reported throughout the Kansas City area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The EM reported that 7 Mile Creek was flowing over Highway 5 making it impassible and closing the road down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe hail and winds occurred in Furnas county late this Friday afternoon. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the early and mid afternoon hours. By 4 p.m. CST, several storms began began affecting northern and western Furnas county, producing hail up to one inch in diameter and estimated winds up to 60 mph. By 5 p.m., these storms had combined into a very small bow echo configuration over the eastern part of the county. This bow echo then raced across north central Kansas producing a swath of wind damage.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.
Storms across the far sections of Southeast Kansas produced one tornado and several funnel clouds.  Wind gusts to 65 mph were also noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A minor amount of water was reported over the road at the railroad crossing at highway 160 and highway 59.  Rooks road at 8000 Road was also closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells rapidly lifted north into south central Nebraska and began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. Most of the tornadoes occurred over Nuckolls and Thayer counties. One tornado did occur over Adams county and a brief spin-up also occurred over Hall county. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary. New storms repeatedly developed over north central Kansas and lifted northeast along the boundary, through Nuckolls and Thayer counties and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 5-11 inches of rain over portions of Nuckolls and Thayer counties. The highest amount reported was 10.91 inches just west of Hebron. This amount of rainfall in 24 hours typically occurs once in 1,000 years at any given location, or stated another way, has a .1% chance of occurrence in a given 24 hour period. Cooperative observers in Hebron and Superior reported 8.59 and 7.13 inches, respectively. These were the highest 24-hour rainfall amounts ever recorded at these locations, dating back to 1893. Flash flooding damaged roads and some bridges were washed out. U.S. Highways 81 and 136 were closed for a time due to the flooding.||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 feet. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This is a continuation of the tornado that touched down in the Scandia area of Republic County, KS.  This tornado was rated an EF2, with an estimated peak wind speed of 120 MPH. The strongest and widest portion of this tornado occurred in Republic County, KS.||In the Thayer County, NE, portion of this tornado, trees were damaged and pivots were overturned. Power poles and grain bins were damaged. One home southeast of Hebron had its roof partially removed. This tornado crossed Highway 81 approximately 6 miles south of Hebron.

Flash flooding damaged roads and some bridges were washed out. EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado was rated an EF0, with an estimated peak wind speed of 80 MPH. Damage from this tornado included a few overturned train cars west of Carleton and overturned irrigation pivots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm produced hail to the size of nickels in far southern Osborne County (north of Luray) very early on this Friday morning. Several small thunderstorms initiated around midnight over Ellis County and quickly merged as they lifted northeast. Over the following two hours, other storms initiated over north central Kansas, forming a northwest-southeast oriented line. One storm embedded within the line was strong enough to produce this nickel size hail. ||A weak low pressure system was advancing through the Northern Plains. Low pressure was over Minnesota, with the associated cold front extending southwest across Nebraska into Wyoming. These storms formed in the warm sector, well ahead of the front. In the upper-levels, a longwave trough was over the western United States, with a ridge over the East. These storms developed just after the passage of a shortwave ridge. Synoptic forcing was negligible. While the strongest warm air advection was further north over Nebraska, these storms did initiate near the nose of a 30-40 knot low-level jet. MUCAPE was around 1000 J/kg and deep layer shear was around 20 knots.

A broken line of storms developed over northeastern Kansas and northwestern Missouri producing a few reports of large hail, winds and flooding. A bluff adjacent to Highway 7 at mile marker 246 collapsed obstructing one lane of the highway.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: K7 in White Cloud was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early afternoon thunderstorms over Morrill County produced large hail, damaging winds and very heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed 16 miles east-northeast of Lynn.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early afternoon thunderstorms over Morrill County produced large hail, damaging winds and very heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of rain from thunderstorms produced flash flooding.  Highway 92 was closed by high water from County Road 119 to the intersection of Highway 385 west of Broadwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated near 60 mph over part of Harlan County on this Saturday evening. Areas of leftover rain, mainly from earlier thunderstorms, were lifting north out of Kansas. Along the leading edge, an embedded thunderstorm developed over Harlan County. Winds were estimated near 60 mph just northwest of Huntley. Radar suggested that these winds could have been associated with an outflow boundary associated with the earlier thunderstorms.||An occluding low pressure system was over the Northern Plains. Its associated cold front extended southward into western Nebraska. A deep trough was over the western United States, and a ridge over the East. A negatively-tilted shortwave trough was exiting out of the trough base into the Southern Plains. MUCAPE was only 500 J/kg. However, deep layer shear was around 50 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms moved into the southeastern panhandle during the evening on June 1st.  Damaging winds of 60 mph caused tree damage near Chappell in Deuel County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts downed 6 to 8 inch diameter tree branches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 5 miles southwest of White Clay estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of 70 mph for a few minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter located 3 miles north northwest of Rushville reported several trees were blown over.

Cooperative observers in Hebron and Superior reported 8.59 and 7.13 inches, respectively. These were the highest 24-hour rainfall amounts ever recorded at these locations, dating back to 1893. Flash flooding damaged roads and some bridges were washed out. U.S. Highways 81 and 136 were closed for a time due to the flooding.||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 feet. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24 hour storm total rainfall amount of 8.20 inches was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of storms developed over northeastern Kansas and northwestern Missouri producing a few reports of large hail, winds and flooding. A bluff adjacent to Highway 7 at mile marker 246 collapsed obstructing one lane of the highway.

Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hen egg size hail was observed three miles west of Court House and Jail Rock.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed eight miles southeast of Broadwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated wind gusts of 65 mph were observed eight miles southeast of Broadwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly two inches of rain in 30 to 45 minutes resulted in widespread flash flooding in and around Scottsbluff.  There were numerous reports of more than a foot of water running over streets in Scottsbluff.  Several businesses were flooded on Broadway Street.  Vehicles were stranded in flood waters on 5th Avenue in Scottsbluff.  County Road 15 was closed west of  Scottsbluff.  Standing water was reported on Highways 26 and 92.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and evening thunderstorms produced very heavy rain, strong winds and numerous reports of large hail across central and southern portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly two inches of rain in 30 to 45 minutes resulted in flash flooding.  Portions of County Road 15 and trees were washed away a mile east of Mitchell.  County Road 15 was closed between Mitchell and Scottsbluff.  Standing water was reported on Highway 92 between Scottsbluff and Mitchell.

However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24 hour storm total rainfall amount of 5.10 inches was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 10 miles south southeast of Clinton reported thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fire department reported that hail up to softball size knocked out all windows on the north side of the house and most windows of the vehicles on the property.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells rapidly lifted north into south central Nebraska and began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. Most of the tornadoes occurred over Nuckolls and Thayer counties. One tornado did occur over Adams county and a brief spin-up also occurred over Hall county. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary. New storms repeatedly developed over north central Kansas and lifted northeast along the boundary, through Nuckolls and Thayer counties and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 5-11 inches of rain over portions of Nuckolls and Thayer counties. The highest amount reported was 10.91 inches just west of Hebron. This amount of rainfall in 24 hours typically occurs once in 1,000 years at any given location, or stated another way, has a .1% chance of occurrence in a given 24 hour period. Cooperative observers in Hebron and Superior reported 8.59 and 7.13 inches, respectively. These were the highest 24-hour rainfall amounts ever recorded at these locations, dating back to 1893. Flash flooding damaged roads and some bridges were washed out. U.S. Highways 81 and 136 were closed for a time due to the flooding.||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 feet. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 75 MPH, with tree limbs downed in town. The local fire chief reported to a radio station that a lean-to building just south of town had been destroyed.

An isolated storm produced hail up to the size of quarters on this Friday evening. Early in the evening, a few isolated, small storms formed over north central Kansas and lifted north into south central Nebraska, west of Highway 183. The storm that tracked through Furnas and Gosper counties produced hail up to the size of quarters around mid-evening, west and north of Arapahoe.||These storms formed in the warm sector of occluding low pressure over Wyoming. A longwave trough was over the western United States, with a ridge over the East, resulting in southwest flow over the Plains. What exactly ignited these storms was unclear, as synoptic and mesoscale forcing were weak. MLCAPE was 1000-1500 J/kg and deep layer shear was 40 knots.

An isolated storm produced hail up to the size of quarters on this Friday evening. Early in the evening, a few isolated, small storms formed over north central Kansas and lifted north into south central Nebraska, west of Highway 183. The storm that tracked through Furnas and Gosper counties produced hail up to the size of quarters around mid-evening, west and north of Arapahoe.||These storms formed in the warm sector of occluding low pressure over Wyoming. A longwave trough was over the western United States, with a ridge over the East, resulting in southwest flow over the Plains. What exactly ignited these storms was unclear, as synoptic and mesoscale forcing were weak. MLCAPE was 1000-1500 J/kg and deep layer shear was 40 knots.

Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.

A swath of damaging winds occurred across portions of north central Kansas early this Friday evening. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the afternoon hours. Between 4 and 5 p.m. CST, several storms combined into a very small bow echo configuration over Furnas County Nebraska. This storm entered northwestern Phillips County Kansas around 5 p.m. and subsequently raced east-southeast across north central Kansas, exiting Mitchell County by 730 p.m. CST. This cluster of storms was responsible for a swath of wind damage across Phillips, Smith and Mitchell counties. Multiple wind gusts were measured at 58 mph or above. The highest wind speed recorded was 73 mph at the Smith Center airport. Large tree limbs were also reported down in several locations. A separate isolated storm, tracking along the Nebraska-Kansas border, intensified over northeastern Jewell County. This storm also produced wind damage, overturning an irrigation pivot and scattering irrigation pipes.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. However, the dry sub-cloud layer did allow for storms to form along a common cold pool and accelerate. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be between 60 and 70 MPH. Penny sized hail accompanied the wind.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were broken, screens were knocked out, and a car was damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple storms briefly produced sub-severe hail on this Friday evening and night. Just after 7 p.m. CST, a string of isolated showers, and a couple embedded thunderstorms, developed along the Highway 136 corridor. Around 9 pm, the storm on the western end of the string strengthened over northwestern Franklin county. This storm maintained its strength as it moved east-northeast, and over southwestern Clay county, it dropped hail up to the size of dimes. The storm then weakened over Fillmore county around midnight. Shortly thereafter, a new line of scattered thunderstorms formed from Fillmore county northwest across Clay, Hall, and Buffalo counties. As this line drifted east, one of the embedded storms briefly intensified, producing hail up to the size of nickels near Grand Island.||Late in the day on Thursday, April 30th, a very weak Canadian cold front moved into Nebraska. This front became stationary across the central third of Nebraska Friday and eventually dissipated by evening. There was very little forcing for these storms aloft. Seasonably strong high pressure was over the Desert Southwest, with zonal flow from the Pacific Northwest into the Northern Plains. All this convective activity formed in an area of low-level convergence, near the frontal remnants, at the terminus of a 35 knot low-level jet. Mid-level lapse rates and instability were low. MUCAPE was around 500 J/kg. Shear in the cloud-bearing layer was 20 to 30 knots. However, this environment was sufficient to produce storms strong enough for small hail.

Widespread wind, hail, and flooding occurred, starting overnight on the 24th into the 25th. While flooding was the biggest problem, mainly in Missouri for the morning of the 25th, severe weather moved in and brought a wide area of severe reports across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee reported a 60 mph wind gust with some storm sthat moved through Stanley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms produced large hail, strong winds and torrential rain across portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County Road 13 was flooded with two to three feet of water west of Scottsbluff.  Several other roads near the Mitchell and Gering canals were flooded.  Highway 92 was flooded at two locations with swift flowing water six to eight inches deep.  County Road L between County Road 16 and Rifle Site Road was covered by fast moving water.  South Mitchell Road flooded from just south of Mitchell to Highway 92.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe hail and winds occurred in Furnas county late this Friday afternoon. Scattered thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska during the early and mid afternoon hours. By 4 p.m. CST, several storms began began affecting northern and western Furnas county, producing hail up to one inch in diameter and estimated winds up to 60 mph. By 5 p.m., these storms had combined into a very small bow echo configuration over the eastern part of the county. This bow echo then raced across north central Kansas producing a swath of wind damage.||These storms formed within a cold frontal zone. Aloft, a trough was over the Rockies with an embedded shortwave trough advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. A ridge was over the eastern United States. Temperatures in the upper 70s and dewpoints in the upper 50s combined with poor mid-level lapse rates to produce MLCAPE between 500 and 1000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. Five tornadoes occurred over Jewell County. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. It was about this time that a short line formed from the Jewell-Smith County line south into Osborne County. Supercells were embedded within this line and several discrete supercells developed ahead of it over Mitchell and Jewell counties. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary, with new storms repeatedly developing over north central Kansas and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 4-8 inches of rain over portions of Jewell County. The highest amount reported was 7.92 inches near Webber. ||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 ft. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE was around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.

Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail to ping pong ball size with 40 to 50 mph wind gusts broke windows on north side of house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 75 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced a landspout tornado late morning near North Platte, then damaging winds by early evening near North Platte.  In Hooker County, large hail was reported in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1125CST, a landspout tornado formed about 7 miles south southeast of North Platte in an open field and drifted slowly to the west. The tornado lifted at 1129CST with no damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of the 15th a severe bow echo rolled through eastern KS causing wind damage. That evening a left over boundary allowed a supercell to form. This storm was long lived and produced large hail and severe winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous trees down in Jamestown.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of thunderstorms led to significant river flooding along many river in southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa during the early part of June. The first episode of heavy rainfall came during the early morning hours on June 4th when thunderstorms lifted north across southeast Nebraska into southwest Iowa to the north of a warm front. Additional thunderstorms moved along this warm front during the morning on the 4th, followed by even heavier and slower moving thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of the 4th. The combination of these repeated rainfalls on already saturated ground led to river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding was observed along the Missouri River near Rulo. The river crested 3.34 feet above flood stage. The flooding was confined to mainly low areas near the river channel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread wind, hail, and flooding occurred, starting overnight on the 24th into the 25th. While flooding was the biggest problem, mainly in Missouri for the morning of the 25th, severe weather moved in and brought a wide area of severe reports across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 18 inch tree blew down along with lots of limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread wind, hail, and flooding occurred, starting overnight on the 24th into the 25th. While flooding was the biggest problem, mainly in Missouri for the morning of the 25th, severe weather moved in and brought a wide area of severe reports across the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large oak trees were snapped. Report was received via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A window was broken, screens were knocked out, and a car sustained damage from tennis ball size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

Quarter size hail was reported in two locations on this Saturday evening. Late in the afternoon, scattered thunderstorms developed between Ord and McCook. The storms were brief and quickly dissipated along and south of Interstate 80. To the north of the Interstate, instability was greater. The storms continued and strengthened, with a couple briefly turning severe, producing hail up to 1 inch in diameter near Greeley and Clarks. ||These storms formed within a broad warm sector, ahead of the lee-side trough that became mobile and advanced east into the central third of Nebraska. There was no discernible forcing aloft as the flow was zonal, and the subtropical and polar jet streams were far to the south and north, respectively. Surface dewpoint depressions were large, with temperatures in the mid 80s and dewpoints in the upper 40s. However, mid-level lapse rates were around 7.5 deg C/km, resulting in MLCAPE of 1000-1250 J/kg north of I-80. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.

Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows and a truck windshield were broken.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Softball size hail put holes in roof and living room ceiling. All vehicles sustained significant damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed across northwest Nebraska during the late evening hours on June 20th and continued overnight as storms moved southeast. The storms produced large hail up to the size of softballs and damaging winds.

During the late afternoon and evening hours on this Thursday, scattered to numerous thunderstorms rumbled through South Central Nebraska counties mainly along and south of the Interstate 80 corridor, resulting in a handful of sub-severe hail reports in the penny to nickel size range. Although radar data suggested that various other locations likely experienced hail up to around this size, the only ground-truth reports originated from Hastings, Edgar and from the vicinities of Kearney, Sutton and Clay Center. While most of this convection was multicellular and linear, there were a few briefly semi-discrete structures as well. Rainfall amounts under most of the heaviest convection averaged between 0.50 and 1, with only few localized higher exceptions. ||Strong storms first developed into southwestern counties such as Harlan and Franklin between 430-600 p.m. CDT. Then between 6-9 p.m. CDT, a couple of narrow west-to-east arcs of strong storms developed eastward through the Highway 6 and Interstate 80 corridors and lifted slowly north, resulting in the aforementioned hail reports. After nightfall, a few stronger storms lingered over mainly Thayer and Fillmore counties for a time, but these steadily faded with the loss of diurnal heating. In the mid and upper levels, weak forcing was provided by small-scale disturbances shifting into the Central Plains on southerly flow aloft, well-downstream from an expansive large-scale closed low spinning over the Four Corners region. At the surface, afternoon high temperatures only climbed between the mid-60s and low-70s F across most of the area, but the combination of surface dewpoints in the mid-50s and rather cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -16 C) was sufficient to promote modest surface-based CAPE as high as 500-1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear only around 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail occurred on the east side of Edgar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of thunderstorms led to significant river flooding along many river in southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa during the early part of June. The first episode of heavy rainfall came during the early morning hours on June 4th when thunderstorms lifted north across southeast Nebraska into southwest Iowa to the north of a warm front. Additional thunderstorms moved along this warm front during the morning on the 4th, followed by even heavier and slower moving thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of the 4th. The combination of these repeated rainfalls on already saturated ground led to river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flooding was observed along the Big Nemaha River near Falls City. The flooding including closing of many gravel and county roads, as well State Highway 8. The flooding also included agricultural low-lands along the river as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of thunderstorms led to significant river flooding along many river in southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa during the early part of June. The first episode of heavy rainfall came during the early morning hours on June 4th when thunderstorms lifted north across southeast Nebraska into southwest Iowa to the north of a warm front. Additional thunderstorms moved along this warm front during the morning on the 4th, followed by even heavier and slower moving thunderstorms during the late afternoon and evening of the 4th. The combination of these repeated rainfalls on already saturated ground led to river flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant flooding occurred along the West Fork of Big Blue River, especially upstream of Dorchester near Beaver Crossing. Here some county road were closed and structures near the river channel at Beaver Crossing were flooded. Only minor low-land agricultural flooding near the river channel was observed near Dorchester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms in Custer County caused isolated reports of large hail during the late morning and early afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms in Custer County caused isolated reports of large hail during the late morning and early afternoon hours.
A line of thunderstorms brought hail, heavy rain, and some flooding during the evening hours to eastern portions of north central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding caused a road to wash out 10 miles northeast of O'Neill.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms brought hail, heavy rain, and some flooding during the evening hours to eastern portions of north central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding covered a road 13 miles north of Page.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening law enforcement estimated wind gusts of 90 MPH from a severe thunderstorm near Tribune.  No damage was reported from these winds.  This same thunderstorm brought rapid, heavy rainfall to western parts of the county.  Law enforcement officers reported water over Highway 96 from Horace to Tribune.  Rainfall totals a mile or two west of Tribune ranged from 1.10 inches to 1.86 inches, with estimated rainfall amounts close to three inches between Horace and the county line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding was reported on Highway 96 from Horace to Tribune.  With higher rainfall amounts to the west of this report area roads also had flooding in low lying areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gust of 60 MPH reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree branches up to 5 inches in diameter reported down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Semi trailer blown over on highway 83 at mile marker 138.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured wind gust at the Ainsworth Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mostly nickel size hail fell, with a few quarter size hail stones mixed in.

Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.

For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24-hour rainfall total of 3.30...most of which fell during the evening of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th. Two-day rainfall totals of 3-7 were common within much of Adams, Clay, Fillmore, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall, southern Hamilton and southern York counties, resulting in significant flooding across parts of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms in association with a strong upper level trough of low pressure developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 17th. As this activity moved east, damaging winds developed across north central and central Nebraska. Large hail to teacup size was reported across southwestern Nebraska.

Severe thunderstorms in association with a strong upper level trough of low pressure developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 17th. As this activity moved east, damaging winds developed across north central and central Nebraska. Large hail to teacup size was reported across southwestern Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In addition to quarter sized hail, 50 MPH winds were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms in association with a strong upper level trough of low pressure developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 17th. As this activity moved east, damaging winds developed across north central and central Nebraska. Large hail to teacup size was reported across southwestern Nebraska.
A cluster of severe thunderstorms produced large hail over southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A picture from social media showed baseball size hail near Highway 47 and Highway 3. Several residences had damaged roofs and windows to homes.  Several cars received severe damage with dents and cracked windshields.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous strong to occasionally severe multicell storms blossomed across South Central Nebraska from the late evening of Wednesday the 3rd into the morning hours of Thursday the 4th, serving as round 1 of an active few days of severe storms and flooding rainfall. With storms ranging in character from semi-discrete to clusters and line segments, they primarily produced hail up to around quarter size, along with heavy rain. Although convection affected parts of several counties at some point during the night, the majority of ground-truth severe weather reports emanated from Adams and Clay counties, including quarter size hail on the east side of Hastings, hail up to golf ball size in Clay Center, and several hours later, a combination of quarter size hail and estimated 60 MPH winds six miles east-southeast of Clay Center. Rainfall-wise, the big story of the night was a concentrated swath of generally 1.50-3.00 that fell over southern Hall/northern Adams counties, southeastward through most of Clay, Fillmore and northern Thayer counties. Within this corridor, a few of the highest overnight totals from NeRAIN observers included 3.13 near Alexandria and 3.00 a few miles northwest of Hastings. As a result, minor flooding affected several creeks and streams and some roadways. In fact, the southbound lanes of Highway 281 in far-southern Hall County were closed for a few hours during the night due to flooding. Although this generally minor flooding subsided during the day of the 4th, unfortunately many of these same areas would soon be drenched with another 2-4 on the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th, resulting in 36-hour totals of 3-7 and a more serious, widespread flooding situation (please refer to the separate June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. severe weather episode for further details). ||Breaking down the overall event timing, all convection through the pre-dark hours focused to the south over northern Kansas. Then, between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT, storms began developing northward into the southern two rows of South Central Nebraska counties, largely in response to a strengthening, northward-lifting low level jet. Over the course of the next several hours, numerous strong to occasionally severe storms continued spreading north and east across the area, with half dollar size hail reported as far north as southern Greeley County. Within the aforementioned primary zone of heavy rain, the majority fell between 2:30-6:00 a.m. CDT. As one area of storms was in the process of exiting eastern counties of the local area around sunrise, a separate, quick-moving line of non-severe convection moved in from the southwest, sweeping across most of South Central Nebraska between 5-9 a.m. CDT. Although a few storms persisted here and there through late-morning, most places began a brief respite before the next round of evening/overnight storms arrived. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front residing near the Nebraska-Kansas border through the night, seasonably-strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet taking direct aim on the local area, this was a well-anticipated nocturnal convective flare-up. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. At the time of the first severe-criteria hail reports around 11:30 p.m. CDT, the environment featured most-unstable CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg and 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to half dollar size hail occurred...report relayed by broadcast media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall totaled generally 4-7 across primarily southern Hamilton County between the 3rd-6th, with the majority of this rain falling on the 4th-5th. Localized road flooding was initially reported across parts of the county on the evening of the 4th. Over the next few days, the main story turned to the West Fork Big Blue River and its smaller stream tributaries in the southern part of the county, as the cumulative effects of multiple rounds of heavy rain resulted in significant flooding, mainly on the 5th-6th. Reports indicated that this may have been some of the worst flooding observed along the river in 50-80 years. A few days of warm and dry weather settled in from June 7-9, allowing flood waters to largely recede.

In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.

It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall totaled generally 4-7 across much of Fillmore County between the 3rd-6th, with the majority of this rain falling on the 4th-5th. The cumulative effects of multiple heavy rains resulted in significant flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River and its smaller stream tributaries in the northern part of the county, mainly on the 6th-7th. Reports indicated that this may have been some the worst flooding observed along the river in 50-80 years. A few days of warm and dry weather settled in from June 7-9, allowing flood waters to largely recede. However, another focused area of 1.50-3.00 of heavy rain targeted the York and northern Fillmore counties area on the night of the 10th into the morning of the 11th. This again pushed the West Fork Big Blue River out of its banks in the McCool Junction area from the 11th into the 12th, before this multiple-day flooding event finally came to a close.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a stationary front across western Nebraska and northeastern Colorado during the late afternoon hours on July 18th. As this activity moved east it became severe across the western Nebraska Sandhills and southwestern Nebraska. Damaging winds impacted crops and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 MPH, along with hail of an unknown size reported. The strong winds and hail stripped corn, led to roof damage and injured livestock at this location.
