EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a fairly classic meteorological setup for June severe weather in place, numerous semi-discrete strong to severe thunderstorms blossomed across this six-county North Central Kansas area on this Wednesday evening the 3rd into early Thursday morning the 4th. While these storms yielded mainly quarter size hail, and one report up to 2 diameter south of Burr Oak, the storm of the night was a slow-moving tornadic supercell that peaked in intensity from far east-central Osborne into central Mitchell County between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT. This storm produced three confirmed after-dark tornadoes, two rated EF-1 with path lengths around one mile near the Osborne/Mitchell County line west of Tipton, and a brief EF-0 touchdown slightly east of Tipton. The two stronger tornadoes, one of which moved east and one west under the parent mesocyclone, damaged or destroyed several farm outbuildings, but no injuries occurred. Around midnight CDT, this storm began losing supercell structure and weakening as it drifted northeast through the Beloit area. In addition to tornadoes, this storm produced torrential rainfall of at least 3-4 in a short time across central and western portions of Mitchell County. Other storms produced a swath of heavy rain of generally 1.50-3.00 across much of southern Jewell County. However, the majority of the six-county area totaled no more than 0.50-1.00.  ||Breaking down the overall event timing, several strong to severe storms first blossomed over Rooks and Osborne counties between 700-830 p.m. CDT. Over the next few hours, activity gradually expanded to the north and east, as the aforementioned tornadic supercell took center stage around nightfall. Between 130-230 a.m. CDT on the 4th, storms vacated the entire six-county area to the north and east. Several hours later between 6-8 a.m. CDT, additional elevated storms flared up primarily east of Highway 281, but were non-severe. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front draped through the northern half of Kansas, seasonably strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet ramping up during the night, this was a well-anticipated severe weather event. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. While modest capping held storms at bay through the afternoon, the combination of subtle, low-amplitude disturbances aloft and increasing lift along the developing low level jet sparked a rapid evening flare-up. At the surface, the evening hours featured steady easterly breezes and dewpoints in the mid-upper 60s F. Around the time the tornadic supercell developed, the mesoscale environment featured mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots, and fairly strong 0-1 kilometer storm-relative helicity of at least 150 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This report was received via Facebook.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado moved west, and began with damage to a silo and large metal building. On the tornado's trek, it tossed grain bin debris about three quarters of a mile. The tornado narrowly missed a new home, but damaged a vacant home on the same property. The tornado lifted in a field west of the farmstead. The movement of this tornado, along with the eastward moving tornado to the south, suggested that the parent mesocyclone associated with the supercell storm was near the ground and that the two tornadoes were rotating within that circulation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms produced a small tornado that hit Eudora.  The tornado tracked around 6.5 miles doing sporadic tree damage along its path. Some portions of the line produced severe wind gusts and caused damage. Heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in Jackson and Shawnee counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was day 4 in a row with severe weather.  A dryline was one focusing mechanism for severe weather.  Otherwise, supercell thunderstorms developed in a the atmosphere was unstable enough with shear to produce severe weather.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts measured.

A cold front advanced across the area during the afternoon and evening.  There were also residual outflow boundaries from convection the day before that provided a focusing area for thunderstorm development.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was also 60 MPH winds estimated at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms brought hail, heavy rain, and some flooding during the evening hours to eastern portions of north central Nebraska.
A line of thunderstorms brought hail, heavy rain, and some flooding during the evening hours to eastern portions of north central Nebraska.
An isolated thunderstorm produced large hail in northwest Keith County during the early morning hours on June 7th.

Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours on June 10th and produced hail, heavy rainfall and flash flooding in portions of Lincoln County. The thunderstorms developed  northeastward and produced areas of damaging winds in Custer, Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Wheeler County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of 60 mph in Taylor.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours on June 10th and produced hail, heavy rainfall and flash flooding in portions of Lincoln County. The thunderstorms developed  northeastward and produced areas of damaging winds in Custer, Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Wheeler County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cooperative observer estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of 60 mph in Burwell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours on June 10th and produced hail, heavy rainfall and flash flooding in portions of Lincoln County. The thunderstorms developed  northeastward and produced areas of damaging winds in Custer, Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Wheeler County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public estimated thunderstorm wind gusts of 60 mph located 8 miles east northeast of Burwell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours on June 10th and produced hail, heavy rainfall and flash flooding in portions of Lincoln County. The thunderstorms developed  northeastward and produced areas of damaging winds in Custer, Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Wheeler County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement in Bartlett reported roof damage from thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 70 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gust of 60 MPH reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous small and large tree branches down at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of a metal roof was blown off of a residents home.  In addition, extensive water damage was also reported to this residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Along with severe limb damage to trees and uprooted trees, lawn furniture was blown over 100 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust estimated at 65 MPH at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level disturbance initiated thunderstorms across northern Nebraska on the evening of July 4th.  Some storms became severe over northern Cherry County to produce one inch diameter hail.

For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24-hour rainfall total of 3.00 in Clay Center...most of which fell during the evening of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th. Also within Clay County, NeRAIN observers reported 24-hour total of 3.75 in Harvard and 3.34 four miles southwest of Sutton. For the 36-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, Harvard totaled an impressive 6.44. Two-day rainfall totals of 3-7 were common within much of Adams, Clay, Fillmore, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall, southern Hamilton and southern York counties, resulting in significant flooding across parts of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms in association with a strong upper level trough of low pressure developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 17th. As this activity moved east, damaging winds developed across north central and central Nebraska. Large hail to teacup size was reported across southwestern Nebraska.

This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall totaled generally 4-7 across primarily northern Adams County between the 3rd-6th, with the majority of this rain falling on the 4th-5th. Road flooding was initially reported across parts of the county on the evening of the 4th. On the morning of the 5th, the Adams County Department of Roads reported that many roads (paved and gravel) were closed due to severe flooding, especially within the northeast quadrant of the county. Just as one example of these road closures, paved Showboat Road from 12th Street to 26th Street was barricaded on the east side of Hastings for several hours on the 5th. The flooding situation gradually improved over the following 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall totaled generally 4-7 across primarily northern Adams County between the 3rd-6th, with the majority of this rain falling on the 4th-5th. Road flooding was initially reported across parts of the county on the evening of the 4th. On the morning of the 5th, the Adams County Department of Roads reported that many roads (paved and gravel) were closed due to severe flooding, especially within the northeast quadrant of the county. Just as one example of these road closures, paved Showboat Road from 12th Street to 26th Street was barricaded on the east side of Hastings for several hours on the 5th. The flooding situation gradually improved over the following 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 70 MPH resulted in large tree limbs being downed in Arcadia, some as large as 10-12 in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a fairly classic meteorological setup for June severe weather in place, numerous semi-discrete strong to severe thunderstorms blossomed across this six-county North Central Kansas area on this Wednesday evening the 3rd into early Thursday morning the 4th. While these storms yielded mainly quarter size hail, and one report up to 2 diameter south of Burr Oak, the storm of the night was a slow-moving tornadic supercell that peaked in intensity from far east-central Osborne into central Mitchell County between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT. This storm produced three confirmed after-dark tornadoes, two rated EF-1 with path lengths around one mile near the Osborne/Mitchell County line west of Tipton, and a brief EF-0 touchdown slightly east of Tipton. The two stronger tornadoes, one of which moved east and one west under the parent mesocyclone, damaged or destroyed several farm outbuildings, but no injuries occurred. Around midnight CDT, this storm began losing supercell structure and weakening as it drifted northeast through the Beloit area. In addition to tornadoes, this storm produced torrential rainfall of at least 3-4 in a short time across central and western portions of Mitchell County. Other storms produced a swath of heavy rain of generally 1.50-3.00 across much of southern Jewell County. However, the majority of the six-county area totaled no more than 0.50-1.00.  ||Breaking down the overall event timing, several strong to severe storms first blossomed over Rooks and Osborne counties between 700-830 p.m. CDT. Over the next few hours, activity gradually expanded to the north and east, as the aforementioned tornadic supercell took center stage around nightfall. Between 130-230 a.m. CDT on the 4th, storms vacated the entire six-county area to the north and east. Several hours later between 6-8 a.m. CDT, additional elevated storms flared up primarily east of Highway 281, but were non-severe. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front draped through the northern half of Kansas, seasonably strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet ramping up during the night, this was a well-anticipated severe weather event. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. While modest capping held storms at bay through the afternoon, the combination of subtle, low-amplitude disturbances aloft and increasing lift along the developing low level jet sparked a rapid evening flare-up. At the surface, the evening hours featured steady easterly breezes and dewpoints in the mid-upper 60s F. Around the time the tornadic supercell developed, the mesoscale environment featured mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots, and fairly strong 0-1 kilometer storm-relative helicity of at least 150 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief tornado that toppled an empty grain bin, and also topped an elm tree and knocked over a metal TV antenna before lifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and early evening thunderstorms across portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle produced large hail, torrential rain and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated at 60 to 65 mph 15 miles northwest of the Alliance Airport.  Utility lines were down and power was out for several hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of minor roof damage to a building.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree was uprooted and damage to a farmstead including broken windows.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power pole down at the intersection of road 80 and road V.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding over the Kansas turnpike at mile marker 118. This shut down the northbound lanes. A 21 year old male driver hydroplaned and lost control of his vehicle. The vehicle left the road and was then swept downstream by the flood waters. He was not able to survive.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado moved in from Meade County and turned north and then northwest dissipating just southeast of Montezuma.  A few pivot irrigation sprinklers were damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was day 4 in a row with severe weather.  A dryline was one focusing mechanism for severe weather.  Otherwise, supercell thunderstorms developed in a the atmosphere was unstable enough with shear to produce severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the hail was pea sized.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was day 4 in a row with severe weather.  A dryline was one focusing mechanism for severe weather.  Otherwise, supercell thunderstorms developed in a the atmosphere was unstable enough with shear to produce severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of 6 inches of water running across some streets in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level disturbance initiated thunderstorms across northern Nebraska on the evening of July 4th.  Some storms became severe over northern Cherry County to produce one inch diameter hail.
Isolated strong to severe storms hit portions of the eastern Nebraska Sandhills on the evening of July 1st.  Large hail up to an inch in diameter was reported.

During the late afternoon and into the evening a strong thunderstorm produced hail up to dime size along with flash flooding over Rawlins county.  Northwest of Atwood 1.20 inches of rain fell in 20 minutes, which lead to part of the North Beaver creek rising out of its banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The North Beaver creek was out of its banks.  Received a total of 1.30 inches of rainfall.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall totaled generally 4-7 across much of York County between the 3rd-6th, with the majority of this rain falling on the 4th-5th. Localized road flooding was initially reported in the York area on the evening of the 4th. Over the next few days, the main story turned to the West Fork Big Blue River in the southern part of the county, as significant flooding worked its way downstream, reaching the McCool Junction area on Saturday the 6th. Parts of McCool Junction were closed off due to flood waters and at least two homes were flooded. However, at least five homes were saved due to sandbagging efforts. All county roads crossing the river in southern York County were blocked off. Reports indicated that this may have bee some the worst flooding observed along the West Fork Big Blue in 50-80 years. Among other impacts, flood water entered Camp Kateri and the camp area was evacuated. A few days of warm and dry weather settled in from June 7-9, allowing flood waters to largely recede. However, another focused swath of 1.50-3.00 of heavy rain targeted the York and northern Fillmore counties area on the night of the 10th into the morning of the 11th. This again pushed the West Fork Big Blue River out of its banks in the McCool Junction area from the 11th into the 12th, before this multiple-day flooding event finally came to a close (see episode narrative for more details).

However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.

Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rainfall over parts of southeast Nebraska from the 6 into the 7th of May lead to minor flooding along the Missouri River. The river crested just above flood stage at 33.04 feet during the evening of the 8th of May, and resulted in just minor flooding of low-lands along the river.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall over parts of southeast Nebraska on the 6th and 7th of May resulting in minor flooding along the Missouri River near Rulo. The river crested at 17.30 feet, or .3 feet above flood state during the early morning on the 9th of May. The flooding was confined to low-lying areas along the river.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado moved in from Gray county and damaged power poles and a few trees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windows were blown out of vehicles and homes.  Power poles were blown down and trees that were at least 1 foot in diameter were blown over.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.

A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm passing to the north brought high wind on the south side.  A 61 year old male was killed when his modular home was overturned and destroyed by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a stationary front across western Nebraska and northeastern Colorado during the late afternoon hours on July 18th. As this activity moved east it became severe across the western Nebraska Sandhills and southwestern Nebraska. Damaging winds impacted crops and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated around 65 MPH at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of heavy rainfall totaled generally 4-7 across much of Clay County between the 3rd-6th, with the majority of this rain falling on the 4th-5th. Localized road flooding was initially reported across parts of the county on the evening of the 4th. Over the next few days, the main story turned to the West Fork Big Blue River and its smaller stream tributaries in the northern part of the county, as the cumulative effects of multiple rounds of heavy rain resulted in significant flooding, mainly on the 5th-6th. Reports indicated that this may have been some the worst flooding observed along the west fork Big Blue in 50-80 years. A few days of warm and dry weather settled in from June 7-9, allowing flood waters to largely recede.

Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate flooding occurred along the Big Blue River through northern and central Gage County. The flooding was extensive over the western and southern side of the city of Beatrice leading to many local streets to be closed, in addition to U.S. Highway 77 and U.S. 136. The Big Blue River at Beatrice crested at 30.11 feet, or 12.11 feet above flood stage late in the evening on the 7th.

Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rainfall of 3 to 7 inches feel upstream of the river gauge and allowed for the river to rise into moderate flooding near Barneston. This resulted in significant low-land flooding along the river. In addition, small streams near Wymore and Blue Springs backed up causing local flood problems in these areas. The Big Blue River near Barneston crested at 28.93 feet or 8.93 feet above flood stage during the morning on the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 7 inches across the Big Blue River basin led to minor flooding along the river near Crete. The flooding was even more significant to the south of the river gauge near DeWitt where the entire town was inundated with flooding leading to evacuations. The Big Blue River created near Crete at 24.21 feet, or 3.21 feet above flood stage during the afternoon of the 7th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A microburst produced at least 80 MPH winds with roof damage, door damage and tree damage reported in and around Boothill Museum in Dodge City.

The thunderstorms developed  northeastward and produced areas of damaging winds in Custer, Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Wheeler County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public reported tree damage from thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 70 mph located 13 miles east of Bartlett.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a fairly classic meteorological setup for June severe weather in place, numerous semi-discrete strong to severe thunderstorms blossomed across this six-county North Central Kansas area on this Wednesday evening the 3rd into early Thursday morning the 4th. While these storms yielded mainly quarter size hail, and one report up to 2 diameter south of Burr Oak, the storm of the night was a slow-moving tornadic supercell that peaked in intensity from far east-central Osborne into central Mitchell County between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT. This storm produced three confirmed after-dark tornadoes, two rated EF-1 with path lengths around one mile near the Osborne/Mitchell County line west of Tipton, and a brief EF-0 touchdown slightly east of Tipton. The two stronger tornadoes, one of which moved east and one west under the parent mesocyclone, damaged or destroyed several farm outbuildings, but no injuries occurred. Around midnight CDT, this storm began losing supercell structure and weakening as it drifted northeast through the Beloit area. In addition to tornadoes, this storm produced torrential rainfall of at least 3-4 in a short time across central and western portions of Mitchell County. Other storms produced a swath of heavy rain of generally 1.50-3.00 across much of southern Jewell County. However, the majority of the six-county area totaled no more than 0.50-1.00.  ||Breaking down the overall event timing, several strong to severe storms first blossomed over Rooks and Osborne counties between 700-830 p.m. CDT. Over the next few hours, activity gradually expanded to the north and east, as the aforementioned tornadic supercell took center stage around nightfall. Between 130-230 a.m. CDT on the 4th, storms vacated the entire six-county area to the north and east. Several hours later between 6-8 a.m. CDT, additional elevated storms flared up primarily east of Highway 281, but were non-severe. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front draped through the northern half of Kansas, seasonably strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet ramping up during the night, this was a well-anticipated severe weather event. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. While modest capping held storms at bay through the afternoon, the combination of subtle, low-amplitude disturbances aloft and increasing lift along the developing low level jet sparked a rapid evening flare-up. At the surface, the evening hours featured steady easterly breezes and dewpoints in the mid-upper 60s F. Around the time the tornadic supercell developed, the mesoscale environment featured mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots, and fairly strong 0-1 kilometer storm-relative helicity of at least 150 m2/s2.

In addition to tornadoes, this storm produced torrential rainfall of at least 3-4 in a short time across central and western portions of Mitchell County. Other storms produced a swath of heavy rain of generally 1.50-3.00 across much of southern Jewell County. However, the majority of the six-county area totaled no more than 0.50-1.00.  ||Breaking down the overall event timing, several strong to severe storms first blossomed over Rooks and Osborne counties between 700-830 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front draped through the northern half of Kansas, seasonably strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet ramping up during the night, this was a well-anticipated severe weather event. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. While modest capping held storms at bay through the afternoon, the combination of subtle, low-amplitude disturbances aloft and increasing lift along the developing low level jet sparked a rapid evening flare-up. EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado set down on the curve of the road about 3 miles west of Tipton, and moved southeast briefly before turning more east in direction, lifting about a mile farther. A farmstead near the point of touchdown had several outbuildings destroyed or heavily damaged, while tree limbs were damaged along the rest of the path. No one was living at the first farmstead hit by the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although numerous thunderstorms rumbled across this six-county North Central Kansas area from the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th, the vast majority of them were sub-severe, producing only gusty winds and brief, heavy downpours. Storm mode primarily consisted of multicell clusters and lines, and the only ground-truth severe-criteria report was estimated 60 MPH gusts in northwestern Smith County at 9 p.m. CDT. During the preceding hour, this same small-scale linear complex yielded several reports of near-severe gusts in the 50-55 MPH range across Phillips County. As for rainfall, the majority of the local area only reported modest amounts of 0.50-1.00. However, much of Jewell and Mitchell counties tallied closer to 1.50, with a small section of southeast Jewell and northeast Mitchell, including the Randall area, getting drenched with at least 2.50-3.00. Despite a lack of ground-truth reports, it can be reasonably assumed that there were some short-term flooding issues in this area lasting into the day of the 11th. ||As for some timing details, the first few storms of the day initiated over Phillips and Smith counties between 5:45-7:00 p.m. CDT before quickly departing northward into Nebraska. Following a short lull, the next storm cluster marched into Phillips/Rooks counties from the west between 7:45-8:45 p.m. CDT and went on to produce the 60 MPH winds in Smith County. Through the remainder of the night, numerous non-severe storms continued streaming across the area, with most places finally rain-free by 6 a.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, the most evident boundary near the local area during the afternoon was a trough axis extending southwestward to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising into the mid-upper 90s, storms developed in an environment featuring 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 30 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in a few tree limbs being downed and some minor shingle damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous strong to occasionally severe multicell storms blossomed across South Central Nebraska from the late evening of Wednesday the 3rd into the morning hours of Thursday the 4th, serving as round 1 of an active few days of severe storms and flooding rainfall. With storms ranging in character from semi-discrete to clusters and line segments, they primarily produced hail up to around quarter size, along with heavy rain. Although convection affected parts of several counties at some point during the night, the majority of ground-truth severe weather reports emanated from Adams and Clay counties, including quarter size hail on the east side of Hastings, hail up to golf ball size in Clay Center, and several hours later, a combination of quarter size hail and estimated 60 MPH winds six miles east-southeast of Clay Center. Rainfall-wise, the big story of the night was a concentrated swath of generally 1.50-3.00 that fell over southern Hall/northern Adams counties, southeastward through most of Clay, Fillmore and northern Thayer counties. Within this corridor, a few of the highest overnight totals from NeRAIN observers included 3.13 near Alexandria and 3.00 a few miles northwest of Hastings. As a result, minor flooding affected several creeks and streams and some roadways. In fact, the southbound lanes of Highway 281 in far-southern Hall County were closed for a few hours during the night due to flooding. Although this generally minor flooding subsided during the day of the 4th, unfortunately many of these same areas would soon be drenched with another 2-4 on the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th, resulting in 36-hour totals of 3-7 and a more serious, widespread flooding situation (please refer to the separate June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. severe weather episode for further details). ||Breaking down the overall event timing, all convection through the pre-dark hours focused to the south over northern Kansas. Then, between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT, storms began developing northward into the southern two rows of South Central Nebraska counties, largely in response to a strengthening, northward-lifting low level jet. Over the course of the next several hours, numerous strong to occasionally severe storms continued spreading north and east across the area, with half dollar size hail reported as far north as southern Greeley County. Within the aforementioned primary zone of heavy rain, the majority fell between 2:30-6:00 a.m. CDT. As one area of storms was in the process of exiting eastern counties of the local area around sunrise, a separate, quick-moving line of non-severe convection moved in from the southwest, sweeping across most of South Central Nebraska between 5-9 a.m. CDT. Although a few storms persisted here and there through late-morning, most places began a brief respite before the next round of evening/overnight storms arrived. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front residing near the Nebraska-Kansas border through the night, seasonably-strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet taking direct aim on the local area, this was a well-anticipated nocturnal convective flare-up. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. At the time of the first severe-criteria hail reports around 11:30 p.m. CDT, the environment featured most-unstable CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg and 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter to golf ball size hail fell during this time in Clay Center.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water over the road at intersection of Hoch rd and Lake rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chaser reported a large tornado on the ground moving north.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chaser reported a large tornado on the ground moving north from Sheridan into Decatur county.  Damage occurred at a farmstead with a large tree damaged, minor roof damage and an antenna blown over near Selden.  Another resident reported a barn was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.

Late afternoon thunderstorms over the southern Nebraska Panhandle produced damaging winds and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated at 65 mph blew a semi-tractor trailer off Highway 385 north of Dalton.  The driver was not injured.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall of 6 to 10 inches fell across the northern basin of the Little Blue River. This cause the river to swell to record levels around the Fairbury area. The flooding resulted in the mandatory evacuations of areas of the western and southern parts of town, to the west of the Union Pacific Railroad tracks. The flooding of some residents along the river did result in one fatality of an elderly residence in her basement. The river crested at 25.42 feet or 6.92 feet above flood stage.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 3 to 6 inches on the evening of May 6th into the early morning of the 7th led to the Lincoln Creek to rise to just above flood stage near Seward. this resulted in low-land flooding along the river. The creek crested at 15.05 feet, or .05 feet above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours on June 10th and produced hail, heavy rainfall and flash flooding in portions of Lincoln County. The thunderstorms developed  northeastward and produced areas of damaging winds in Custer, Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Wheeler County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated.

Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy rainfall of 5 to 10 inches fell along the Turkey Creek basin. This allowed for the creek to swell into moderate flood levels. Flooding along the Creek resulted in numerous rural road closures and significant low-land flooding. The combination of the Turkey Creek and Big Blue river led to nearly the entire town of De Witt to be flooded on the 7th of May resulting in a voluntary evacuation of the city. The creek at Wilber crested at 17.89 feet, or 5.39 feet above flood stage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Standing water was still occurring over roads but roads were passable the following morning.  Delayed report from social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding occurred in St Francis last night.  Time of flooding is estimated from Doppler radar and other reports.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms produced a small tornado that hit Eudora.  The tornado tracked around 6.5 miles doing sporadic tree damage along its path. Some portions of the line produced severe wind gusts and caused damage. Heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in Jackson and Shawnee counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of 86th and Carlton rd is closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of hwy 99 and 135th rd was closed due to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water running over the road at 25th and Frontier rd, 26th and Jayhawk rd, and 23rd and Hackberry rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms were confined to mostly the far southwest part of the area along a dryline in the vicinity.
Thunderstorms were confined to mostly the far southwest part of the area along a dryline in the vicinity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief tornado and most likely a landspout.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front advanced across the area during the afternoon and evening.  There were also residual outflow boundaries from convection the day before that provided a focusing area for thunderstorm development.

A cold front advanced across the area during the afternoon and evening.  There were also residual outflow boundaries from convection the day before that provided a focusing area for thunderstorm development.
Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chaser reported utility poles were snapped just north of Highway 36 on Road 314.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.

Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 2 to 5 inches fell across the Wahoo Creek basin from the evening of the 6th into the morning of the 7th. This resulted in widespread low-land flooding along the creek from near Ithica to Ashland. The creek crested during the morning on the 7th at 1.64 feet above flood stage at 20.43 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours on June 10th and produced hail, heavy rainfall and flash flooding in portions of Lincoln County. The thunderstorms developed  northeastward and produced areas of damaging winds in Custer, Blaine, Loup, Garfield, and Wheeler County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts of 60 mph located 8 miles west southwest of Almeria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced a landspout tornado late morning near North Platte, then damaging winds by early evening near North Platte.  In Hooker County, large hail was reported in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree limb was downed in North Platte from thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was running over several county roads last night and this morning due to heavy rainfall.  Time of flooding is estimated from Doppler radar.  Flooding continued early this morning but has since subsided.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of tropical moisture moved into portions of eastern KS causing widespread heavy rain. This rain fell on top of already saturated ground, which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding ongoing across all of Lyon county with 15 roads currently impassible. A creek in Americus has flooded several streets in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of tropical moisture moved into portions of eastern KS causing widespread heavy rain. This rain fell on top of already saturated ground, which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several county roads flooded though out Osage county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of tropical moisture moved into portions of eastern KS causing widespread heavy rain. This rain fell on top of already saturated ground, which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding ongoing in Coffey county with roads closed in Burlington. At 16th and Angus water was running over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of tropical moisture moved into portions of eastern KS causing widespread heavy rain. This rain fell on top of already saturated ground, which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 59 was closed at the railroad tracks in Kincaid.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed along a cool front in the central Nebraska Sandhills during the late afternoon hours of July 23rd.  This activity moved to the south impacting southwestern Nebraska during the early evening hours.  Large hail, and a brief tornado touch down was reported southwest of Thedford.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter sized hail and estimated wind gusts to 50 MPH were reported.
