In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.

During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 70 MPH resulted in the derailment of seven BNSF freight train cars in extreme western Adams County (the train had a total of 72 cars). Hail up to the size of nickels was also reported in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: When considering the time of day, this Tuesday featured a somewhat rare type of severe weather event in far southeastern portions of the local area (mainly Thayer County): severe hail-producing storms that didn't initiate until a few hours after sunrise, peaked in intensity mid-late morning and departed east of the area during the early afternoon. More specifically, mainly between 9:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m. CDT, a number of elevated storms continuously redeveloped over the same west-to-east corridor, resulting in several hail reports ranging in size from quarters to slightly larger than golf balls. The largest hail reports originated from the Hebron, Byron and Chester areas, including a broken windshield a few miles northeast of Chester. In addition, a spotter several miles northeast of Hubbell reported quarter size hail from separate storms 90 minutes apart. Outside of Thayer County, additional storms brushed through Fillmore County along with several other counties to the west along Highway 136, but for the most part they were weaker, yielding only a few accounts of dime to penny size hail in Upland and near Hardy. Although all severe-criteria reports occurred after 9 a.m. CDT, the very first storm of the morning actually flared up along the extreme southern edges of Nuckolls/Thayer counties between 8:00-8:30 a.m. CDT.  As for rainfall, the majority of Thayer County received no more than 0.50-1.00. However, east-central portions of the county were drenched with notably higher totals thanks to repeated storm training, including a measured 3.15 in Gilead, where some short-term flooding issued were noted in the vicinity. ||Although the time of day was somewhat unusual for this elevated hailer event, the synoptic and mesoscale setup was supportive. In the mid-upper levels, there were no notable disturbances passing through the zonal pattern, as South Central Nebraska resided within the transition zone between weak flow to the south within a Southern Plains ridge, and much stronger flow to the north over the Dakotas/Upper Midwest. At the surface, seasonably strong high pressure was centered over Nebraska, holding the primary west-east oriented surface front and resultant low-level instability axis well to the south in Kansas. However, it was a different story around the 700 millibar level, where a persistent axis of southwesterly lift/moisture advection teamed with steepening mid-level lapse rates to yield an environment supportive of hail production, featuring 1000-2000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and effective-shear around 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to 2 in diameter broke the windshield of a vehicle.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: When considering the time of day, this Tuesday featured a somewhat rare type of severe weather event in far southeastern portions of the local area (mainly Thayer County): severe hail-producing storms that didn't initiate until a few hours after sunrise, peaked in intensity mid-late morning and departed east of the area during the early afternoon. More specifically, mainly between 9:00 a.m.-1:30 p.m. CDT, a number of elevated storms continuously redeveloped over the same west-to-east corridor, resulting in several hail reports ranging in size from quarters to slightly larger than golf balls. The largest hail reports originated from the Hebron, Byron and Chester areas, including a broken windshield a few miles northeast of Chester. In addition, a spotter several miles northeast of Hubbell reported quarter size hail from separate storms 90 minutes apart. Outside of Thayer County, additional storms brushed through Fillmore County along with several other counties to the west along Highway 136, but for the most part they were weaker, yielding only a few accounts of dime to penny size hail in Upland and near Hardy. Although all severe-criteria reports occurred after 9 a.m. CDT, the very first storm of the morning actually flared up along the extreme southern edges of Nuckolls/Thayer counties between 8:00-8:30 a.m. CDT.  As for rainfall, the majority of Thayer County received no more than 0.50-1.00. However, east-central portions of the county were drenched with notably higher totals thanks to repeated storm training, including a measured 3.15 in Gilead, where some short-term flooding issued were noted in the vicinity. ||Although the time of day was somewhat unusual for this elevated hailer event, the synoptic and mesoscale setup was supportive. In the mid-upper levels, there were no notable disturbances passing through the zonal pattern, as South Central Nebraska resided within the transition zone between weak flow to the south within a Southern Plains ridge, and much stronger flow to the north over the Dakotas/Upper Midwest. At the surface, seasonably strong high pressure was centered over Nebraska, holding the primary west-east oriented surface front and resultant low-level instability axis well to the south in Kansas. However, it was a different story around the 700 millibar level, where a persistent axis of southwesterly lift/moisture advection teamed with steepening mid-level lapse rates to yield an environment supportive of hail production, featuring 1000-2000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and effective-shear around 40 knots.

A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
Thunderstorms produced a landspout tornado late morning near North Platte, then damaging winds by early evening near North Platte.  In Hooker County, large hail was reported in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mesonet observation near North Platte measured 60 mph thunderstorm wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced a landspout tornado late morning near North Platte, then damaging winds by early evening near North Platte.  In Hooker County, large hail was reported in the afternoon.

Thunderstorms developed in central Cherry County and moved southeast producing large hail, heavy rain, and gusty winds. Other thunderstorms developed in the southeast Nebraska Panhandle and southwest that also produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain. The heavy rainfall led to localized flash flooding in portions of Keith, Perkins, Lincoln, and Hayes counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported Highway 61 was half covered with water, with some locations being 6 to 8 inches deep.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Lincoln County Emergency Manager reported flood waters over highways 25 and 23 near Wallace.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 3 miles south of Madrid reported quarter size hail and widespread tree damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.

The supercell thunderstorm that tracked across parts of northwest Kansas continued into extreme southwest Nebraska. Law enforcement reported a tornado south of McCook which dissipated as it got closer to town.  Further west, repeat episodes of thunderstorms resulted in very heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Benkelman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement and a storm spotter reported an intermittent tornado south of McCook.  No damage was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The supercell thunderstorm that tracked across parts of northwest Kansas continued into extreme southwest Nebraska. Law enforcement reported a tornado south of McCook which dissipated as it got closer to town.  Further west, repeat episodes of thunderstorms resulted in very heavy rainfall and flash flooding in Benkelman.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The fairgrounds area iin Benkelman received flash flooding. Water was up to the running boards on pickup trucks and over many roads as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms produced torrential rains across parts of South-Central Kansas for much of the afternoon and evening. Major flooding occurred. The most serious was that of a flash flood that occurred in Wichita. In parts of South and Southeast Wichita as well as West Wichita vehicles were submerged. Most of the parking lots at the Towne West Mall were flooded to depths around 3 feet. Rainfalls from 3-6 inches were widespread. Many streets were barricaded. Among them was Maple Avenue from I-235 to West Streets. The situation was exacerbated by heavy thunderstorms that produced torrential rains early in the morning. In fact, a staggering 5.60 inches was measured in Harper that morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KAKE Channel 10 reported the flooding at Towne West Mall parking lot.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very early in the morning of the 24th, an isolated thunderstorm produced an estimated 52 KT/60 MPH gust 5 miles northeast of Lincoln. No damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms moved over Northwest Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  The majority of the severe weather occurred during the afternoon in Logan county with several tornado reports in the Winona and Monument area.  The largest hail size reported was 1.75 inches near Winona, the same storm that produced the tornado.  Later on a line of storms over Thomas county produced severe wind gusts measuring 63 MPH at the Colby airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was intermittently in contact with the ground for about 10 minutes. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon a slow moving severe thunderstorm moved over Benkelman producing hail ranging from golf ball up to softball size (4.25).  An estimated four inches of heavy rainfall occurred from the slow moving storm.  This caused flooding in Benkelman, with six inches of water over the road near the fairgrounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail started out as golf ball in size then grew to baseball and finally softball size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads remain closed due to flooding. Elk creek from Circleville to the Atchison county line is out of its banks. There are a couple of bridges that were damaged, one of which may fail near Whiting.

Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Coal creek remains out of its banks. Several county roads remain closed due to flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads remain closed due to flood waters. A couple of the roads may be washed out due to damage of culverts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water has been reported running over Granite rd. A barricade has been put up to stop traffic from driving through the flooded road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed along a cool front in the central Nebraska Sandhills during the late afternoon hours of July 23rd.  This activity moved to the south impacting southwestern Nebraska during the early evening hours.  Large hail, and a brief tornado touch down was reported southwest of Thedford.

Isolated severe thunderstorms developed along a cool front in the central Nebraska Sandhills during the late afternoon hours of July 23rd.  This activity moved to the south impacting southwestern Nebraska during the early evening hours.  Large hail, and a brief tornado touch down was reported southwest of Thedford.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1547 CST, an off duty NWS employee reported a tornado south southwest of Thedford. The tornado briefly touched down in open range land with no damage reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed along a cool front in the central Nebraska Sandhills during the late afternoon hours of July 23rd.  This activity moved to the south impacting southwestern Nebraska during the early evening hours.  Large hail, and a brief tornado touch down was reported southwest of Thedford.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 MPH.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total rainfall of 3.15, all of which fell between 9 a.m.-2 p.m. CDT. This was a rather localized area of heavy rain over eastern Thayer County, and some short-term flooding was reported in the area by county officials.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over the western Nebraska Panhandle produced very heavy rain, strong winds, a weak tornado and numerous reports of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two inches of rain in less than an hour produced flash flooding.  Portions of US Highway 385 were closed to high water five to ten miles south of Chadron.  Flooding was reported at the Chadron State Park and Red Cloud Campground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early afternoon thunderstorms over Morrill County produced large hail, damaging winds and very heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated wind gusts of 60 mph snapped the top of a large poplar tree.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early afternoon thunderstorms over Morrill County produced large hail, damaging winds and very heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Golf ball size hail was observed three miles east-northeast of Bridgeport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early afternoon thunderstorms over Morrill County produced large hail, damaging winds and very heavy rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated wind gusts of 60 mph were observed 12 miles southwest of Miles Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple of thunderstorms that were just under severe limits were reported within 40 miles of Dodge City.

Approximately 14 tornadoes were documented and confirmed via reports and radar data all occurring during the late afternoon and evening of May 6th.  The tornadoes impacted Republic, Cloud, Washington and Clay Counties.  In fact, 7 tornadoes alone occurred in Republic County.  This was the largest one day outbreak of tornadoes in the past 10 years for NWS Topeka.  The strongest tornado was an EF3 that destroyed a home south of Munden in Republic county.  The longest was over 25 miles in length also across Republic county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reported an elephant trunk shaped tornado around 2  miles northwest of Washington. EM was not able to find any damage but area is open pasture so possible that touched down in pasture and did no damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in central Cherry County and moved southeast producing large hail, heavy rain, and gusty winds. Other thunderstorms developed in the southeast Nebraska Panhandle and southwest that also produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain. The heavy rainfall led to localized flash flooding in portions of Keith, Perkins, Lincoln, and Hayes counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: General public located 11 miles south southeast of Lisco reported thunderstorm wind gusts to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were two locations near Robinson where gravel and debris had been washed onto the roads from water coming off the fields.

During the afternoon a slow moving severe thunderstorm moved over Benkelman producing hail ranging from golf ball up to softball size (4.25).  An estimated four inches of heavy rainfall occurred from the slow moving storm.  This caused flooding in Benkelman, with six inches of water over the road near the fairgrounds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: With an estimated four inches of rainfall occurring, six inches or more of water was reported to be over the road near the fairgrounds on the south side of Benkelman.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Creeks and stream are rising again and county roads are covered by water coming out of the fields. Oketo measured 1.5 inches of rain this morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shallow supercell t-storm developed in Marion County Kansas on the evening of June 14th.  This storm moved into Morris County and produced a brief weak tornado that touched down in open country.  Photos of the tornado were taken but no damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EM relayed report of a brief tornado on the ground at 742pm CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated severe thunderstorms developed along a cool front in the central Nebraska Sandhills during the late afternoon hours of July 23rd.  This activity moved to the south impacting southwestern Nebraska during the early evening hours.  Large hail, and a brief tornado touch down was reported southwest of Thedford.

Isolated severe thunderstorms developed along a cool front in the central Nebraska Sandhills during the late afternoon hours of July 23rd.  This activity moved to the south impacting southwestern Nebraska during the early evening hours.  Large hail, and a brief tornado touch down was reported southwest of Thedford.

Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stationary front located over southwestern Nebraska. These storms then migrated to the east northeast into portions of central Nebraska. Large hail and damaging winds were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A window was broken out by golf ball sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stationary front located over southwestern Nebraska. These storms then migrated to the east northeast into portions of central Nebraska. Large hail and damaging winds were reported.

Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stationary front located over southwestern Nebraska. These storms then migrated to the east northeast into portions of central Nebraska. Large hail and damaging winds were reported.

A line of severe thunderstorms produced a small tornado that hit Eudora.  The tornado tracked around 6.5 miles doing sporadic tree damage along its path. Some portions of the line produced severe wind gusts and caused damage. Heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in Jackson and Shawnee counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree blew over in 70 to 80 mph wind gusts.

Shortly after sunset on this Thursday evening, between 9:00-9:30 p.m. CDT, a southwest-to-northeast corridor of strong to marginally severe multicell storms ignited over the heart of this six-county North Central Kansas area. These slightly elevated storms primarily produced small hail and brief heavy rain before mostly-departing the local area to the south and east by 11 p.m. CDT. However, one storm pulsed up to severe thresholds over southern Mitchell County, yielding a quarter size hail report. Shortly after this first round of storms vacated the local area, yet another southwest-to-northeast complex of convection fired up over North Central Kansas between 11:00-11:30 p.m. CDT. Unlike its predecessor though, this round remained sub-severe as it too gradually departed to the south and east by around 2 a.m. CDT, ending all local thunderstorm activity for the night. Rainfall-wise, amounts varied rather widely, ranging from little to nothing (especially within northern portions of Phillips/Smith/Jewell counties) to pockets up to around 1 (especially within southern portions of Osborne/Jewell/Mitchell counties). Wettest of all was a portion of south central Mitchell County, which likely received at least 1.50-2.00. ||In terms of forcing mechanisms, the most pertinent feature was a modest evening increase in convergence along a fairly sharp, slightly-elevated frontal zone evident at 850 millibars. This boundary was stretched in west-to-east fashion directly over the local area, roughly 60-80 miles north of a corresponding surface front draped through central Kansas. As the night went on, this elevated frontal zone pressed southward, taking thunderstorm chances out of the local area with it. On the larger scale synoptic scene, lift was provided by a broad shortwave trough dropping southeastward into the region from the Northern Plains. Around the time of the quarter size hail report in Mitchell County, the mesoscale environment featured 1000-2000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and around 40 knots of effective shear.

Numerous strong to occasionally severe multicell storms blossomed across South Central Nebraska from the late evening of Wednesday the 3rd into the morning hours of Thursday the 4th, serving as round 1 of an active few days of severe storms and flooding rainfall. With storms ranging in character from semi-discrete to clusters and line segments, they primarily produced hail up to around quarter size, along with heavy rain. Although convection affected parts of several counties at some point during the night, the majority of ground-truth severe weather reports emanated from Adams and Clay counties, including quarter size hail on the east side of Hastings, hail up to golf ball size in Clay Center, and several hours later, a combination of quarter size hail and estimated 60 MPH winds six miles east-southeast of Clay Center. Rainfall-wise, the big story of the night was a concentrated swath of generally 1.50-3.00 that fell over southern Hall/northern Adams counties, southeastward through most of Clay, Fillmore and northern Thayer counties. Within this corridor, a few of the highest overnight totals from NeRAIN observers included 3.13 near Alexandria and 3.00 a few miles northwest of Hastings. As a result, minor flooding affected several creeks and streams and some roadways. In fact, the southbound lanes of Highway 281 in far-southern Hall County were closed for a few hours during the night due to flooding. Although this generally minor flooding subsided during the day of the 4th, unfortunately many of these same areas would soon be drenched with another 2-4 on the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th, resulting in 36-hour totals of 3-7 and a more serious, widespread flooding situation (please refer to the separate June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. severe weather episode for further details). ||Breaking down the overall event timing, all convection through the pre-dark hours focused to the south over northern Kansas. Then, between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT, storms began developing northward into the southern two rows of South Central Nebraska counties, largely in response to a strengthening, northward-lifting low level jet. Over the course of the next several hours, numerous strong to occasionally severe storms continued spreading north and east across the area, with half dollar size hail reported as far north as southern Greeley County. Within the aforementioned primary zone of heavy rain, the majority fell between 2:30-6:00 a.m. CDT. As one area of storms was in the process of exiting eastern counties of the local area around sunrise, a separate, quick-moving line of non-severe convection moved in from the southwest, sweeping across most of South Central Nebraska between 5-9 a.m. CDT. Although a few storms persisted here and there through late-morning, most places began a brief respite before the next round of evening/overnight storms arrived. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front residing near the Nebraska-Kansas border through the night, seasonably-strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet taking direct aim on the local area, this was a well-anticipated nocturnal convective flare-up. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. At the time of the first severe-criteria hail reports around 11:30 p.m. CDT, the environment featured most-unstable CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg and 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to quarter size hail fell during this time.

Late afternoon and early evening thunderstorms produced strong winds and large hail across portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported seven miles southeast of Melbeta.  Wrights Gap Road was covered with hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low moved slowly towards the area aiding ascent for a large area of showers and thunderstorms.  Initiation was early in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most of the hail was pea sized and it covered the ground.

Thunderstorms developed in central Cherry County and moved southeast producing large hail, heavy rain, and gusty winds. Other thunderstorms developed in the southeast Nebraska Panhandle and southwest that also produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain. The heavy rainfall led to localized flash flooding in portions of Keith, Perkins, Lincoln, and Hayes counties.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.

A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.

One lone storm moved across portions of Central, KS and produced a limited amount of severe weather.

Numerous strong to occasionally severe multicell storms blossomed across South Central Nebraska from the late evening of Wednesday the 3rd into the morning hours of Thursday the 4th, serving as round 1 of an active few days of severe storms and flooding rainfall. With storms ranging in character from semi-discrete to clusters and line segments, they primarily produced hail up to around quarter size, along with heavy rain. Although convection affected parts of several counties at some point during the night, the majority of ground-truth severe weather reports emanated from Adams and Clay counties, including quarter size hail on the east side of Hastings, hail up to golf ball size in Clay Center, and several hours later, a combination of quarter size hail and estimated 60 MPH winds six miles east-southeast of Clay Center. Rainfall-wise, the big story of the night was a concentrated swath of generally 1.50-3.00 that fell over southern Hall/northern Adams counties, southeastward through most of Clay, Fillmore and northern Thayer counties. Within this corridor, a few of the highest overnight totals from NeRAIN observers included 3.13 near Alexandria and 3.00 a few miles northwest of Hastings. As a result, minor flooding affected several creeks and streams and some roadways. In fact, the southbound lanes of Highway 281 in far-southern Hall County were closed for a few hours during the night due to flooding. Although this generally minor flooding subsided during the day of the 4th, unfortunately many of these same areas would soon be drenched with another 2-4 on the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th, resulting in 36-hour totals of 3-7 and a more serious, widespread flooding situation (please refer to the separate June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. severe weather episode for further details). ||Breaking down the overall event timing, all convection through the pre-dark hours focused to the south over northern Kansas. Then, between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT, storms began developing northward into the southern two rows of South Central Nebraska counties, largely in response to a strengthening, northward-lifting low level jet. Over the course of the next several hours, numerous strong to occasionally severe storms continued spreading north and east across the area, with half dollar size hail reported as far north as southern Greeley County. Within the aforementioned primary zone of heavy rain, the majority fell between 2:30-6:00 a.m. CDT. As one area of storms was in the process of exiting eastern counties of the local area around sunrise, a separate, quick-moving line of non-severe convection moved in from the southwest, sweeping across most of South Central Nebraska between 5-9 a.m. CDT. Although a few storms persisted here and there through late-morning, most places began a brief respite before the next round of evening/overnight storms arrived. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front residing near the Nebraska-Kansas border through the night, seasonably-strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet taking direct aim on the local area, this was a well-anticipated nocturnal convective flare-up. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. At the time of the first severe-criteria hail reports around 11:30 p.m. CDT, the environment featured most-unstable CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg and 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.

Within this corridor, a few of the highest overnight totals from NeRAIN observers included 3.13 near Alexandria and 3.00 a few miles northwest of Hastings. As a result, minor flooding affected several creeks and streams and some roadways. In fact, the southbound lanes of Highway 281 in far-southern Hall County were closed for a few hours during the night due to flooding. Although this generally minor flooding subsided during the day of the 4th, unfortunately many of these same areas would soon be drenched with another 2-4 on the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th, resulting in 36-hour totals of 3-7 and a more serious, widespread flooding situation (please refer to the separate June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. severe weather episode for further details). ||Breaking down the overall event timing, all convection through the pre-dark hours focused to the south over northern Kansas. Then, between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT, storms began developing northward into the southern two rows of South Central Nebraska counties, largely in response to a strengthening, northward-lifting low level jet. Over the course of the next several hours, numerous strong to occasionally severe storms continued spreading north and east across the area, with half dollar size hail reported as far north as southern Greeley County. Within the aforementioned primary zone of heavy rain, the majority fell between 2:30-6:00 a.m. CDT. As one area of storms was in the process of exiting eastern counties of the local area around sunrise, a separate, quick-moving line of non-severe convection moved in from the southwest, sweeping across most of South Central Nebraska between 5-9 a.m. CDT. Although a few storms persisted here and there through late-morning, most places began a brief respite before the next round of evening/overnight storms arrived. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front residing near the Nebraska-Kansas border through the night, seasonably-strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet taking direct aim on the local area, this was a well-anticipated nocturnal convective flare-up. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. At the time of the first severe-criteria hail reports around 11:30 p.m. CDT, the environment featured most-unstable CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg and 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to quarter size hail lasted around 10 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Compared to the more concentrated zones of severe weather and/or flooding rains that plagued nearby areas to the north, west and east, this six-county portion of North Central Kansas fared quite well on the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning hours of Friday the 5th. In fact, the only local severe-criteria report consisted of quarter size hail west of Phillipsburg shortly after 9:30 p.m. CDT, produced by a briefly-severe, semi-discrete storm that drifted northeastward across the heart of the county. Otherwise, the vast majority of storms on this night produced nothing more than sub-severe wind gusts and pockets of moderate to briefly-heavy rainfall. Based on a combination of gauge reports and radar estimation, the majority of the six-county area averaged well-under 1 of rain, except for higher totals potentially in excess of 1.50 that fell primarily within northeastern Jewell, northern Phillips and extreme northwestern Rooks counties. Even so, there were no known reports of impactful flooding issues. ||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity, the first few semi-discrete storms developed into Phillips and northern Rooks counties between 8:30-10:00 p.m. CDT, including the one that produced quarter size hail. Through the remainder of the night and lasting into morning hours on the 5th, numerous, primarily weak storms affected much of the local area. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: this was a fairly similar setup to the one that produced the more significant severe weather event within North Central Kansas the night before, as a quasi-stationary, composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. However, this time around no organized supercell storms were able to develop, and the most vigorous late-night convection focused slightly north and east of the local area within the primary exit region of a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet. On the large scale, the parent mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast as a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with a rather unstable airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the Phillips County hail report, the mesoscale environment featured 2000-3000 J/kg mixed layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear.

For the fourth consecutive night, this time from the late evening of Friday the 5th into the early morning of Saturday the 6th, most of South Central Nebraska saw a fairly widespread coverage of thunderstorms. However, compared to the preceding two nights, rainfall across the vast majority of the area was held down in the 0.50-1.50 range, as opposed to concentrated, multiple-county swaths of 3+ inch totals. In addition, severe weather was held to a minimum with only a few marginally severe wind reports. Unfortunately, for counties such as Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, northern Adams, southern Hall and southern Hamilton that had already received 3-7 of rainfall the past few days, these lesser additional totals were not welcomed. However, because fairly widespread flooding had already been set in motion from these preceding rains, especially within the West Fork Big Blue River basin, most of the damage had already been done anyway. Therefore, additional impacts from rains on this night were relatively minimal (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). Outside of the primary area already experiencing flooding, this night featured one localized pocket of heavy rain centered over the southwestern quadrant of Webster County, where radar estimation suggested that as much as 2-3 fell in a short time primarily between 11 p.m.-1 a.m. CDT. ||In the severe weather department, the only ground-truth reports in the local 24-county area consisted of a pair of estimated 60 MPH wind gusts in northwestern Furnas County between midnight-1 a.m. CDT. This was a result of one storm, embedded within a larger shield of rain, briefly intensifying as it swept into the local area from southwest Nebraska. Otherwise, the majority of convective activity during the night developed out ahead of the incoming southwest Nebraska complex, as numerous multicell storms blossomed across the heart of South Central Nebraska during the 10 p.m.-midnight CDT time frame, before heading east and expanding into a larger complex through the rest of the night. Finally, between 7-9 a.m. on the 6th, the last storms of the morning departed far northeast local counties such as Nance/Polk. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: the overall large-scale scenario remained fairly similar to the preceding few nights of active weather. This meant that a series of low-amplitude disturbances continued passing through the Central Plains in west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from the primary upper trough hanging back well to the west over the California-Nevada border area. At the surface, a subtle warm front lifted north through Nebraska during the night. Although not quite as pronounced as the previous few nights, the nocturnal increase in convection over South Central Nebraska was again aided by enhanced convergence/lift within the axis of a 20-30 knot southerly low level jet. Around the time of the Furnas County severe wind reports, the mesoscale environment featured approximately 1000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and only around 30 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were at least 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few strong to marginally-severe storms rumbled through mainly western sections of South Central Nebraska on Saturday afternoon the 6th into early Sunday morning the 7th, serving as a fairly low-key final act to a busy several days of severe storms and flooding rains within the local area. There were only a few ground-truth reports of hail, both of them during the late afternoon: one up to penny size in central Buffalo County and the other up to quarter size in southwestern Valley County. In the wake of this afternoon activity, for the first time in several nights the vast majority of South Central Nebraska received little to no measurable rain. That being said, the biggest local weather story of all on the 6th was severe flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River in the McCool Junction area of York County, primarily resulting from heavy rain of at least 3-7 that fell on the 4th-5th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Turning to some timing details of local convection on the afternoon of the 6th into the early morning of the 7th, the first cluster of strong multicell storms developed within Furnas, Harlan and Phelps counties between 3:00-4:30 p.m. CDT. During the next few hours, additional small clusters of storms pushed rapidly northeast through mainly portions of Buffalo, Sherman and Valley counties, yielding the aforementioned hail reports. Once this activity departed the local area by early evening, all of South Central Nebraska remained storm-free until well past nightfall. Then, between 11 p.m.-2 a.m. CDT, a few additional small areas of strong storms flared up over primarily Furnas, Harlan, Gosper and Phelps counties, but likely produced no more than small hail and gusty winds. As for the synoptic and mesoscale situation during the afternoon hours, the clusters of multicell convection developed in the vicinity of a north-to-south oriented pre-frontal trough at the surface. Meanwhile, in the mid-upper levels, the setup remained much the same as the past several days, as a series of low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from the primary upper trough centered well to the west over the southern Nevada area. Around the time of the quarter size hail in Valley County, mesoscale parameters included roughly 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.

A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief tornado under the mesocyclone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy, and in some cases, record rainfall fell across southeast Nebraska on the evening of the 6th and into the early morning hours of the 7th. This led to flooding on several rivers and creeks across southeast Nebraska on the days to follow. In some cases the flooding reached record levels and resulted in significant damage, and tragically 1 fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record rainfall of 5 to 10 inches fell across Lancaster County, and the Salt Creek basin on the evening of the 6th into the early morning of the 7th. This led to significant flooding along the creek, from near Roca north through the Lincoln metro area. The flooding resulted in numerous road closures, water rescues and some mandatory evacuations. The flooding was largely contained within the levy system within the city of Lincoln, but many parks and low-lined areas were flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.

Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Walnut creek is out of its banks. 280th rd southwest of Padonia has been closed because of the flood waters.

Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. EVENT_NARRATIVE: An 8 inch diameter tree limb was blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be at least 80 MPH.  Two vehicles had windows blown out and every wind on the west side of the house had windows blown out by the high wind.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were blown down at Highway 183 and L Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few strong to severe storms moved across northeastern Kansas and northwestern Missouri during the evening of May 4th. The storms produced localized flash flooding as well as some 1 hail reports.
A few strong to severe storms moved across northeastern Kansas and northwestern Missouri during the evening of May 4th. The storms produced localized flash flooding as well as some 1 hail reports.

A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.

A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In addition to ping pong ball sized hail, numerous trees were blown over at this location.

Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In addition to quarter sized hail, thunderstorm wind gusts were estimated at 60 MPH.

As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.

In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and into the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved out of Colorado into Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball size in Sharon Springs.  Winds from the thunderstorms blew down large elm trees near Weskan, uprooting two of them due to estimated speeds of 100 MPH.  The high winds also caused blowing dust, dropping visibilities to less than a quarter mile near Monument.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large elm trees were blown down, including one of the trees being uprooted.  A larger tree by the creek, with a diameter of 2.5 to 3 feet, was also uprooted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and into the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved out of Colorado into Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball size in Sharon Springs.  Winds from the thunderstorms blew down large elm trees near Weskan, uprooting two of them due to estimated speeds of 100 MPH.  The high winds also caused blowing dust, dropping visibilities to less than a quarter mile near Monument.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Zero visibility and heavy rainfall accompanied the winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and into the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved out of Colorado into Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball size in Sharon Springs.  Winds from the thunderstorms blew down large elm trees near Weskan, uprooting two of them due to estimated speeds of 100 MPH.  The high winds also caused blowing dust, dropping visibilities to less than a quarter mile near Monument.

A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado appeared much stronger and wider than it actually was due to very low cloud bases.  Irrigation pivots were damaged.  The tornado moved into Meade county at 20:49 LST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado moved in from Seward County.  It appeared to be much stronger and wider, visually.  But the cloud bases were extremely low. The tornado turned north and then northwest as is dissipated, based on the survey.  Many persons did not see the tornado due to nearby stratus and fog.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low moved slowly towards the area aiding ascent for a large area of showers and thunderstorms.  Initiation was early in the afternoon.
A large upper level low moved slowly towards the area aiding ascent for a large area of showers and thunderstorms.  Initiation was early in the afternoon.
A large upper level low moved slowly towards the area aiding ascent for a large area of showers and thunderstorms.  Initiation was early in the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail covered the ground and stripped leaves from trees.  Most of the hail stones were pea to nickel sized.  Also, 1.50 inches of rain fell at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level low moved slowly towards the area aiding ascent for a large area of showers and thunderstorms.  Initiation was early in the afternoon.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 2.0 inches was observed.  There was also pea sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few 2 to 3 inch diameter tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Prolonged rainfall from the previous day's storm activity both along the Republican river channel and the runoff into the river caused the Republican river to go out of its banks at Stratton, NE by a quarter to half a mile on both sides of the river.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Republican River near Stratton was out of its banks by a quarter to half a mile on both sides of the river.  The crest of the river peaked at a height of 10.89 ft. at 7 A.M. CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon strong to severe storms moved across parts of Northwest Kansas. The largest hail size reported was 2.5 inches reported near Selkirk.  The majority of the large hail reports were confined to Greeley county. A couple tornadoes developed northwest of Lydia over the southern half of Wichita county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported roadways being covered with water at least six inches deep in some areas.  Some county roads will be impassable due to the prolonged heavy rainfall.  Storm report was sent through Spotter Network.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The wind occurred just ahead of the thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms occurred in Sheridan County and across portions of the western Sandhills during the evening on June 2nd. Large hail and damaging winds were reported.
Scattered thunderstorms occurred in Sheridan County and across portions of the western Sandhills during the evening on June 2nd. Large hail and damaging winds were reported.
Scattered thunderstorms occurred in Sheridan County and across portions of the western Sandhills during the evening on June 2nd. Large hail and damaging winds were reported.

During the evening law enforcement estimated wind gusts of 90 MPH from a severe thunderstorm near Tribune.  No damage was reported from these winds.  This same thunderstorm brought rapid, heavy rainfall to western parts of the county.  Law enforcement officers reported water over Highway 96 from Horace to Tribune.  Rainfall totals a mile or two west of Tribune ranged from 1.10 inches to 1.86 inches, with estimated rainfall amounts close to three inches between Horace and the county line.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 90 MPH wind gust was reported with the severe thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.

A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Windshield broken on a spotter vehicle.

At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.
