EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Through all but the final few days of June, an unusually long-lasting, roughly six-week period of generally minor flooding continued along the Platte River in South Central Nebraska, impacting local areas from Gothenburg downstream to near Grand Island. This flooding event got underway during the May 15th-20th time frame, initially spurred by a combination of heavy rainfall over upstream portions of northeast Colorado and the southern Nebraska Panhandle, coincident with above normal Rocky Mountains snow melt. During June, flooding persisted, and at times worsened, thanks to multiple rounds of heavy rain falling directly over the local Platte basin, especially downstream from Kearney. Although peak water levels and impacts during this May-June event closely resembled those which occurred during the Platte River flooding of late-September to early-October 2013, this event was considerably more prolonged. The vast majority of local flooding impacts were noted within Dawson, Buffalo and Hall counties, mainly affecting pastures and lowlands immediately adjacent to the river, with very little impact to infrastructure. That being said, a few locations did experience legitimate disruptions. One of these was the Blue Heron Campground near Gothenburg, and another was the area around the south side of the Interstate 80/Highway 281 interchange (exit 312) near Grand Island, where water occasionally encroached into the parking lots of businesses. Flooding concerns were noticeably lower downstream from the Grand Island area, largely due to the widening of the main river channel. ||Taking a closer look at local flooding trends during June, of three automated Platte river gauges near Cozad, Kearney and Grand Island, all of them spent the majority of the month in minor flood stage. Grand Island even briefly exceeded moderate flood stage of 7.0 feet on two occasions, first on the 5th and again on the 19th. The gauge sites near Cozad and Grand Island briefly dropped slightly below flood stage for a few days around mid-month, before going into flood again. In general, there were June crests in water levels, one early in the month between mainly the 2nd-8th, and again later in the month from primarily the 17th-23rd. The early-month peak was clearly tied to multiple rounds of heavy rain that fell between the 3rd-6th. During this four-day stretch, a concentrated area of the Platte basin between Kearney, Hastings and Grand Island was drenched with 3-7. During a heavy rain event at Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the river actually flowed over South Locust St. near Interstate 80 exit 314 for a short time. Fortunately, a noticeably drier weather pattern settled in for the latter half of the month, allowing excess water to gradually work its way out of the local area. From roughly the 23rd onward through the end of June, a steady decline in water levels occurred at all three aforementioned gauge sites, with the Kearney gauge being the last to drop below its flood stage of 6.0 ft. on the 29th.

For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several intersections were flooded in Grand Island due to heavy rain. This included several locations along Broadwell Avenue and 17th Street. Also, water from the Platte River south channel near Schultz Road covered South Locust St. for a time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the third consecutive night, this time from the evening of Thursday the 4th into the early morning of Friday the 5th, several rounds of thunderstorms rumbled across much of the 24-county South Central Nebraska area. And for the second straight night, the majority of storms concentrated within the southeastern half of the area. Although the first few hours of evening convection yielded several hail reports up to mainly quarter size within Hall, Hamilton, Merrick and York counties, by far the biggest story of the night, and for some places for the next several days thereafter, was heavy rainfall and resultant flooding. During the 24-hour period ending around sunrise on the 5th, widespread rainfall of 2-4 drenched several counties, primarily including: Adams, Clay, Fillmore, York, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall and southern Hamilton. Combined with as much as 1.50-3.00 that fell across some of these same areas during the preceding night, the net result was 36-hour rain totals of generally 3-7, with the overall-highest concentration of 5-7 impacting a fairly narrow, roughly 10-mile wide corridor extending through southeast Hall, northeast Adams, southern Hamilton, northern Clay and western Fillmore counties. As just a few specific examples of 36-hour measured totals ending around sunrise on the 5th: 6.44 at Harvard and 5.28 four miles west of Geneva (NeRAIN observers). For the calendar days of June 3rd-5th, Hastings airport totaled 5.39, of which 4.74 fell on the 4th. This total set a new Hastings daily record for June rainfall, and was the third-highest daily total for any day of the year. Needless to say, widespread flooding of creeks, streams and primarily rural roadways was well-underway in the aforementioned counties by daybreak on the 5th. Adams county Emergency Management issued a press release alerting citizens that some roads are impassable and dangerous due to standing water and possible unknown damage in the northeast part of the county. Earlier on, during the initial stages of heavy rain on the evening of the 4th, significant street flooding impacted many communities including Grand Island, where several city streets were closed for a few hours. Also near Grand Island on the evening of the 4th, the Platte River (which had already been slightly above flood stage for a few weeks) briefly rose far enough out of its banks to overflow Locust Street near the Interstate 80 exit 314 interchange. Getting back to the daytime hours on the 5th, although flooding of roads and small streams began to very slowly subside, issues began ramping up on larger creeks and rivers. Most notably, this included the West Fork Big Blue River, which was centered almost directly under the narrow axis of heaviest rain and experienced historic flooding over the next several days (please refer to the separate paragraph below for more details regarding West Fork Big Blue River flooding).||Taking a closer look at the timing and evolution of local thunderstorm activity from the afternoon of the 4th into the early morning of the 5th...there were several different rounds. Following a brief lull in the wake of widespread activity during the early morning of the 4th, the next round of mainly non-severe storms affected counties primarily along/north of Interstate 80 through most of the afternoon hours. These storms yielded only one severe weather report: quarter size hail near Pleasanton. Following another brief lull during the late afternoon and early evening, a narrow swath of hail and torrential rain-producing severe storms blew up between 7-9 p.m. CDT along an axis from near Grand Island and Central City, eastward to near Stromsburg and York. Between 9-11 p.m. CDT, this vigorous line of convection gradually weakened as it sank southward toward the Kansas border, but continued dumping heavy rain. Beyond 11 p.m., the next several hours featured widespread, persistent development of non-severe-but-heavy-rain producing convection over most counties along and south of Interstate 80, largely driven by convergence/lift along the nose of a nocturnal, 30-40 knot low level jet. Finally, between 3-6 a.m. CDT on the 5th, storms steadily diminished in intensity and ended from north-to-south, leaving only lingering light rain over the Nebraska-Kansas border area by sunrise. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: this was a fairly similar situation to the night before, as a quasi-stationary composite surface front/outflow boundary remained in place near the Nebraska-Kansas border. Although the primary large scale mid-upper trough remained well to the west along the California coast, a series of downstream low-amplitude disturbances passed through the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow, interacting with an unstable and very moist airmass to trigger vigorous convection. Around the time of the initial evening hail-producing storms, the mesoscale environment featured around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear. ||June 5th-12th Summary of Historic Flooding Along the West Fork Big Blue River from near the Adams/Clay County line downstream through southeastern York County...deemed to be the worst flooding in 50-80 years: As detailed in the first paragraph above, 36-hour rainfall totals averaged 5-7 along much of the local stretch of the West Fork Big Blue River between the evening of June 3rd and the morning of June 5th. As a result, significant flooding commenced along the river and its smaller tributaries on the 5th, with the primary flood crest initially working its way across the northern Clay and southern Hamilton County area. By the daylight hours on Saturday the 6th, the seriousness of the flooding situation became more apparent for downstream communities such as McCool Junction. Residents in southern Hamilton County were already calling it the worst flooding they had witnessed in 50-80 years, as the crest reached the Lushton area of York County by late morning. Around this time, officials in McCool Junction began evacuations of several homes on the east side of town along the rising river, along with sandbagging operations. Around 12:30 p.m. CDT, water entered a church camp just south of town, cutting off access to it. The West Fork Big Blue crested in the immediate McCool Junction area that evening, but only a few homes suffered significant flooding. It was reported that at least five homes were saved due to advance notice of the approaching crest and resultant sandbagging. By daylight on Sunday morning June 7th, water levels had receded 1-2 feet at McCool Junction, as the crest worked downstream to near the York/Seward County line. Over the next few days, a welcomed-stretch of warm and dry weather allowed the river to slowly recede back within its banks over southern York County, and the initial multi-day Flood Warning was allowed to expire on Wednesday, June 10th. However, Mother Nature soon threw one last curveball at the McCool Junction area, as yet another round of heavy rain on the order of 1.50-3.00 fell into much of the West Fork Big Blue basin on the evening of the 10th into the morning of Thursday the 11th. As a result, a secondary, less-severe round of flooding was reported at McCool Junction by 10 a.m. CDT on the 11th, with the river reported to be one foot out of its banks. This second round of primarily minor flooding persisted into the daytime hours on Friday, June 12th, but largely abated by sunset that evening, finally ending over one week of flooding issues along the West Fork Big Blue River in eastern portions of South Central Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The daily rainfall total for June 4th at the National Weather Service office was 5.10 inches (some of this fell in the morning but most of it fell in the evening). Total Hastings NWS office rainfall from June 3rd-5th was 6.05. Two-day rainfall totals of 3-7 were common within much of Adams, Clay, Fillmore, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall, southern Hamilton and southern York counties, resulting in significant flooding across parts of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and into the evening a line of strong to severe thunderstorms moved out of Colorado into Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was golf ball size in Sharon Springs.  Winds from the thunderstorms blew down large elm trees near Weskan, uprooting two of them due to estimated speeds of 100 MPH.  The high winds also caused blowing dust, dropping visibilities to less than a quarter mile near Monument.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water rushing over County Road 14 southwest of Sharon Springs near the intersection of Muddy Road.  Pictures from social media of water ponding in fields and farms, with various roads covered with water.  Standing water was half way up cattle panels at the stockyard on the south side of Sharon Springs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the third day in a row with severe weather.  Even though the atmosphere was not terribly unstable, the high shear environment along a stationary front provided the ingredients for severe weather.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Entire trees knocked down by the winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.

During the evening law enforcement estimated wind gusts of 90 MPH from a severe thunderstorm near Tribune.  No damage was reported from these winds. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front, coupled with an upper level trough of low pressure, produced widespread severe thunderstorms across the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle and north central Nebraska on during the late afternoon and evening of July 5th.  Large hail to baseball size and damaging winds to 79 knots were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between midnight-5 a.m. CDT on Wednesday the 24th, scattered thunderstorms roamed through the northern half of South Central Nebraska, affecting counties along and especially north of Interstate 80. While none of these storms breached severe thresholds, a few likely produced small hail, with the only ground-truth report consisting of nickel size stones in Cozad during one of the first storms of the night. As for timing, scattered elevated storms developed almost simultaneously in two separate areas between midnight-1 a.m. CDT, one over Dawson County and the other farther northeast over Valley/Greeley/Nance counties. Over the next few hours, this initial convection tracked east while new storms flared up in its wake. By 5 a.m. CDT, all local activity had departed eastward into eastern Nebraska. ||This was a fairly classic round of nocturnal convection, as the nose of a rather strong 40-45 knot low level jet took aim on the local area, surging over the top of a well-defined surface stationary front draped along the Nebraska-Kansas border, which separated easterly low level flow to its north from southerly breezes to its south. In the mid-upper levels, modest zonal flow was in place, as the Central Plains was sandwiched between a west-to-east oriented ridge centered over the OK area, and much stronger westerly flow over the Dakotas/Upper Midwest. Around the time of the Cozad hail report, the mesoscale environment featured up to around 2000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and 30-35 knots of deep-layer wind shear. Although this environment might have otherwise supported a more robust threat of large hail, warm air aloft as noted by 700 millibar temperatures of at least 12-14C likely enhanced convective inhibition (CIN) even for elevated parcels.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The official June 4th rainfall total for Hastings airport was 4.74 inches. The total includes 1.90 inches in the morning, and 2.84 inches in the evening. This is the third highest daily total on record at Hastings for any day of the year, and is the highest daily total on record for the month of June. Total Hastings airport rainfall from June 3rd-5th was 5.39. Two-day rainfall totals of 3-7 were common within much of Adams, Clay, Fillmore, Nuckolls, Thayer, southern Hall, southern Hamilton and southern York counties, resulting in significant flooding across parts of the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a new tornado that developed east of the bigger Plains tornado but passed over open areas with no damage evident.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado damaged pivot irrigation sprinklers as it moved northeast and then turned north into Gray county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.

High terrain thunderstorms moved out of Colorado associated with a passing short wave trough and helped trigger thunderstorms, some severe.  One storm in particular developed and became supercellular and turned south.  It caused extensive damage along it's path shredding corn fields to nubs and killing numerous wildlife.  Thirty-three pivot sprinklers were overturned.  Several high voltage transmission line structures were crumpled by the high wind with speeds in excess of 110 MPH likely.||There was also reports of corn fields (6 foot high stalks) that were completely shredded with nothing but nubs left.  Wildlife in these fields were killed with numerous reports of dead deer, rapids and other critters.

A slow moving cold front sagged southward through western Iowa and eastern Nebraska during the day on August 2nd. Ahead of the front during the early morning hours the nocturnal low-level jet increased ahead of the front. This allowed for isolated thunderstorms to develop in northeast Nebraska and move into west central Iowa during the early morning hours. Some of these thunderstorms reached severe limits with large hail the main threats. These thunderstorms dissipated in the morning hours, but as the instability increased during the afternoon thunderstorms redeveloped along the cold front. Vertical wind shear also increased during the afternoon as well with some of the thunderstorms becoming supercells producing large hail and damaging winds. The thunderstorms weakened by mid to late evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado damaged high voltage transmission lines and poles, pivot irrigation sprinklers, a home and trees.  A stock trailer was tossed through the side of the home but fortunately all occupants were in the basement.  A car in the driveway was carried and then dropped in a field about 100 miles to the north-northeast.  There were no roll marks from the vehicle.  The tornado moved into Ford County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed over Central & South-Central Kansas in the afternoon of the 25th. The thunderstorms barely achieved severity with half dollar-sized hail the largest reported. One severe thunderstorm produced gusts around 52 knots in & near Salina but the most significant event occurred in Southeast Ellsworth County where 4-5 inches of rain caused a flash flood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: With a fairly classic meteorological setup for June severe weather in place, numerous semi-discrete strong to severe thunderstorms blossomed across this six-county North Central Kansas area on this Wednesday evening the 3rd into early Thursday morning the 4th. While these storms yielded mainly quarter size hail, and one report up to 2 diameter south of Burr Oak, the storm of the night was a slow-moving tornadic supercell that peaked in intensity from far east-central Osborne into central Mitchell County between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT. This storm produced three confirmed after-dark tornadoes, two rated EF-1 with path lengths around one mile near the Osborne/Mitchell County line west of Tipton, and a brief EF-0 touchdown slightly east of Tipton. The two stronger tornadoes, one of which moved east and one west under the parent mesocyclone, damaged or destroyed several farm outbuildings, but no injuries occurred. Around midnight CDT, this storm began losing supercell structure and weakening as it drifted northeast through the Beloit area. In addition to tornadoes, this storm produced torrential rainfall of at least 3-4 in a short time across central and western portions of Mitchell County. Other storms produced a swath of heavy rain of generally 1.50-3.00 across much of southern Jewell County. However, the majority of the six-county area totaled no more than 0.50-1.00.  ||Breaking down the overall event timing, several strong to severe storms first blossomed over Rooks and Osborne counties between 700-830 p.m. CDT. Over the next few hours, activity gradually expanded to the north and east, as the aforementioned tornadic supercell took center stage around nightfall. Between 130-230 a.m. CDT on the 4th, storms vacated the entire six-county area to the north and east. Several hours later between 6-8 a.m. CDT, additional elevated storms flared up primarily east of Highway 281, but were non-severe. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front draped through the northern half of Kansas, seasonably strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet ramping up during the night, this was a well-anticipated severe weather event. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. While modest capping held storms at bay through the afternoon, the combination of subtle, low-amplitude disturbances aloft and increasing lift along the developing low level jet sparked a rapid evening flare-up. At the surface, the evening hours featured steady easterly breezes and dewpoints in the mid-upper 60s F. Around the time the tornadic supercell developed, the mesoscale environment featured mixed-layer CAPE around 2000 J/kg, 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear around 30 knots, and fairly strong 0-1 kilometer storm-relative helicity of at least 150 m2/s2.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary was draped across Central Kansas during the overnight and early morning hours of June 5th, 2015.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along this front (generally along Interstate 70), and trained along this boundary.   As the ealry morning progressed and complex of storms moved out of Northwest Kansas and moved along this boundary as well, to produce torrential rainfall across Central Kansas.  So reports of flash flooding occurred, due to rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The intersection of ninth and Republic had water over the road. Several other streets were also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved east across far northern Nebraska, producing hail to golf ball size and wind gusts to 80 mph in Cherry County.

High terrain thunderstorms moved out of Colorado associated with a passing short wave trough and helped trigger thunderstorms, some severe.  One storm in particular developed and became supercellular and turned south.  It caused extensive damage along it's path shredding corn fields to nubs and killing numerous wildlife.  Thirty-three pivot sprinklers were overturned.  Several high voltage transmission line structures were crumpled by the high wind with speeds in excess of 110 MPH likely.||There was also reports of corn fields (6 foot high stalks) that were completely shredded with nothing but nubs left.  Wildlife in these fields were killed with numerous reports of dead deer, rapids and other critters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous large tree branches were blown down.

Wildlife in these fields were killed with numerous reports of dead deer, rapids and other critters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three large high voltage line transmission towers were blown down by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An MCS in northwest flow aloft moved out across the plains.  Early on though widely scattered thunderstorms in a very unstable airmass were able to produce severe weather, including a landspout tornado that was highly visible and which moved across a lake.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 2 inch diameter tree limb was broken by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon and into the evening severe thunderstorms developed over Northwest Kansas.  The strongest storm of the day produced hail 2 deep on Highway 27 8 N of Tribune.  Later on the same storm produced a tornado 11 SE of Leoti, which continued into Scott county.  During the evening a few more severe storms developed producing quarter size hail in Rawlins and Decatur counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel size hail 2 inches deep fell on Highway 27.  The snowplows had to be dispatched to clear the highway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some marginally severe hail fell in a couple locations late on this Friday evening. Through the evening hours, scattered thunderstorms advanced eastward through southwestern Nebraska, just north of the state line. Just after 10 p.m. CST, the storms merged into a multi-cell cluster and moved into Furnas county. Shortly thereafter, this cluster produced some hail over the western part of the county. The largest hail was one inch in diameter. This cluster of storms then weakened, but a short line segment of storms, oriented from northwest to southeast, briefly developed across Dawson, Phelps, and Harlan counties. Before they weakened, a storm near the southern end of the line produced hail up to the size of nickels in extreme southwestern Kearney county. ||All of this thunderstorm activity developed just north of a quasi-stationary front that extended from the Kansas-Nebraska border east-southeast across Missouri and then into the Ohio Valley. The upper levels, subtropical high pressure was over Texas, with a ridge extending northeast over the Mississippi River Valley. A broad trough was upstream over the western United States, with a closed low over northern California and Nevada. A weak shortwave trough was lifting across the Central Plains. MUCAPE was around 2000 J/kg, with deep layer shear near 20 knots.

During the evening a severe thunderstorm moved across Hitchcock and Red Willow counties.  The largest hail reported was golf ball size south of McCook.  Powerful winds from the storm caused major damage to building at the fair grounds in Culbertson and uprooted a few trees in McCook.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail started out as pea to nickel size then increased to the size of a quarter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across the Sandhills during the afternoon and moved southeast toward the I-80 corridor. In addition to large hail in Custer and Lincoln counties, two brief landspout tornadoes touched down in open range land near Lake Maloney, south of North Platte. No damaged was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At 1435CST a public report of a brief landspout tornado that touched down near Lake Maloney. A picture of the landspout was posted on social media in open range land and no damage.

An intense thunderstorm developed over Cheyenne County in eastern Colorado and collapsed as it crossed into Kansas.  Winds estimated at 100 mph produced significant damage to a residence in far northwestern Greeley county as well as to a dairy farming operation further east. A dust storm accompanied the intense burst of winds with a wall of dirt and visibility to near zero reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An intense downburst swept across northern Greeley County producing significant damage and a dust storm dropping visibility to near zero in blowing dirt.  Damage included overturned irrigation pivots, downed utility poles, sides and roofs of outbuilding removed and damage to a dairy farming operation.  Gravel was scoured off county roads and embedded in trees and utility poles.  Damage was consistent with winds of approximately 100 mph.  The strong outflow continued across northern Wichita County and ultimately into Scott county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense thunderstorm developed over Cheyenne County in eastern Colorado and collapsed as it crossed into Kansas.  Winds estimated at 100 mph produced significant damage to a residence in far northwestern Greeley county as well as to a dairy farming operation further east. A dust storm accompanied the intense burst of winds with a wall of dirt and visibility to near zero reported.

A slow moving cold front sagged southward through western Iowa and eastern Nebraska during the day on August 2nd. Ahead of the front during the early morning hours the nocturnal low-level jet increased ahead of the front. This allowed for isolated thunderstorms to develop in northeast Nebraska and move into west central Iowa during the early morning hours. Some of these thunderstorms reached severe limits with large hail the main threats. These thunderstorms dissipated in the morning hours, but as the instability increased during the afternoon thunderstorms redeveloped along the cold front. Vertical wind shear also increased during the afternoon as well with some of the thunderstorms becoming supercells producing large hail and damaging winds. The thunderstorms weakened by mid to late evening.

High terrain thunderstorms moved out of Colorado associated with a passing short wave trough and helped trigger thunderstorms, some severe.  One storm in particular developed and became supercellular and turned south.  It caused extensive damage along it's path shredding corn fields to nubs and killing numerous wildlife.  Thirty-three pivot sprinklers were overturned.  Several high voltage transmission line structures were crumpled by the high wind with speeds in excess of 110 MPH likely.||There was also reports of corn fields (6 foot high stalks) that were completely shredded with nothing but nubs left.  Wildlife in these fields were killed with numerous reports of dead deer, rapids and other critters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The metal roof was blown off a building and a tree three feet in diameter was blown down by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some marginally severe hail fell in a couple locations late on this Friday evening. Through the evening hours, scattered thunderstorms advanced eastward through southwestern Nebraska, just north of the state line. Just after 10 p.m. CST, the storms merged into a multi-cell cluster and moved into Furnas county. Shortly thereafter, this cluster produced some hail over the western part of the county. The largest hail was one inch in diameter. This cluster of storms then weakened, but a short line segment of storms, oriented from northwest to southeast, briefly developed across Dawson, Phelps, and Harlan counties. Before they weakened, a storm near the southern end of the line produced hail up to the size of nickels in extreme southwestern Kearney county. ||All of this thunderstorm activity developed just north of a quasi-stationary front that extended from the Kansas-Nebraska border east-southeast across Missouri and then into the Ohio Valley. The upper levels, subtropical high pressure was over Texas, with a ridge extending northeast over the Mississippi River Valley. A broad trough was upstream over the western United States, with a closed low over northern California and Nevada. A weak shortwave trough was lifting across the Central Plains. MUCAPE was around 2000 J/kg, with deep layer shear near 20 knots.

An isolated thunderstorm developed over central Nebraska shortly after midnight the morning of July July 11th. This storm moved east and dropped quarter size hail in Elgin, Nebraska before quickly dissipating.

Isolated thunderstorms occurred overnight in eastern Nebraska. Although these storms were largely non-severe, one storm did produce a microburst within the Omaha area. These thunderstorms weakened, but additional thunderstorms developed by mid afternoon along a weak surface trough over central Nebraska. The thunderstorms increased in coverage through the late afternoon and into the evening hours as they generally dropped east and southeast. Isolated occurrences of large hail and damaging winds occurred along the track of these storms. Thunderstorms generally weakened by mid to late evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported on a swatch of wind damage from the Benson to Dundee area of Omaha. Within this zone tree limbs of 3 inches or great were blown down. Some homes had siding partially removed, and over 8800 people were without electrical power.

The thunderstorms increased in coverage through the late afternoon and into the evening hours as they generally dropped east and southeast. Isolated occurrences of large hail and damaging winds occurred along the track of these storms. Thunderstorms generally weakened by mid to late evening.

During the early morning hours of the 8th a powerful storm developed in north central KS. As it moved southeastward it began to strengthen as it approached I-70. It then proceeded to move across Topeka causing 70 to 90 mph winds and damage to trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were snapped or uprooted.

Several clusters of strong to severe storms developed during the afternoon and evening over Northwest Kansas, some of them remaining stationary at times.  The largest hail size reported was quarter size near Blakeman, however over three inches of small hail was reported near Edson.  The strongest wind gust reported was an estimated 70 MPH at Winona, which occurred when the town to lose power.  A measured wind speed of 65 MPH was reported near Leoti ahead of a line of storms.  Flash flooding occurred near Winona with these storms as water 18 inches deep and roughly 100 yards wide was reported over Road 230.
After midnight a severe thunderstorm developed south of Sharon Springs.  Large hail up to quarter size was reported.
During the late evening a strong thunderstorm moved over Culbertson.  Nickle size hail was reported with this storm.

Thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon over north central Nebraska as moisture returned to the region behind cold front that moved through the region on the 18th of July. These thunderstorms generally weakened as they moved into northeast Nebraska near midnight, but one storm in Boone County produced damaging wind.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered large tree branches were blown down around town. In addition, one healthy tree was uprooted and fell into a house in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved slowly southeast across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the day on July 24th. Ahead of the front, isolated thunderstorms developed during the early morning on the 24th as moisture returned to the region. Later in the day, extreme instability developed ahead of the front as temperatures soared into the upper 90s coupled with dew points in the mid and upper 70s. Two rounds of thunderstorms developed in association with the front. The first was in the late afternoon over east central Nebraska into southwest Iowa, and then a second round occurred as storms moved into the region from central Nebraska around midnight crossing into southwest Iowa early in the morning on the 25th. Both of these rounds produced isolated severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager, as well as media outlets, reported significant tree damage in the town of Wymore.

Two rounds of thunderstorms developed in association with the front. The first was in the late afternoon over east central Nebraska into southwest Iowa, and then a second round occurred as storms moved into the region from central Nebraska around midnight crossing into southwest Iowa early in the morning on the 25th. Both of these rounds produced isolated severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported tree limbs 8 to 10 inches in diameter were downed in the city of Plattsmouth.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved slowly southeast across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the day on July 24th. Ahead of the front, isolated thunderstorms developed during the early morning on the 24th as moisture returned to the region. Later in the day, extreme instability developed ahead of the front as temperatures soared into the upper 90s coupled with dew points in the mid and upper 70s. Two rounds of thunderstorms developed in association with the front. The first was in the late afternoon over east central Nebraska into southwest Iowa, and then a second round occurred as storms moved into the region from central Nebraska around midnight crossing into southwest Iowa early in the morning on the 25th. Both of these rounds produced isolated severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twitter pictures indicated numerous tree branches down on the southeast side of Lincoln, some greater than 8 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong complex of thunderstorms moved across southern South Dakota during the evening of June 19th, and into the early morning hours of June 20th. Although the majority of these storms stayed in South Dakota, the southern edge of the squall line moved across Knox County in northeast Nebraska producing strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few large tree limbs down and some shingle damage to roofs were reported.

A stationary boundary was draped across Central Kansas during the overnight and early morning hours of June 5th, 2015. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: While conditions were not particularly hot, they were slightly above average for the mid to late summer. A 15 year old boy was out riding his bike near Osawatomie when he complained to his friend of being too hot, so he turned around to go home. He was found near train tracks near 335th Street and Bethel Church Road about 5 p.m. August 3. His autopsy determined dehydration being a significant factor in his death.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: While conditions were not particularly hot, they were slightly above average for the mid to late summer, with heat indices in the middle to upper 90s. A 15 year old boy was out riding his bike near Osawatomie when he complained to his friend of being too hot, so he turned around to go home. He was found near train tracks near 335th Street and Bethel Church Road about 5 p.m. August 3. His autopsy determined dehydration being a significant factor in his death.

Showers and thunderstorms developed along this front (generally along Interstate 70), and trained along this boundary.   As the ealry morning progressed and complex of storms moved out of Northwest Kansas and moved along this boundary as well, to produce torrential rainfall across Central Kansas.  So reports of flash flooding occurred, due to rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported water over several roads across town.   Rainfall amounts ranged from 2 to 4 inches.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The golf ball hail was reported along the Lincoln and Ottawa county line.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Significant tree, utility pole and structural damage consistent with an intense downburst occurred in the eastern portions of Palisade and adjacent areas south and east of town. One large garage south of town was destroyed, several irrigation pivots were overturned, and grain bins were damaged or destroyed. An estimated 250 utility poles throughout the county were either snapped or pushed down. Power outages continue in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A complex of showers and thunderstorms moved across portions of Central Kansas during the early morning hours of August 5th, 2015.  The complex propagated to the southeast and produced one hail report, but mainly produced damaging winds along and east of Interstate 135.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was mostly nickel size with a couple of quarter size stones.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong November severe weather episode occurred across the region.  A very strong upper level low approached with with strong winds aloft.  An unusually high amount of moisture and unseasonably unstable airmass were transported north into Kansas.  Storms developed along a dry line but quickly moved off the dryline and became supercellular.  Large, long tracked and rapidly moving tornadoes occurred along with instances of large and damaging hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was significant vehicle damage from the hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced damaging winds in Dixon and Dakota Counties of extreme northeast Nebraska during the evening  of July 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds caused tree damage, including a large cottonwood tree uprooted and blown onto a shed. Other tree damage included large limbs blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced damaging winds in Dixon and Dakota Counties of extreme northeast Nebraska during the evening  of July 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds blew down branches and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms produced damaging winds in Dixon and Dakota Counties of extreme northeast Nebraska during the evening  of July 17th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds caused tree damage, including two 18 inch diameter trees and numerous smaller branches blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated supercell developed along a rather diffuse cold frontal boundary during the evening hours of June 7th, 2015.   This supercell moved to the southeast and produced large hail and damaging winds along its path from northwest of Salina, to Salina to Cottonwood Falls.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tallgrass Prairie Raws site measured the gust.

A cluster of severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon over Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was two inches in diameter near Colby and Bird City.  Some thunderstorms also produced high winds, with the highest wind gusts of 64 MPH reported at the Oakley airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail shredded leaves and broke some house windows.  The largest hail size increased from 1.5 to 2 in diameter, with the average size being a penny.

A strong upper level low swept through the Southern Rockies and into the Central Plains November 16th and 17th before exiting the area on the 18th. Wrap around moisture from this low and frontogenesis formed across northwestern Kansas and eastern Colorado early in the morning causing snow to fall and persisted throughout the day. This band of snow then slowly shifted eastward during the evening and overnight hours. Over 6 inches of snow fell outside of our forecast area with lesser amounts in the counties mentioned above.  Snowfall greater than 2 inches fell in portions northwestern Scott, northern Kearney, a majority of Hamilton, western Stanton, and western Morton counties. The highest reported snowfall was 6 inches located 11 miles north of Coolidge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 6 inches was observed at a location about 8 miles north of Coolidge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Both a cold front and an upper level low moving out of the Rockies helped fuel severe thunderstorms during the evening.
Both a cold front and an upper level low moving out of the Rockies helped fuel severe thunderstorms during the evening.
Both a cold front and an upper level low moving out of the Rockies helped fuel severe thunderstorms during the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five power poles were broken by high wind and RVs were flipped over by the high wind.  No injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Both a cold front and an upper level low moving out of the Rockies helped fuel severe thunderstorms during the evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 60 MPH.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor street flooding was reported in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong upper level storm system moved across the northern Plains during the day on August 22nd. This system allowed for a strong cold front to sweep across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the late afternoon and evening. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed along the cold front from west central Iowa into eastern Nebraska, and moved southeast through the evening. Although the large majority of these storms were sub-severe, isolated reports of large hail and damaging winds were received.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported heavy rainfall and some minor street flooding in town.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated supercells developed along a weak frontal boundary during the late afternoon and early evening hours of August 8th, 2015.  One such supercell produced a quarter size hail report across Central Kansas.

A cluster of severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon over Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was two inches in diameter near Colby and Bird City.  Some thunderstorms also produced high winds, with the highest wind gusts of 64 MPH reported at the Oakley airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm winds picked up and damaged a heavy wooden picnic table.  A trampoline, which was staked into the ground, was pulled up and lofted.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to 64 MPH were reported at the airport.  In town the thunderstorm winds blew down a 9 inch tree limb.

In a very unstable airmass, a few thunderstorms became severe and several produced excessive rainfall.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fields were reported to be flooded and some of the runoff went across highway 25.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved slowly southeast across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the day on July 24th. Ahead of the front, isolated thunderstorms developed during the early morning on the 24th as moisture returned to the region. Later in the day, extreme instability developed ahead of the front as temperatures soared into the upper 90s coupled with dew points in the mid and upper 70s. Two rounds of thunderstorms developed in association with the front. The first was in the late afternoon over east central Nebraska into southwest Iowa, and then a second round occurred as storms moved into the region from central Nebraska around midnight crossing into southwest Iowa early in the morning on the 25th. Both of these rounds produced isolated severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several branches reported blown down ranging from 1 to 15 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ample June moisture and a weak front in the area allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop over parts of central and eastern Nebraska. The majority of these storms were non severe in nature due to limited vertical wind shear, but sufficient instability allowed for an isolated large hail report, and later as storms developed more into an eastward moving complex, a couple of reports of strong wind gusts.
A thunderstorm produced a brief landspout.
A thunderstorm produced a brief landspout.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief landspout tornado.

An unseasonably strong upper level storm system moved across the northern Plains during the day on August 22nd. This system allowed for a strong cold front to sweep across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the late afternoon and evening. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed along the cold front from west central Iowa into eastern Nebraska, and moved southeast through the evening. Although the large majority of these storms were sub-severe, isolated reports of large hail and damaging winds were received.

A slow moving upper level storm system crossed Nebraska during the day on August 28th and into the state of Iowa on the 29th. Seasonably deep moisture combined with the slow moving storm system to produce intense rainfall over parts of northeast Nebraska. Some rainfall amounts ranged from 6 to 8 inches during the evening. The rainfall slowly diminished after midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media indicated that areal flooding continued into the morning on the 28th of August. This included water across U.S. Highway 275 and State Highway 70. In addition numerous farm fields, ditches, and small streams flooded during this time as well. The flooding slowly receded through the morning as the rainfall had ended.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong upper level storm system moved across the northern Plains during the day on August 22nd. This system allowed for a strong cold front to sweep across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the late afternoon and evening. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed along the cold front from west central Iowa into eastern Nebraska, and moved southeast through the evening. Although the large majority of these storms were sub-severe, isolated reports of large hail and damaging winds were received.

During the afternoon severe thunderstorms developed near St. Francis.  Large hail up to ping-pong ball size was reported near town.  In addition lightning strikes from the storm started as many as a dozen small fires in the Cheyenne county area.
During the early afternoon a severe thunderstorm developed near Parks.  Quarter size hail was reported with this storm.

Several clusters of strong to severe storms developed during the afternoon and evening over Northwest Kansas, some of them remaining stationary at times.  The largest hail size reported was quarter size near Blakeman, however over three inches of small hail was reported near Edson.  The strongest wind gust reported was an estimated 70 MPH at Winona, which occurred when the town to lose power.  A measured wind speed of 65 MPH was reported near Leoti ahead of a line of storms.  Flash flooding occurred near Winona with these storms as water 18 inches deep and roughly 100 yards wide was reported over Road 230.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eighteen inches of water 75 to 100 yards wide is running over County Road 230 just north of Cedar Crest Road.  Road 230 is closed from Winona to the Thomas county line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed in an extremely unstable atmosphere, characterized with temperatures in the mid 90s and dew points in the mid 70s, over northeast Nebraska during the late afternoon and continued into the evening. The thunderstorms were developing along and behind a cold front in the area. Large hail, damaging winds and heavy rainfall were observed from these thunderstorms that generally weakened by late evening.
Thunderstorms developed along a thermal trough in the presence of an unstable airmass during the afternoon heat and a few became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 60 to 70 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late afternoon thunderstorm over southern Kimball County produced large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed 11 miles south-southeast of the Kimball Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm in southeast Box Butte County produced large hail and a funnel cloud.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea to golf ball size hail was reported four miles north of Alliance.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm in southeast Box Butte County produced large hail and a funnel cloud.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half dollar size hail was observed 17 miles southwest of Chadron.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms over Sioux County produced very heavy rain and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed at Harrison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon thunderstorms over Sioux County produced very heavy rain and large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of rain in less than two hours produced flash flooding.  Warbonnet, Van Tassel and Monroe Creeks were running over their banks with lowland flooding reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon thunderstorms over the southern Nebraska Panhandle produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ping pong ball size hail was observed seven miles northeast of Bridgeport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon thunderstorms over the southern Nebraska Panhandle produced large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel to quarter size hail was observed at Broadwater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong November severe weather episode occurred across the region.  A very strong upper level low approached with with strong winds aloft.  An unusually high amount of moisture and unseasonably unstable airmass were transported north into Kansas.  Storms developed along a dry line but quickly moved off the dryline and became supercellular.  Large, long tracked and rapidly moving tornadoes occurred along with instances of large and damaging hail.

Multiple rounds of severe weather moved across southeast KS producing hail and torrential downpours.  The heavy rains resulted in flash flooding in Montgomery county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rains produced nuisance flooding of the usual flood prone areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple rounds of severe weather moved across southeast KS producing hail and torrential downpours.  The heavy rains resulted in flash flooding in Montgomery county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several inches of water was flowing over the road making for dangerous conditions.  Elsewhere across the county, nuisance flooding of the usual flood prone areas was noted.

During the early morning hours of the 8th a powerful storm developed in north central KS. As it moved southeastward it began to strengthen as it approached I-70. It then proceeded to move across Topeka causing 70 to 90 mph winds and damage to trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of the 8th a powerful storm developed in north central KS. As it moved southeastward it began to strengthen as it approached I-70. It then proceeded to move across Topeka causing 70 to 90 mph winds and damage to trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of 4 inch diameter tree limbs down and pea sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of strong to severe storms developed during the afternoon and evening over Northwest Kansas, some of them remaining stationary at times.  The largest hail size reported was quarter size near Blakeman, however over three inches of small hail was reported near Edson.  The strongest wind gust reported was an estimated 70 MPH at Winona, which occurred when the town to lose power.  A measured wind speed of 65 MPH was reported near Leoti ahead of a line of storms.  Flash flooding occurred near Winona with these storms as water 18 inches deep and roughly 100 yards wide was reported over Road 230.

Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed in an extremely unstable atmosphere, characterized with temperatures in the mid 90s and dew points in the mid 70s, over northeast Nebraska during the late afternoon and continued into the evening. The thunderstorms were developing along and behind a cold front in the area. Large hail, damaging winds and heavy rainfall were observed from these thunderstorms that generally weakened by late evening.

Ample June moisture and a weak front in the area allowed for scattered thunderstorms to develop over parts of central and eastern Nebraska. The majority of these storms were non severe in nature due to limited vertical wind shear, but sufficient instability allowed for an isolated large hail report, and later as storms developed more into an eastward moving complex, a couple of reports of strong wind gusts.

Isolated thunderstorms developed along a surface trough over northeast Nebraska on the afternoon of July 16th. Although the thunderstorms were supercells, limited instability and a very warm atmosphere reduced the severe weather threat to smaller hail. The thunderstorms quickly dissipated after sunset.

Thunderstorms increased in coverage and intensity during the evening on July 15th into the early morning hours of the 16th to the north of a surface warm front. Instability was limited across the area and thus allowed for most thunderstorms to be non-severe during the evening and overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported blown down along U.S. Highway 75 and Platteview Rd blocking the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms increased in coverage and intensity during the evening on July 15th into the early morning hours of the 16th to the north of a surface warm front. EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manger relayed reports from local law enforcement of strong winds estimated in excess of 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms over Kimball and Cheyenne counties produced torrential rainfall that resulted in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Five to eight inches of rain overnight over east central Kimball County produced flash flooding.  County Road 45 near US Highway 30 was washed out.  County Road 55 near US Highway 30 and railroad was washed out.  Extensive lowland flooding was reported along the Lodgepole Creek drainage basin as well as areas surrounding Interstate 80 from three miles east of Kimball to two miles west of Dix.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over Banner and Kimball counties produced several funnel clouds, damaging winds and torrential rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three inches of rain in less than two hours caused flash flooding.  Many Kimball streets were closed by more than a foot of water.  Lodgepole Creek overran its banks with lowland flooding reported south across US Highway 30 and Interstate 80.

In a couple rounds of severe thunderstorms early morning storms did some wind damage in eastern Kansas and western Missouri. Later in the day more storms moved in causing some wind damage as well as some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees around 6 to 8 inches were down at 295th and Bethel Church.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In a couple rounds of severe thunderstorms early morning storms did some wind damage in eastern Kansas and western Missouri. Later in the day more storms moved in causing some wind damage as well as some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were down just north of Fontana. The trees were 6 to 8 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In a couple rounds of severe thunderstorms early morning storms did some wind damage in eastern Kansas and western Missouri. Later in the day more storms moved in causing some wind damage as well as some flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several power lines were down in Mound City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent low pressure system tracked east across the central Rockies and high plains, while an arctic front surged south through the region.  Periods of light to moderate snowfall combined with gusty northwest winds of 40 to 50 mph created considerable blowing snow and very low visibility.  Consequently, Interstate 80 was closed from the Wyoming border east of Sidney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of light to moderate snowfall combined with northwest winds gusting as high as 50 mph produced considerable blowing snow and very low visibility. Interstate 80 was closed from the Wyoming border to mile marker 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent low pressure system tracked east across the central Rockies and high plains, while an arctic front surged south through the region.  Periods of light to moderate snowfall combined with gusty northwest winds of 40 to 50 mph created considerable blowing snow and very low visibility.  Consequently, Interstate 80 was closed from the Wyoming border east of Sidney.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Periods of light to moderate snowfall combined with northwest winds gusting as high as 50 mph produced considerable blowing snow and very low visibility. Interstate 80 was closed from east of mile marker 30 to mile marker 77.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep trough across the southwest United States moved into the southern Plains early on January 31st. Ahead of this system deep moisture spread northward across the central Plains. This broad, but persistent area of warm air advection led to increasing showers over Kansas, which moved northward into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa early on the 31st. This initial precipitation was a mix of light rain and snow through mid afternoon. As colder air, associated with a stronger northern stream trough and cold front, started to move into the area late Saturday afternoon and evening the precipitation turned to all snow and began to accumulate. Snow, occasionally moderate, continued into Saturday night diminishing to light snow on Sunday morning, before ending Sunday afternoon. Snowfall of 5 to 9 inches were common across east central and southeast Nebraska, as well as southwest Iowa. As the colder air moved into the area Saturday night winds switched from northeast to northwest and increased. Winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph were common into the day on Sunday that led to considerable blowing and drifting snow. The combination of falling and blowing snow resulted in reduced visibilities and very difficult driving conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 6 to 7 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep trough across the southwest United States moved into the southern Plains early on January 31st. Ahead of this system deep moisture spread northward across the central Plains. This broad, but persistent area of warm air advection led to increasing showers over Kansas, which moved northward into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa early on the 31st. This initial precipitation was a mix of light rain and snow through mid afternoon. As colder air, associated with a stronger northern stream trough and cold front, started to move into the area late Saturday afternoon and evening the precipitation turned to all snow and began to accumulate. Snow, occasionally moderate, continued into Saturday night diminishing to light snow on Sunday morning, before ending Sunday afternoon. Snowfall of 5 to 9 inches were common across east central and southeast Nebraska, as well as southwest Iowa. As the colder air moved into the area Saturday night winds switched from northeast to northwest and increased. Winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph were common into the day on Sunday that led to considerable blowing and drifting snow. The combination of falling and blowing snow resulted in reduced visibilities and very difficult driving conditions. This winter storm continued into February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 6 to 8 inches across the county, included a measured 6 inches near Auburn, and a measured 8 inches measured near Nemaha.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Periods of light snow began during the very early morning hours before sunrise Saturday, January 31st, primarily along and east of Highway 281. The temperature profile was very marginal, but snow continued to fall through the day. It did mix with rain at times. Due to its persistence, some wet accumulations of 1 to 2 inches occurred on grassy surfaces. During the evening hours, snow became widespread as an organized snow band formed in the deformation zone of an intensifying low pressure center. Snow fell over nearly all of north central Kansas for a time, but the heaviest and most persistent snow fell where it had been snowing during the daylight hours of Saturday, east of Highway 281. By 4 am CST Sunday, the accumulating snow ended and exited into northeast Kansas. However, some smaller bands of light snow lingered through mid-morning. Storm total snowfall was generally 2 to 5 inches from eastern Smith into Jewell counties. The highest amount of 5.8 inches was measured at Mankato. As the snow ended, north winds dramatically increased as the low pressure system organized. Winds were sustained around 30 mph with gusts up to 45 mph. The cooling of the temperature profile allowed for the snow character to become drier after sunset. The result was significant blowing and drifting that lasted through the afternoon hours. The visibility was below one mile at times in blowing snow.||The initial wet snow Saturday occurred in warm air advection, in the entrance region of a 150 kt upper-level jet streak. The forcing for precipitation changed, however, as an arctic cold front sagged into Nebraska with lee cyclogenesis occurring ahead of it over southeastern Colorado. As the front continued moving south into Kansas Saturday night, the weak low left Colorado and progressed east along the front. It was located near Kansas City by daybreak Sunday and advanced east into Indiana by sunset. It was this low that was responsible for the majority of the snowfall accumulation which occurred Saturday night. The central pressure never lowered to less than 1005 mb and there was no deepening. However, the pressure gradient was significant northwest of the low, resulting in the strong winds. As with much of this winter, the flow aloft was split with a ridge along the West Coast, a closed low over the Desert Southwest, and confluent flow into the trough over the eastern United States. This low formed as a result of a shortwave trough that came out of western Canada and amplified as it approached the longwave trough.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level low swept through the Southern Rockies and into the Central Plains November 16th and 17th before exiting the area on the 18th. Wrap around moisture from this low and frontogenesis formed across northwestern Kansas and eastern Colorado early in the morning causing snow to fall and persisted throughout the day. This band of snow then slowly shifted eastward during the evening and overnight hours. Over 6 inches of snow fell outside of our forecast area with lesser amounts in the counties mentioned above.  Snowfall greater than 2 inches fell in portions northwestern Scott, northern Kearney, a majority of Hamilton, western Stanton, and western Morton counties. The highest reported snowfall was 6 inches located 11 miles north of Coolidge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall was generally around 4 inches across the county.

Ahead of this system deep moisture spread northward across the central Plains. This broad, but persistent area of warm air advection led to increasing showers over Kansas, which moved northward into eastern Nebraska and western Iowa early on the 31st. This initial precipitation was a mix of light rain and snow through mid afternoon. As colder air, associated with a stronger northern stream trough and cold front, started to move into the area late Saturday afternoon and evening the precipitation turned to all snow and began to accumulate. Snow, occasionally moderate, continued into Saturday night diminishing to light snow on Sunday morning, before ending Sunday afternoon. Snowfall of 5 to 9 inches were common across east central and southeast Nebraska, as well as southwest Iowa. As the colder air moved into the area Saturday night winds switched from northeast to northwest and increased. Winds of 20 to 30 mph with gusts over 40 mph were common into the day on Sunday that led to considerable blowing and drifting snow. The combination of falling and blowing snow resulted in reduced visibilities and very difficult driving conditions. This winter storm continued into February.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall ranged from 6 to 9 inches across the county including a measured 6 inches in Bloomfield and 9 inches in Crofton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms formed on the evening of March 28th across the eastern Nebraska Panhandle. As they moved east, they produced a downburst over portions of Garden County which led to damage.  As the thunderstorms moved east, they touched off a wildfire in far eastern Arthur County.  Aided by strong northerly winds, the fire burned over 35,000 acres of range land in eastern Arthur, western McPherson and eastern Keith Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dry lightning started a fire 13 miles east of Arthur around 830 PM MST.  The fire quickly spread south aided by strong northerly winds.  By the morning of the 29th, around 30000 acres of range land was burned over eastern Arthur, western McPherson and eastern Keith counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moved into eastern Nebraska during the afternoon of the 1st. Ahead of the cold front some moisture return from the southern Pains coupled with steep lapse-rates aloft to create marginal instability. Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed along the cold front by late afternoon, developing into a line of thunderstorms before moving southeast through eastern Nebraska and into western Iowa. Isolated severe weather was reported along this line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An active weather pattern set up over the Central Plains and Middle to Lower Missouri Valley. Rain with embedded thunderstorms occurred the night of the 23rd into the 24th with some of the storms producing small hail.
A thunderstorm produced nickel size hail at Emerson in Dakota County in extreme northeast Nebraska on the morning of June 24th.

A strong upper level low swept through the Southern Rockies and into the Central Plains November 16th and 17th before exiting the area on the 18th. Wrap around moisture from this low and frontogenesis formed across northwestern Kansas and eastern Colorado early in the morning causing snow to fall and persisted throughout the day. This band of snow then slowly shifted eastward during the evening and overnight hours. Over 6 inches of snow fell outside of our forecast area with lesser amounts in the counties mentioned above.  Snowfall greater than 2 inches fell in portions northwestern Scott, northern Kearney, a majority of Hamilton, western Stanton, and western Morton counties. The highest reported snowfall was 6 inches located 11 miles north of Coolidge.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall was generally around 2 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe Drought conditions persisted across Northwest Kansas south of Sherman and Thomas counties.  Precipitation reports ranged from 0.02 below normal to 0.41 below normal for the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation reports ranged from 0.09 below normal to 0.25 below normal for the month.
