Scattered to numerous, semi-discrete and multicell thunderstorms blossomed across much of South Central Nebraska on this Saturday afternoon and evening, with a few storms becoming severe and producing hail ranging from 1-2 in diameter. The first severe storm of the afternoon developed near Kearney around 5 p.m. CDT, and was likely the most prolific hail-producer as it slowly drifted north-northwest through central and northwest Buffalo County for nearly two hours. Just north of Kearney, a few vehicles slid off of Highway 10 as it became hail-covered and slick. This storm also produced the largest reported hail of the day (2) north of Riverdale. Between 6-9 p.m. CDT, several other storms either flared up over various parts of the area or pushed northward out of Kansas, with quarter size hail reported near the state line south of Red Cloud and also in Wood River. Even though the mesoscale environment was potentially supportive of a somewhat greater severe weather threat, the fairly rapid development of plentiful convection and resultant storm-scale outflow interference likely mitigated this. With the loss of diurnal heating, storms steadily weakened and diminished in coverage within a few hours after nightfall. Although most affected areas received less than 1 of rainfall, much of northern Kearney County along with adjacent portions of southeast Buffalo, southwest Hall and northwest Adams counties received higher amounts to around 2. ||In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was an expansive closed low churning slowly eastward through eastern Colorado, with several smaller-scale disturbances shifting northward into the Central Plains along its eastern flank. At the surface, there were no distinct synoptic features within South Central Nebraska, only fairly weak, broad low pressure and prevailing light southerly to easterly breezes. Despite afternoon temperatures only rising into the low-70s F, the combination of surface dewpoints in the low to mid-50s and notably cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -18 C) yielded surface-based CAPE around 1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to golf ball size covered Highway 10 three miles north of Kearney, causing drivers to slide off of the road and into the ditch.

During the late afternoon and evening hours on this Thursday, scattered to numerous thunderstorms rumbled through South Central Nebraska counties mainly along and south of the Interstate 80 corridor, resulting in a handful of sub-severe hail reports in the penny to nickel size range. Although radar data suggested that various other locations likely experienced hail up to around this size, the only ground-truth reports originated from Hastings, Edgar and from the vicinities of Kearney, Sutton and Clay Center. While most of this convection was multicellular and linear, there were a few briefly semi-discrete structures as well. Rainfall amounts under most of the heaviest convection averaged between 0.50 and 1, with only few localized higher exceptions. ||Strong storms first developed into southwestern counties such as Harlan and Franklin between 430-600 p.m. CDT. Then between 6-9 p.m. CDT, a couple of narrow west-to-east arcs of strong storms developed eastward through the Highway 6 and Interstate 80 corridors and lifted slowly north, resulting in the aforementioned hail reports. After nightfall, a few stronger storms lingered over mainly Thayer and Fillmore counties for a time, but these steadily faded with the loss of diurnal heating. In the mid and upper levels, weak forcing was provided by small-scale disturbances shifting into the Central Plains on southerly flow aloft, well-downstream from an expansive large-scale closed low spinning over the Four Corners region. At the surface, afternoon high temperatures only climbed between the mid-60s and low-70s F across most of the area, but the combination of surface dewpoints in the mid-50s and rather cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -16 C) was sufficient to promote modest surface-based CAPE as high as 500-1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear only around 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail nearly covered the ground. Most of the hail stones were pea size, but some were as big as three quarter inch diameter. Wind gusts of up to 30 mph and torrential rain occurred, and visibility dropped to about 3/8 of a mile during the heaviest rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager estimated 70 mph gusts and ping pong ball sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and associated upper level trough moved across the southeast Kansas. Severe storms and some supercells developed which had damaging winds, large hail, and isolated tornadoes.
A cold front and associated upper level trough moved across the southeast Kansas. Severe storms and some supercells developed which had damaging winds, large hail, and isolated tornadoes.

A passing upper level disturbance produced a brief period of moderate to heavy snow across portions of the northern Nebraska Panhandle.  Gusty northwest winds of 20 to 30 mph created low visibility in blowing snow.  Snowfall totals ranged from six to ten inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to ten inches of snow was reported from Alliance to five miles south of Alliance.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A passing upper level disturbance produced a brief period of moderate to heavy snow across portions of the northern Nebraska Panhandle.  Gusty northwest winds of 20 to 30 mph created low visibility in blowing snow.  Snowfall totals ranged from six to ten inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer 24 miles southwest of Hemingford measured 7.5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On this Wednesday morning, a fairly significant winter storm took aim on South Central Nebraska for the second time in five days. Unlike the more prolonged event of the preceding weekend, this one was a quick hitter associated with one primary snow band, with most affected areas receiving accumulation for no more than 6-7 hours. Despite this brevity, bursts of moderate to heavy snow combined with sustained north wind of generally 20-25 MPH and gusts up to around 35 MPH to promote a treacherous morning commute along with numerous school closures. The brunt of this system targeted locations north-northeast of a line extending from Gothenburg-Hastings-Hebron, where most places received at least 2-4 inches. However, the epicenter of heaviest accumulations on the order of 4-8 occurred in a generally 30-40 mile wide corridor extending from around Loup City in the northwest, then east-southeast through the St. Paul, Grand Island, Central City, Aurora, Osceola and York areas. Within the heart of this band, a few of the highest measured totals (per a combination of NWS cooperative observers and NeRAIN observers) featured 8.7 four miles north of Aurora, 8.2 at Ravenna, 7.1 in Loup City, 6.1 at Grand Island airport, 6.0 at St. Paul and 5.7 in Osceola. On either side of this primary snow band there was a fairly sharp drop-off in amounts, as evidenced by reports from Ord (3.0) and Genoa (3.0) to the north, and Hastings (1.7) and Hebron (2.8) to the south. ||Breaking down event timing, this generally west-to-east oriented snow band first infiltrated the northwestern quadrant of South Central Nebraska between 1-3 a.m. and then steadily intensified through daybreak as it spread east. Generally between 7-9 a.m., the band began sinking southward across the Highway 6 corridor and toward the Kansas border, while gradually weakening and ending from north-to-south and also from west-to-east. By 1130 a.m. the vast majority of the local area was snow-free. On the synoptic and mesoscale aloft, this quick-but-intense event was driven by a rather classic, strongly-forced frontogenetic band evident mainly in the 850-500 millibar layer, but especially centered around 700 millibars. This frontogenetic forcing slid across the heart of Nebraska from northwest-to-southeast, enhanced by a coupled upper jet structure evident at 300 millibars, featuring the exit region of one jet streak nosing in from the Northern Rockies and the entrance region of another jet streak centered over the Upper Midwest. At the surface, gusty north wind across Nebraska was driven by an enhanced pressure gradient between an Arctic high pressure system sliding into the Northern Plains and the leading edges of a cold front charging southward through southern Kansas at daybreak. Temperatures across South Central Nebraska averaged between 15-20 F during the majority of this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall total of 7.1 inches was reported 2 miles northwest of Rockville, along with 6.2 inches in Loup City. Wind gusts of up to 30 to 35 mph occurred out of the north. These snowfall reports were from Nebraska Rainfall Assessment and Information Network (NERAIN).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short line of severe thunderstorms moved northeast during the late afternoon hours of Saturday May 16th.  The line produced sporadic wind damage along a wide path and it also produced a narrow short path of more intense damage that was attributed to a small tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short line of severe thunderstorms moved northeast during the late afternoon hours of Saturday May 16th.  The line produced sporadic wind damage along a wide path and it also produced a narrow short path of more intense damage that was attributed to a small tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roof blown off of a barn on south Paulen rd in Overbrook.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A short line of severe thunderstorms moved northeast during the late afternoon hours of Saturday May 16th.  The line produced sporadic wind damage along a wide path and it also produced a narrow short path of more intense damage that was attributed to a small tornado.

A short line of severe thunderstorms moved northeast during the late afternoon hours of Saturday May 16th.  The line produced sporadic wind damage along a wide path and it also produced a narrow short path of more intense damage that was attributed to a small tornado.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Barns and homes damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two brief weak EF0 tornadoes touched down with a low topped supercell during the evening of May 15th.  No damage occurred.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report of a brief tornado touchdown that lasted around one minute.  No damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon and evening of the 25th a line of storms developed along a boundary in a very unstable environment. These storms produced large hail and then proceeded to move over the same areas causing flash flooding.

During the afternoon strong to severe storms moved across parts of Northwest Kansas. The largest hail size reported was 2.5 inches reported near Selkirk.  The majority of the large hail reports were confined to Greeley county. A couple tornadoes developed northwest of Lydia over the southern half of Wichita county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Brief tornado touchdown reported via The Spotter Network.

An intense late season snowstorm affected portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle with moderate to heavy snow and gusty northeast winds of 30 mph. Very low visibility in falling and blowing snow closed portions of Highway 385 north of Alliance. Snowfall totals ranged from six inches to as much as two feet north of the Pine Ridge.

An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front acted as a focusing mechanism in an unstable airmass to help produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado quickly developed with thunderstorm mergers occurring near an old outflow boundary.  Damage was done to power poles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary front acted as a focusing mechanism in an unstable airmass to help produce thunderstorms during the late afternoon and early evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a weak landspout that developed near a bigger tornado but it only lasted a short time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered showers and thunderstorms developed during the afternoon on May 17th along and ahead of a cold front. Nearly all the storms remained below severe limits, but one cell moving through central Nebraska and into Boone County briefly became severe with strong gusty winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported winds to near 70 mph. This resulted in tree limbs of 2 to 3 inches in diameter being blown down. There were also center irrigation pivots overturned as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.

On the morning of April 8, several severe thunderstorms rolled through the area, bringing with it mostly large hail. These storms even brought 1.5 inch hail to the NWS office in Pleasant Hill, Missouri. On the Kansas side, the only hail reports were from the morning convection, but in Missouri the second round in the afternoon and evening brought a long swatch of wind that went into Central Missouri. In the Kansas City metro area a left-moving short-lived storm brought 2 inch hail that afternoon to the northern part of the metro.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms erupted along a stationary front during the afternoon. The initial storms produced land-spouts with subsequent storms producing hail and wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was the first of 5 landspout tornadoes that occurred along a convergence area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was the second landspout out of five that occurred.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several streets in Carbondale and across the county are flooded.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was the fourth out of five landspout tornadoes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms erupted along a stationary front during the afternoon. The initial storms produced land-spouts with subsequent storms producing hail and wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was the fifth of five landspout tornadoes.  This one struck a farm doing low end EF1 damage to a well built 60 by 100 foot building, a tractor and home.  Wind speeds estimated to be about 90 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level jet streak, unstable atmosphere and a warm front lifting north helped to fuel thunderstorms, some severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado was video taped by a web tower cam but it passed through an area with no trees, fences or buildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a very unstable atmosphere aided by a short wave trough and residual outflow boundaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This landspout was one of the first tornadoes reported during this event.  It moved northwest very slowly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a very unstable atmosphere aided by a short wave trough and residual outflow boundaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This landspout formed first before the mesocyclone tornado formed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced a 60 mph wind gust at the Goodland ASOS.  At about the same time, local law enforcement reported a carport was lofted over a building in downtown Goodland, landing upright on Main Street.  Only minor building damage was reported, with heavy damage to the carport itself.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A carport was blown over a building and onto Main Street in Goodland.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peak wind gust was estimated at 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a very unstable atmosphere aided by a short wave trough and residual outflow boundaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado did high end EF1 damage to Pivot irrigation sprinklers along with other damage to several outbuildings and eight large grain bins.  A semi was flipped and carried into a field.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This landspout looking tornado traveled northwest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the evening of the 23rd isolated severe hail occurred near the city of Holton. Later the next day marginal hail occurred in Osage county as a line of storms moved through the area.
On the afternoon of the 3rd a line of storms developed in far northeast Kansas. They proceeded to move south and managed to produce large hail before weakening.
On the afternoon of the 3rd a line of storms developed in far northeast Kansas. They proceeded to move south and managed to produce large hail before weakening.

On the evening of the 7th several supercells developed within a weakly forced environment that was very unstable. These supercells were persistent and produced hail between 1-2 inches in diameter.

An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.
Wind and hail around severe criteria occurred on the morning and again during the night of April 2nd. No damage was reported with this event and reports were fairly isolated.
Wind and hail around severe criteria occurred on the morning and again during the night of April 2nd. No damage was reported with this event and reports were fairly isolated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust was measured on a Davis weather station on top of a shed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of the 15th a severe bow echo rolled through eastern KS causing wind damage. That evening a left over boundary allowed a supercell to form. This storm was long lived and produced large hail and severe winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 10th a supercell formed west of Lyon county. It then moved into the county and began to bow out causing severe wind gusts in the process. Slow storm motion and heavy rainfall lead to flash flooding in Lyon and Osage counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water running over hwy K-68 approximately 1.5 miles east of the US hwy 75 intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated the gusts, which blew a transformer and resulted in power outages north of Rose Hill.

Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.

In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sedgwick County Emergency Management relayed a report of quarter-sized hail occurring occurring at the Hydraulic/MacArthur intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread 2-3 inches of rain, with an isolated 4.5 inches measured In Kingman County, occurred across much of South-Central Kansas in the morning of the 30th. Flooding of highways resulted in parts of Sedgwick and Cowley Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Emergency manager reported water over the roads in and around the intersection of 132nd Road and 75th Road 2-3 miles north of Winfield.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two rounds of severe storms occurred during the afternoon and evening of April 8th, 2015. Storms first developed over Southern Kansas and quickly raced into Southeast Kansas during the afternoon. These storms produced 70 to 80 mph winds along with hail up to the size of golf balls. A second round of supercell thunderstorms eventually fired back to the west along a retreating dry line during the early evening over South Central Kansas and Northern Oklahoma. These storms produced several reports of  very large hail and eventually tracked into Kingman county where hail over 3 inches was reported which is larger than the size of baseballs. A brief tornado touchdown occurred southeast of Zenda, Kansas. ||Another supercell thunderstorm formed over eastern Kingman county. Rotating wall clouds were reported near the town of Cheney and a tornado touched down in extreme northwest Sedgwick County and tracked into Southeast Reno county.  The tornado was rated an EF0.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A rope to elephant trunk tornado was reported over open country north of Kingman. The tornado was 75 yards wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms produced a small tornado that hit Eudora.  The tornado tracked around 6.5 miles doing sporadic tree damage along its path. Some portions of the line produced severe wind gusts and caused damage. Heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in Jackson and Shawnee counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several 2 to 3 inch diameter tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening severe thunderstorms moved across Northwest Kansas.  A large tornado occurred in northern Logan county.  The largest hail reported was golf ball near Winona.  Late in the evening heavy rainfall caused flooding to occur south west of Atwood in the South Beaver river valley where water was estimated to be a foot deep over the road at the intersection of Road 15 and Road M.5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tornado moved ENE from just east of Winona and crossed to the south side of Highway 40.  The tornado then moved in a NNE direction, again crossing Highway 40 near Page City.  No tornado damage was reported by the emergency manager, but in Page City a large shed was damaged by downburst winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A modest dryline developed  across South Central and Central Kansas during the afternoon hours of May 6th, 2015.  Moderate instability and shear combined to produce supercell thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and Central Kansas. |The supercell thunderstorms produced some large hail, but also produced five  tornadoes across the area.  One of the tornadoes was rated an EF3, with another rated an EF2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple vortex tornado moved to the northeast across open country.  Minor damage was noted at one farmstead when a sheet metal roof was blown across the road (DI1 DOD2).  Otherwise, minor tree damage occurred sporadically along the path.  Several cedar trees were snapped in the cemetery on the east side of Lincoln. The tornado was 100 yards wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A modest dryline developed  across South Central and Central Kansas during the afternoon hours of May 6th, 2015.  Moderate instability and shear combined to produce supercell thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and Central Kansas. |The supercell thunderstorms produced some large hail, but also produced five  tornadoes across the area.  One of the tornadoes was rated an EF3, with another rated an EF2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was observed crossing 71st street south and quickly lifting. The tornado was 50 yards wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms produced a small tornado that hit Eudora.  The tornado tracked around 6.5 miles doing sporadic tree damage along its path. Some portions of the line produced severe wind gusts and caused damage. Heavy rainfall caused flash flooding in Jackson and Shawnee counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damage assessment survey found a path of sporadic tree damage extending approximately 6 miles along a line from Eudora to around 3 miles southwest of De Soto in Johnson County.  This tornado did cross from Douglas County Kansas which is NWS Topeka's area into Johnson County Kansas which is NWS Kansas City's service area.  EF1 tree damage was noted along the path.  Width of damage estimated 250 yards maximum while majority of tornado damage path was more narrow on order of 50 to 100 yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense thunderstorm developed over Cheyenne County in eastern Colorado and collapsed as it crossed into Kansas.  Winds estimated at 100 mph produced significant damage to a residence in far northwestern Greeley county as well as to a dairy farming operation further east. A dust storm accompanied the intense burst of winds with a wall of dirt and visibility to near zero reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two irrigation pivots were overturned, power lines blown down, dead trees uprooted and minor damage to two farm houses.  Time estimated from Doppler radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of freezing rain, sleet and snow fell across the county.  Up to 3 inches and a little less than 1/4 of an inch of ice were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail occurred for 7 minutes.

Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.

An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.

Daytime heating allowed the atmosphere to become marginally unstable.  The presence of a dry line help to ignite scattered thunderstorms, a few which became severe producing high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A powerpole was blown down by the wind.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A semi truck was blown over on highway 50 at this location.

Daytime heating allowed the atmosphere to become marginally unstable.  The presence of a dry line help to ignite scattered thunderstorms, a few which became severe producing high winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was from the Kansas State mesonet system.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level short wave trough approached the region and helped to produce a few thunderstorms.  The higher bases led to brief high wind gusts.

Numerous thunderstorms produced torrential rains across parts of South-Central Kansas for much of the afternoon and evening. Major flooding occurred. The most serious was that of a flash flood that occurred in Wichita. In parts of South and Southeast Wichita as well as West Wichita vehicles were submerged. Most of the parking lots at the Towne West Mall were flooded to depths around 3 feet. Rainfalls from 3-6 inches were widespread. Many streets were barricaded. Among them was Maple Avenue from I-235 to West Streets. The situation was exacerbated by heavy thunderstorms that produced torrential rains early in the morning. In fact, a staggering 5.60 inches was measured in Harper that morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Street flooding occurred in and around Haven.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The flooding occurred in the town of Harper that no doubt included most of the town's streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread 2-3 inches of rain, with an isolated 4.5 inches measured In Kingman County, occurred across much of South-Central Kansas in the morning of the 30th. Flooding of highways resulted in parts of Sedgwick and Cowley Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was reported over the roads of 183rd St. West between 71st and 79th Streets South as well as 55th Street South between 183rd and 199th Streets West.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter-sized hail was reported near Highway 54 and Munson Hill Road. The report was relayed by KWCH Channel 12.

A series of severe thunderstorms moved across central Kansas dropping a plethora of hail in many locations across Russell and Lincoln counties. The severe thunderstorms also unleashed damaging winds that reached 80 mph. Two tornadoes were reported with one being rated as an EF1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The roof was peeled off of the high school gymnasium (DI16 DOD5) and the press box at the football stadium was completely demolished. The tornado was 40 yards wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening severe thunderstorms moved across Northwest Kansas.  A large tornado occurred in northern Logan county.  The largest hail reported was golf ball near Winona.  Late in the evening heavy rainfall caused flooding to occur south west of Atwood in the South Beaver river valley where water was estimated to be a foot deep over the road at the intersection of Road 15 and Road M.5.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A brief satellite tornado was observed just northwest of a larger tornado. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense thunderstorm developed over Cheyenne County in eastern Colorado and collapsed as it crossed into Kansas.  Winds estimated at 100 mph produced significant damage to a residence in far northwestern Greeley county as well as to a dairy farming operation further east. A dust storm accompanied the intense burst of winds with a wall of dirt and visibility to near zero reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radio Station KFDI reported that cars were submerged at the Harry/Seneca intersection in Southeast Wichita.

A modest dryline developed  across South Central and Central Kansas during the afternoon hours of May 6th, 2015.  Moderate instability and shear combined to produce supercell thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and Central Kansas. |The supercell thunderstorms produced some large hail, but also produced five  tornadoes across the area.  One of the tornadoes was rated an EF3, with another rated an EF2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A very brief tornado was observed by an off duty weather service employee. The tornado width was 50 yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous thunderstorms produced torrential rains across parts of South-Central Kansas for much of the afternoon and evening. Major flooding occurred. The most serious was that of a flash flood that occurred in Wichita. In parts of South and Southeast Wichita as well as West Wichita vehicles were submerged. Most of the parking lots at the Towne West Mall were flooded to depths around 3 feet. Rainfalls from 3-6 inches were widespread. Many streets were barricaded. Among them was Maple Avenue from I-235 to West Streets. The situation was exacerbated by heavy thunderstorms that produced torrential rains early in the morning. In fact, a staggering 5.60 inches was measured in Harper that morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported flooding along a segment of Highway 44.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 65 MPH resulted in some shingles being blown off the roof of a local business and tree branches being downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Primarily between 4-8 p.m. CDT on this Sunday, several multicell thunderstorms rumbled across various portions of South Central Nebraska, but with the overall-greatest coverage focused within counties north of Interstate 80. While most of these storms produced nothing more than small hail and non-severe wind gusts, one flared up to severe levels over Sherman County mainly between 5:30-6:00 p.m. CDT, yielding a couple quarter size hail reports from the Loup City and Ashton areas. A few miles south of Ashton, one resident reported vinyl siding damage along with a destroyed garden. As the early evening hours wore on, this scattered convection steadily faded away with the loss of daytime heating. ||In the most basic sense, this largely diurnally-driven convection was sparked by a combination of strong surface heating and high instability near a weak, west-east oriented cold front sagging down from northern Nebraska, along with limited support aloft from a subtle disturbance embedded within broad northwesterly flow. Despite somewhat warm mid level temperatures, the combination of afternoon highs rising well into the 90s F and dewpoints averaging in the mid-60s to low-70s helped promote considerable instability with mixed-layer CAPE on the order of 2000-4000 J/kg. Storm organization was likely limited somewhat by only modest deep-layer wind shear generally on the order of 30-35 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The vinyl siding on the west side of the garage was damaged by the hail. The garden located at the home was destroyed and there was notable crop damage in the area.

Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.

A couple severe thunderstorms produced hail up to one inch in diameter on this Monday afternoon and evening, as well as a little wind damage. Scattered mostly single cell thunderstorms developed during the early to mid-afternoon hours, with a few small multicell clusters. These storms formed over the Sandhills and progressed southeastward through the late afternoon and evening hours, affecting portions of central and south central Nebraska. One of the storms that became severe moved out of western Polk County around 3:45 p.m. CST, and then dropped almost due south through York County. This storm blew an irrigation pivot over near Benedict and produced hail up to one inch in diameter just north of York.  One storm produced wind strong enough to snap off some 5 inch diameter tree limbs in Central City. As this storm continued southeastward, it produced hail up to the size of quarters in Henderson.||These storms developed along and head of a weak cold front which was sagging into Nebraska from the north. Northwest flow was established over the Plains, with a longwave ridge over the western United States, and a trough over the East. A subtropical high was situated over the Desert Southwest. Despite poor mid-level lapse rates, temperatures in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s, resulted in MLCAPE values of 2000-3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear increased from 25 kts, early in the event, to around 30 knots during its peak.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An area pivot was overturned.

A line of severe thunderstorms produced wind damage and minor flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust was estimated at the KOAM-TV studios.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of severe thunderstorms produced large hail over southeast Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was nickel to quarter size hail at the intersection of Highway 47 and Highway 3. Wind was estimated up to 40 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lone severe thunderstorm produced hail up to 2 inches in diameter, over Mitchell County, on this Sunday evening. A couple isolated thunderstorms formed over north central Kansas late this afternoon and into the early evening hours. These storms did not live long. The storm that produced the hail over Mitchell County formed over Osborne County just before 6 p.m. CST. It intensified as it crossed into western Mitchell County. The severe hail fell just south of Waconda Lake. The storm rapidly weakened, over the eastern part of the county, between 7 and 7:30 p.m. CST.||These storms formed near a long surface trough that extended from South Dakota through central Kansas to the Texas Panhandle. This trough separated maritime tropical air to the east, and continental tropical air to the west. Dewpoints ahead of it were in the lower to middle 70s, while they were in the 50s to lower 60s to the west. Aloft, subtropical high pressure was over Texas with a ridge extending north into the Central Plains. Troughs were along both the East and West Coasts. The lack of synoptic forcing was the reason for the paucity of thunderstorms. MLCAPE was near 3,000 J/kg and deep layer shear was around 45 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranged from half dollar to hen egg in size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in some tree damage and a flag pole being snapped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This Sunday afternoon and evening featured a rather localized-but-significant flooding event within primarily central and northeast portions of Furnas County, including the community of Edison, which was ground zero for flooding rains and also a brief bout of severe wind gusts estimated up to 65 MPH, along with hail up to quarter size. According to a trained spotter two miles southwest of Edison, an unofficial rain total of 5 inches poured down in a 90-minute span between 3:30-5:00 p.m. CDT, washing out part of a driveway. In Edison itself, the NWS cooperative observer recorded a slightly lower storm total of 3.74, but this was still more than enough rain in a short time to cause significant flooding of several roads and some structures. Some of the worst damage occurred at Ag Valley Coop, where a shallow depth of water infiltrated much of the first floor office. Even after the last drops of lingering light rain vacated Edison around 9 p.m. CDT, impactful flooding persisted well into the morning hours of the 17th. Although the Furnas County flooding situation was the big story from this event, radar data suggested that other pockets of flooding might have also occurred in portions of eastern Gosper and western Phelps counties, where rain totals of at least 2-3 were also fairly common. ||For the vast majority of the 16th, all the way from the pre-dawn hours through midnight, at least isolated to scattered showers and mainly weak thunderstorms affected at least some portion of South Central Nebraska, primarily within counties northwest of line from Franklin to York. While most of this convection was fairly disorganized and weak, the mid-afternoon through early evening hours featured a noticeable uptick in storm coverage and intensity, especially in southwestern counties such as Furnas, Gosper, and Phelps. Within this area, an initially weak cluster of convection rapidly intensified between 3-6 p.m. CDT, morphing into a nearly solid, southward-sinking line of slow-moving strong to severe storms. The primary synoptic scale trigger for this event was a very slow-moving, southwest-to-northeast oriented surface cold front roughly bisecting Nebraska during the afternoon and evening. Considerable moisture pooled in the vicinity of this boundary, featuring surface dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70s F and precipitable water values averaging 1.50-2.00. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was rather subtle and weak, with southern Nebraska positioned well-south of a primary shortwave trough shifting from the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Around the time of the most intense Furnas County convection, mesoscale parameters featured at least 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE, but weak deep-layer wind shear only around 25 knots, helping promote slow storm motions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 to 65 mph were reported both from law enforcement two miles north of Edison, and also a trained spotter in Edison.

Even after the last drops of lingering light rain vacated Edison around 9 p.m. CDT, impactful flooding persisted well into the morning hours of the 17th. Although the Furnas County flooding situation was the big story from this event, radar data suggested that other pockets of flooding might have also occurred in portions of eastern Gosper and western Phelps counties, where rain totals of at least 2-3 were also fairly common. ||For the vast majority of the 16th, all the way from the pre-dawn hours through midnight, at least isolated to scattered showers and mainly weak thunderstorms affected at least some portion of South Central Nebraska, primarily within counties northwest of line from Franklin to York. While most of this convection was fairly disorganized and weak, the mid-afternoon through early evening hours featured a noticeable uptick in storm coverage and intensity, especially in southwestern counties such as Furnas, Gosper, and Phelps. Within this area, an initially weak cluster of convection rapidly intensified between 3-6 p.m. CDT, morphing into a nearly solid, southward-sinking line of slow-moving strong to severe storms. The primary synoptic scale trigger for this event was a very slow-moving, southwest-to-northeast oriented surface cold front roughly bisecting Nebraska during the afternoon and evening. Considerable moisture pooled in the vicinity of this boundary, featuring surface dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70s F and precipitable water values averaging 1.50-2.00. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was rather subtle and weak, with southern Nebraska positioned well-south of a primary shortwave trough shifting from the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Around the time of the most intense Furnas County convection, mesoscale parameters featured at least 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE, but weak deep-layer wind shear only around 25 knots, helping promote slow storm motions.

This Sunday afternoon and evening featured a rather localized-but-significant flooding event within primarily central and northeast portions of Furnas County, including the community of Edison, which was ground zero for flooding rains and also a brief bout of severe wind gusts estimated up to 65 MPH, along with hail up to quarter size. According to a trained spotter two miles southwest of Edison, an unofficial rain total of 5 inches poured down in a 90-minute span between 3:30-5:00 p.m. CDT, washing out part of a driveway. In Edison itself, the NWS cooperative observer recorded a slightly lower storm total of 3.74, but this was still more than enough rain in a short time to cause significant flooding of several roads and some structures. Some of the worst damage occurred at Ag Valley Coop, where a shallow depth of water infiltrated much of the first floor office. Even after the last drops of lingering light rain vacated Edison around 9 p.m. CDT, impactful flooding persisted well into the morning hours of the 17th. Although the Furnas County flooding situation was the big story from this event, radar data suggested that other pockets of flooding might have also occurred in portions of eastern Gosper and western Phelps counties, where rain totals of at least 2-3 were also fairly common. ||For the vast majority of the 16th, all the way from the pre-dawn hours through midnight, at least isolated to scattered showers and mainly weak thunderstorms affected at least some portion of South Central Nebraska, primarily within counties northwest of line from Franklin to York. While most of this convection was fairly disorganized and weak, the mid-afternoon through early evening hours featured a noticeable uptick in storm coverage and intensity, especially in southwestern counties such as Furnas, Gosper, and Phelps. Within this area, an initially weak cluster of convection rapidly intensified between 3-6 p.m. CDT, morphing into a nearly solid, southward-sinking line of slow-moving strong to severe storms. The primary synoptic scale trigger for this event was a very slow-moving, southwest-to-northeast oriented surface cold front roughly bisecting Nebraska during the afternoon and evening. Considerable moisture pooled in the vicinity of this boundary, featuring surface dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70s F and precipitable water values averaging 1.50-2.00. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was rather subtle and weak, with southern Nebraska positioned well-south of a primary shortwave trough shifting from the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Around the time of the most intense Furnas County convection, mesoscale parameters featured at least 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE, but weak deep-layer wind shear only around 25 knots, helping promote slow storm motions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isolated flooding continued across parts of eastern Furnas County through the night, especially in the Edison area. The NWS cooperative observer in Edison reported a 24-hour rainfall total of 3.74, most of which fell between 3-5 p.m. CDT on the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple severe thunderstorms produced hail up to one inch in diameter on this Monday afternoon and evening, as well as a little wind damage. Scattered mostly single cell thunderstorms developed during the early to mid-afternoon hours, with a few small multicell clusters. These storms formed over the Sandhills and progressed southeastward through the late afternoon and evening hours, affecting portions of central and south central Nebraska. One of the storms that became severe moved out of western Polk County around 3:45 p.m. CST, and then dropped almost due south through York County. This storm blew an irrigation pivot over near Benedict and produced hail up to one inch in diameter just north of York.  One storm produced wind strong enough to snap off some 5 inch diameter tree limbs in Central City. As this storm continued southeastward, it produced hail up to the size of quarters in Henderson.||These storms developed along and head of a weak cold front which was sagging into Nebraska from the north. Northwest flow was established over the Plains, with a longwave ridge over the western United States, and a trough over the East. A subtropical high was situated over the Desert Southwest. Despite poor mid-level lapse rates, temperatures in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s, resulted in MLCAPE values of 2000-3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear increased from 25 kts, early in the event, to around 30 knots during its peak.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated near 60 MPH knocked down tree limbs up to 5 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front sagged southward through western Iowa and eastern Nebraska during the day on August 2nd. Ahead of the front during the early morning hours the nocturnal low-level jet increased ahead of the front. This allowed for isolated thunderstorms to develop in northeast Nebraska and move into west central Iowa during the early morning hours. Some of these thunderstorms reached severe limits with large hail the main threats. These thunderstorms dissipated in the morning hours, but as the instability increased during the afternoon thunderstorms redeveloped along the cold front. Vertical wind shear also increased during the afternoon as well with some of the thunderstorms becoming supercells producing large hail and damaging winds. The thunderstorms weakened by mid to late evening.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three sections of the center pivot were overturned in a field.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A seasonably strong jet stream was moving across the northern Plains during the day on the 8th of August. During the late afternoon and evening a warm front lifted north into southeast Nebraska as low pressure associated with the jet streak moved into eastern Nebraska. Thunderstorms developed by mid evening along the warm front producing an isolated tornado and locally heavy rainfall across southeast Nebraska and into southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado developed in the extreme northeast part of Pawnee County from a supercell moving southeast. The tornado only occurred for a short distance in Pawnee County before moving into Richardson County. Little damage occurred in in Pawnee County but the tornado was given an EF1 rating based on how extensive the crop damage was from the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms roamed through primarily the western half of South Central Nebraska (west of the Highway 281 corridor) during the morning and early afternoon hours on this Thursday. Although the majority of storms produced no more than small hail and brief downpours, one organized, elevated supercell became marginally severe as it tracked east-southeast across portions of Furnas and Harlan counties between 9:00-11:30 a.m. CDT before departing southward into Kansas. Actually, this storm first developed just west of the local area over the Frontier/Red Willow County line. Ground-truth reports were limited, but nickel size hail was reported southeast of Cambridge and quarter size hail near the state line south of Alma. In Beaver City, only pea size hail was reported, but the NWS cooperative observer tallied 1.77 inches of rain in 40 minutes. In the wake of this supercell, a few additional strong storms flared up within the area into early afternoon, but all of South Central Nebraska was pretty much storm-free by 2 p.m. CDT. ||The development of this isolated severe storm was fairly unexpected, given rather weak forcing aloft and also warm mid level temperatures. However, in the mid-upper levels, the broad quasi-zonal flow in place over Nebraska did in fact feature a subtle disturbance moving in from the west, along the southern periphery of a better-defined, low amplitude shortwave trough tracking out of the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Despite temperatures at the 700-millibar level averaging at least 12-14 C, this rogue severe storm thrived in a mesoscale environment featuring most-unstable CAPE around 2000 J/kg and seasonably strong deep-layer wind shear of 40-50 knots.

A severe thunderstorm produced damaging winds across portions of Mitchell County on this Wednesday evening. This thunderstorm entered southwestern Mitchell County, from Russell county, around 7 p.m. CST, and tracked from southwest to northeast across the county between 7 and 8 p.m. As this storm passed through the Beloit area, winds measured as high as 78 mph snapped multiple power poles and large tree branches. Power outages lasted as much as 12 hours. A portion of the tin roof was also blown off from an auto parts store. ||This storm formed near cold front that moved into northern Kansas, the previous night, and became stationary. In the upper levels, a subtropical high was over Texas, with a ridge extending north to Minnesota. Troughs were along the East Coast and over the western United States. A shortwave trough was embedded, in the western trough, from Montana south to Utah. Surface temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s and lower 70s. Mid-level lapse rates were low, resulting in MLCAPE between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 30-35 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports of estimated wind gusts of 60 to 70 MPH, while a gust of 70 MPH measured by a mesonet site west-southwest of Beloit and a gust of 78 MPH measured by the Beloit Airport AWOS. Damage was reported in the Beloit area, including in town where a metal roof was blown off an auto dealer on the north side of town. Numerous trees suffered damage, with a few larger limbs falling on vehicles. A number of power poles were also downed, causing power outages in the Beloit and Glen Elder areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced hail up to the size of golf balls in a few locations on this Tuesday afternoon. Just after 2 p.m. CST, an isolated thunderstorm developed along the Buffalo-Sherman County line. This storm advanced slowly to the east and weakened by 3:30 p.m. By 2:45 p.m., another storm joined it over northern Sherman County. This storm moved north into Valley County by 3:30 p.m. and exited the county by 5 p.m. Both of these storms produced hail up to the size of golf balls. The second storm produced golf ball size hail near Arcadia and near Fort Hartsuff State Park. ||These storms formed well ahead of a backdoor cold front that was pressing into northeastern Nebraska. However, convective initiation was more likely a result of a small area of low-level convergence between Broken Bow, where winds were from the west, and Ord, where winds were from the east. In the upper levels, a subtropical high was over Oklahoma, with a ridge extending north through the Dakotas. Troughs were located over the western and eastern United States. At mid-afternoon, surface temperatures were in the middle 90s, with dewpoints in the middle to upper 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 7 deg C/km, MLCAPE was around 2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was near 25 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranged from quarter to golf ball size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A seasonably strong jet stream was moving across the northern Plains during the day on the 8th of August. During the late afternoon and evening a warm front lifted north into southeast Nebraska as low pressure associated with the jet streak moved into eastern Nebraska. Thunderstorms developed by mid evening along the warm front producing an isolated tornado and locally heavy rainfall across southeast Nebraska and into southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm survey found tree damage consistent with straight line winds in this area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A seasonably strong jet stream was moving across the northern Plains during the day on the 8th of August. During the late afternoon and evening a warm front lifted north into southeast Nebraska as low pressure associated with the jet streak moved into eastern Nebraska. Thunderstorms developed by mid evening along the warm front producing an isolated tornado and locally heavy rainfall across southeast Nebraska and into southwest Iowa.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado continued into Richardson County from Pawnee County. The tornado continue to produce little damage in Richardson County as there were little structures for the tornado to impact. Some tree damage was noted along the path in Richardson County as well as continued crop damage. As the tornado dissipated it made a loop near 632nd Ave and move southwest for a short time before finally dissipating.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moving quickly through the northern Plains allowed for a seasonably strong cold front to sweep through eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa late in the day on the 9th of August. Isolated to scattered supercells developed along the cold front as it moved southeast across the area with some of the supercells producing severe weather in the form of large hail and damaging winds, as well as locally heavy rainfall.

Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in some tree limbs approximately 3 inches in diameter being downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unseasonably strong upper level storm system moved across the northern Plains during the day on August 22nd. This system allowed for a strong cold front to sweep across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the late afternoon and evening. Scattered to numerous thunderstorms developed along the cold front from west central Iowa into eastern Nebraska, and moved southeast through the evening. Although the large majority of these storms were sub-severe, isolated reports of large hail and damaging winds were received.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports in town indicated hail ranged from quarter to golf ball size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving upper level storm system crossed Nebraska during the day on August 28th and into the state of Iowa on the 29th. Seasonably deep moisture combined with the slow moving storm system to produce intense rainfall over parts of northeast Nebraska. Some rainfall amounts ranged from 6 to 8 inches during the evening. The rainfall slowly diminished after midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement, as well as local print media, indicated that flash flooding occurred from heavy repeated thunderstorms across parts of Antelope County. The worst of the flooding was near the areas of Oakdale and Elgin. The flooding led to water covering U.S. Highway 275 and State Highway 70 into the morning on the 29th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the evening a line of severe storms moved into Southwest Nebraska from Northwest Kansas.  The highest wind speeds were along the leading edge of the squall line.  The highest wind gust reported was 100 MPH at Stratton.  Large hail was also reported as the squall line moved through, with the golf ball size hail near Stratton being the largest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high wind gust snapped the top of an 80 foot tree off, with the top of the tree flying over a nearby house.  The wind also flipped a swing set.  The house shook because the winds were so strong.  Elsewhere around town there was widespread, major tree damage.  Twelve to eighteen inch diameter trees were snapped and uprooted.  Power poles were damaged which lead to power outages in town and the surrounding area.  In town one garage and one unanchored mobile home were destroyed.  There were many roofs damaged as well as siding on houses.  A camper was overturned, damaged and resulted in one (direct) fatality.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in tree damage and power outages in Aurora.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was a rather active Friday night into early Saturday morning for this six-county North Central Kansas area, featuring several hours of widespread strong to marginally severe thunderstorm activity, but ultimately yielding only a few ground truth severe-criteria wind reports. Both of these measured gusts occurred in Smith County between 11:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. CDT as the southern portion of a north-to-south oriented squall line charged through, including a 62 MPH gust at the Smith Center airport and a 72 MPH reading at a mesonet site south of Lebanon. Despite the lack of additional ground-truth, radar data suggested that at least marginally-severe winds likely affected other counties as well. Rainfall-wise, most areas near and north of the Highway 24 corridor tallied 0.75-1.50, with the greatest concentration of higher 1.50-2.25 totals focused within central and eastern Jewell County, including 2.25 at Formoso (CoCoRaHS). There were no reports of flooding. ||Timing-wise, North Central Kansas made it through nightfall storm-free. However, a pair of expanding severe storm clusters gradually took aim on the local area as they approached from southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas, eventually merging into an organized mesoscale convective system (MCS), the southern end of which surged into Phillips and Rooks counties between 10:30-11:30 p.m. CDT. During the midnight to 2 a.m. CDT time frame, this initial squall line reached Jewell and Mitchell counties before departing the local area into northeast Kansas. Meanwhile, additional strong storms redeveloped farther west and continued streaming eastward across the area through around 4 a.m. CDT, followed by only scattered, lighter shower activity which lingered through around sunrise. In the mid/upper levels, this event featured slightly-stronger-than-average forcing by early August standards, as a well-defined lead disturbance moved out of the Central Rockies into the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow aloft, downstream from a larger scale parent trough centered over Nevada. By the time the MCS tracked into the local area, convection was being sustained/enhanced by a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet evident at 850 millibars. At the surface, North Central Kansas featured an east-southeast flow regime, to the north of a quasi-stationary front loosely draped across the southern half of Kansas. Around the time of the severe wind reports, mesoscale parameters featured around 2000 J/kg most unstable CAPE, deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots and strong 0-1 kilometer low level shear, also of 30-40 knots.

Both of these measured gusts occurred in Smith County between 11:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. CDT as the southern portion of a north-to-south oriented squall line charged through, including a 62 MPH gust at the Smith Center airport and a 72 MPH reading at a mesonet site south of Lebanon. There were no reports of flooding. ||Timing-wise, North Central Kansas made it through nightfall storm-free. However, a pair of expanding severe storm clusters gradually took aim on the local area as they approached from southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas, eventually merging into an organized mesoscale convective system (MCS), the southern end of which surged into Phillips and Rooks counties between 10:30-11:30 p.m. CDT. In the mid/upper levels, this event featured slightly-stronger-than-average forcing by early August standards, as a well-defined lead disturbance moved out of the Central Rockies into the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow aloft, downstream from a larger scale parent trough centered over Nevada. By the time the MCS tracked into the local area, convection was being sustained/enhanced by a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet evident at 850 millibars.
