Around the time of the severe wind reports, mesoscale parameters featured around 2000 J/kg most unstable CAPE, deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots and strong 0-1 kilometer low level shear, also of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gust was measured by a Kansas Department of Transportation mesonet site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was a rather active weather night for South Central Nebraska, highlighted by a handful of severe-criteria wind reports within counties along and south of Interstate 80. Although widespread precipitation affected the area for several hours on this Friday night into early Saturday morning, all severe wind reports occurred between 11:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. CDT as a north-to-south oriented bowing segment charged through. Along and near the leading edge of the surging outflow, wind gusts around 60 MPH were reported near Gibbon, in rural southeastern Adams and southwestern Clay counties, and also near Superior. Well-behind this bowing line, severe gusts associated with a well-defined mesoscale convective vortex (MCV) brought down numerous tree limbs in Cozad. Although there were no confirmed tornadoes, the presence of seasonably-strong low level shear aided the development of a few brief, radar-indicated rotational signatures, one of which prompted a short-fused Tornado Warning for southern Adams County. Rainfall-wise, though many areas roughly southwest of a Ravenna-Hastings-Hebron line picked up 1-2, the fairly progressive nature of the heaviest cores held flooding issues to a minimum, save for typical short-term street flooding in communities such as Elm Creek. ||Timing-wise, most of South Central Nebraska remained rain-free until after dark, save for a narrow band of weak convection that lifted through several northern and eastern counties during the early evening. However, a pair of expanding severe storm clusters gradually took aim on the local area as they approached from southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas, eventually merging into an organized mesoscale convective system (MCS) that surged into western portions of South Central Nebraska between 10-11 p.m. CDT. By the midnight to 1 a.m. CDT time frame, the primary bowing segment raced through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 before departing into southeast Nebraska and northeast Kansas. In its wake, a large shield of light to moderate rain persisted across the local area for most of the night. In the mid/upper levels, this event featured slightly-stronger-than-average forcing by early August standards, as a well-defined lead disturbance moved out of the Central Rockies into the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow aloft, downstream from a larger scale parent trough centered over Nevada. By the time the MCS entered the local area, convection was being sustained/enhanced by a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet evident at 850 millibars. At the surface, South Central Nebraska featured a light easterly flow regime, to the north of a quasi-stationary front loosely draped across the southern half of Kansas. Around the time of the severe wind reports, mesoscale parameters featured 1000-2000 J/kg most unstable CAPE, deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots and rather strong 0-1 kilometer low level shear of 20-30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH at campground area near Interstate 80 exit 285.

By the midnight to 1 a.m. CDT time frame, the primary bowing segment raced through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 before departing into southeast Nebraska and northeast Kansas. In its wake, a large shield of light to moderate rain persisted across the local area for most of the night. In the mid/upper levels, this event featured slightly-stronger-than-average forcing by early August standards, as a well-defined lead disturbance moved out of the Central Rockies into the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow aloft, downstream from a larger scale parent trough centered over Nevada. By the time the MCS entered the local area, convection was being sustained/enhanced by a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet evident at 850 millibars. At the surface, South Central Nebraska featured a light easterly flow regime, to the north of a quasi-stationary front loosely draped across the southern half of Kansas. Around the time of the severe wind reports, mesoscale parameters featured 1000-2000 J/kg most unstable CAPE, deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots and rather strong 0-1 kilometer low level shear of 20-30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH, and were likely associated with a mesoscale convective vortex (MCV). The NWS coop observer in town reported small to medium tree limbs down across town.

Ground-truth reports were limited, but nickel size hail was reported southeast of Cambridge and quarter size hail near the state line south of Alma. In Beaver City, only pea size hail was reported, but the NWS cooperative observer tallied 1.77 inches of rain in 40 minutes. In the wake of this supercell, a few additional strong storms flared up within the area into early afternoon, but all of South Central Nebraska was pretty much storm-free by 2 p.m. CDT. ||The development of this isolated severe storm was fairly unexpected, given rather weak forcing aloft and also warm mid level temperatures. However, in the mid-upper levels, the broad quasi-zonal flow in place over Nebraska did in fact feature a subtle disturbance moving in from the west, along the southern periphery of a better-defined, low amplitude shortwave trough tracking out of the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Despite temperatures at the 700-millibar level averaging at least 12-14 C, this rogue severe storm thrived in a mesoscale environment featuring most-unstable CAPE around 2000 J/kg and seasonably strong deep-layer wind shear of 40-50 knots.

Between 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. CDT on this Thursday, an isolated, elevated supercell storm dropped east-southeast out of Nebraska and across primarily northern and eastern Phillips County along with parts of Smith County, before rapidly weakening. Along the way, there were a handful of severe-criteria hail reports, including stones up to golf ball size near Agra and quarter size in Kensington. As the storm began to weaken, penny size hail fell southeast of Smith Center. In the wake of this supercell, a few additional strong storms brushed across far northern Smith and Jewell counties during the early afternoon, but all of this six-county North Central Kansas area was pretty much storm-free by 3 p.m. CDT. ||The development of this isolated severe storm was fairly unexpected, given rather weak forcing aloft and also warm mid level temperatures. However, in the mid-upper levels, the broad quasi-zonal flow in place over northern Kansas did in fact feature a subtle disturbance moving in from the west, along the southern periphery of a better-defined, low amplitude shortwave trough tracking out of the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Despite temperatures at the 700-millibar level averaging at least 12-14 C, this rogue severe storm thrived in a mesoscale environment featuring most-unstable CAPE around 2000 J/kg and seasonably strong deep-layer wind shear of 40-50 knots.

Quarter size hail was reported in two locations on this Saturday evening. Late in the afternoon, scattered thunderstorms developed between Ord and McCook. The storms were brief and quickly dissipated along and south of Interstate 80. To the north of the Interstate, instability was greater. The storms continued and strengthened, with a couple briefly turning severe, producing hail up to 1 inch in diameter near Greeley and Clarks. ||These storms formed within a broad warm sector, ahead of the lee-side trough that became mobile and advanced east into the central third of Nebraska. There was no discernible forcing aloft as the flow was zonal, and the subtropical and polar jet streams were far to the south and north, respectively. Surface dewpoint depressions were large, with temperatures in the mid 80s and dewpoints in the upper 40s. However, mid-level lapse rates were around 7.5 deg C/km, resulting in MLCAPE of 1000-1250 J/kg north of I-80. Deep layer shear was 35-40 knots.

Two separate thunderstorm events produced a little severe weather and flash flooding on this Friday. The first episode was associated with a couple supercells that formed near McCook, Nebraska the prior evening. These storms evolved into a small multicell cluster that was joined by a few other storms as it moved southeast across north-central Kansas between midnight at 3 a.m. CST. This small cluster was mostly sub-severe, producing penny size hail and measured winds of 50-55 mph in a few spots. However, it did produce a severe wind gust of 61 mph in Logan. Later in the day, between 5 and 6 pm CST, several thunderstorms formed over Rooks, Phillips, and Smith Counties. They quickly congealed into a multicell cluster. This cluster remained quasi-stationary between 5:30 and 8:30 p.m., with the most persistent heavy rain over southeastern Phillips and northeastern Rooks Counties. Three to six inches of rain were measured in this short time span and this resulted in flash flooding, with numerous gravel roads under water and some washed out in spots. One of these storms did produce hail to the size of quarters in Stockton, which is in Rooks County.||The overnight storms occurred near a dissipating frontal boundary, with no forcing aloft. The late afternoon and evening storms formed along a weak cold front that had dropped through Nebraska, during the day, and was slowing its forward progress over north central Kansas. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall fell across the area, with the highest totals near 6 inches. This rain resulted in numerous roads with water running over them. Some of the gravel roads had enough water running over them to wash away the rock covering.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A shortwave trough moving quickly through the northern Plains allowed for a seasonably strong cold front to sweep through eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa late in the day on the 9th of August. Isolated to scattered supercells developed along the cold front as it moved southeast across the area with some of the supercells producing severe weather in the form of large hail and damaging winds, as well as locally heavy rainfall.

This was a rather active weather night for South Central Nebraska, highlighted by a handful of severe-criteria wind reports within counties along and south of Interstate 80. Although widespread precipitation affected the area for several hours on this Friday night into early Saturday morning, all severe wind reports occurred between 11:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. CDT as a north-to-south oriented bowing segment charged through. Along and near the leading edge of the surging outflow, wind gusts around 60 MPH were reported near Gibbon, in rural southeastern Adams and southwestern Clay counties, and also near Superior. Well-behind this bowing line, severe gusts associated with a well-defined mesoscale convective vortex (MCV) brought down numerous tree limbs in Cozad. Although there were no confirmed tornadoes, the presence of seasonably-strong low level shear aided the development of a few brief, radar-indicated rotational signatures, one of which prompted a short-fused Tornado Warning for southern Adams County. Rainfall-wise, though many areas roughly southwest of a Ravenna-Hastings-Hebron line picked up 1-2, the fairly progressive nature of the heaviest cores held flooding issues to a minimum, save for typical short-term street flooding in communities such as Elm Creek. ||Timing-wise, most of South Central Nebraska remained rain-free until after dark, save for a narrow band of weak convection that lifted through several northern and eastern counties during the early evening. However, a pair of expanding severe storm clusters gradually took aim on the local area as they approached from southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas, eventually merging into an organized mesoscale convective system (MCS) that surged into western portions of South Central Nebraska between 10-11 p.m. CDT. By the midnight to 1 a.m. CDT time frame, the primary bowing segment raced through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 before departing into southeast Nebraska and northeast Kansas. In its wake, a large shield of light to moderate rain persisted across the local area for most of the night. In the mid/upper levels, this event featured slightly-stronger-than-average forcing by early August standards, as a well-defined lead disturbance moved out of the Central Rockies into the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow aloft, downstream from a larger scale parent trough centered over Nevada. By the time the MCS entered the local area, convection was being sustained/enhanced by a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet evident at 850 millibars. At the surface, South Central Nebraska featured a light easterly flow regime, to the north of a quasi-stationary front loosely draped across the southern half of Kansas. Around the time of the severe wind reports, mesoscale parameters featured 1000-2000 J/kg most unstable CAPE, deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots and rather strong 0-1 kilometer low level shear of 20-30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH by an off-duty NWS employee.

On the morning of the 22nd, a couple severe thunderstorms visited Sedgwick and Sumner counties where quarter to golfball-sized hail occurred.  Later that afternoon and evening, more storms moved across the central sections of the state producing hail and wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to quarter-sized hail was reported to have occurred for the past few minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of the 22nd, a couple severe thunderstorms visited Sedgwick and Sumner counties where quarter to golfball-sized hail occurred.  Later that afternoon and evening, more storms moved across the central sections of the state producing hail and wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter reported the golf ball sized hail occurred along with hail of various other sizes that eventually covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.

During an 18-hour stretch between noon CDT on Tuesday the 4th and 6 a.m. on Wednesday the 5th, two fairly distinct rounds of widespread thunderstorm activity soaked much (but not all) of this six county North Central Kansas area with 1-4 inches of rain, and localized pockets as high as 6-8. Not surprisingly, short term flooding of rural roads and fields ensued within the zones of highest rainfall, along with minor flooding along the South Fork Solomon River in southern Smith and northeastern Osborne counties. Although a few storms exhibited radar signatures indicative of marginally severe hail and/or wind, there were no confirming ground truth reports. As a result, flooding concerns took center stage in an environment characterized by precipitable water values averaging 1.50-2.00.  The primary swath of 2-4 amounts (and locally higher) was roughly 10-20 miles wide and oriented northwest-to-southeast through most of Smith and Mitchell counties, along with adjacent portions of northern Osborne, southwestern Jewell and far southeastern Phillips counties. Within this broader zone of highest totals, there were mainly three smaller-scale maximums of at least 4-6. The largest of these zones included much of the northern half of Smith County, and particularly the northwest quadrant, where radar estimated a small zone of (unverified) 6-8 amounts. The majority of rain within Smith County fell during the overnight hours, and the highest-known ground truth report was 4.02 from the NWS coop observer in Lebanon. There were at least a few rural roads washed out within the county. The second zone of enhanced rainfall was a small, roughly 5x5 mile section of southeast Mitchell County, featuring a CoCoRaHS total of 6.15 six miles northwest of Barnard. However, rain here did not fall all at once, and was a combination of both afternoon and late-night activity. The third area of primary interest was a tiny, likely no more than 4x4 mile portion of extreme southeastern Phillips County south of Kirwin, where an unofficial total of 5 accumulated in 2-3 hours during the afternoon, resulting in water over numerous rural roads. Given that Smith County bore the brunt of excessive rainfall, much of the runoff steadily worked its way into the North Fork Solomon River upstream of Waconda Lake. At the automated gauge near Portis, the river breached minor flood stage of 15.0 ft. on the morning of the 5th and crested at 16.9 ft. on the morning of the 6th, before slipping below flood late that afternoon. In sharp contrast to the aforementioned pockets of heaviest rain within the six-county area, the majority of Rooks County along with central portions of Phillips and Osborne counties received well under 1, if hardly any at all.  ||Focusing on timing of this multi-part heavy rain event, round 1 was centered between 1-8 p.m. CDT on the 4th as various clusters of multicell convection traversed the area, largely tied to convergence along a quasi-stationary surface front stretched across the heart of northern Kansas. During this time, the only notable flooding was the localized deluge south of Kirwin. Following a relative minimum in storm activity for a few hours, round 2 got underway around 11 p.m. CDT and persisted through the remainder of the night before vacating local counties shortly before sunrise. This round, which featured repeated development of storms within a northwest-to-southeast axis centered through Smith and Mitchell counties, was largely driven by classic warm air advection/moisture transport along the nose of a modest 25-30 knot low level jet evident at 850 millibars. In the larger scale scene of the mid/upper levels, this entire heavy rain event was instigated by a slow-moving, elongated shortwave trough gradually sinking from northwest-to-southeast through the Central Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The NWS cooperative observer in Ionia received a 24-hour rainfall amount of 3.20.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced hail up to the size of golf balls in a few locations on this Tuesday afternoon. Just after 2 p.m. CST, an isolated thunderstorm developed along the Buffalo-Sherman County line. This storm advanced slowly to the east and weakened by 3:30 p.m. By 2:45 p.m., another storm joined it over northern Sherman County. This storm moved north into Valley County by 3:30 p.m. and exited the county by 5 p.m. Both of these storms produced hail up to the size of golf balls. The second storm produced golf ball size hail near Arcadia and near Fort Hartsuff State Park. ||These storms formed well ahead of a backdoor cold front that was pressing into northeastern Nebraska. However, convective initiation was more likely a result of a small area of low-level convergence between Broken Bow, where winds were from the west, and Ord, where winds were from the east. In the upper levels, a subtropical high was over Oklahoma, with a ridge extending north through the Dakotas. Troughs were located over the western and eastern United States. At mid-afternoon, surface temperatures were in the middle 90s, with dewpoints in the middle to upper 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 7 deg C/km, MLCAPE was around 2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was near 25 knots.

Between 4-9 p.m. CDT on this Sunday afternoon and evening, a smattering of strong to severe thunderstorms developed along and just ahead of an invading cold front, producing hail in various parts of South Central Nebraska, but especially within Polk, Nance and northeast Merrick counties in far northeast portions of the local area. Within these counties, the main event occurred between 430-630 p.m. CDT as a cluster of semi-discrete severe storms blossomed slightly ahead of the cold front and tracked east-northeast before exiting into eastern Nebraska. Polk County yielded the most hail reports, with nickel to quarter size stones reported in the Osceola and Shelby areas, and larger golf ball size stones reported in western and far northeast sections of the county. In fact, a NeRAIN observer located a few miles south-southwest of Columbus reported broken windows and roof damage in the area. Outside of this main, concentrated zone of severe storms, a combination of linear and small multicell storm structures yielded a few instances of sub-severe hail in the Ord, Red Cloud and Hubbell areas, and a lone quarter size report in Clay Center. By 9 p.m. CDT, the surface cold front had pushed through all of South Central Nebraska, ending all local thunderstorm activity for the night as convection exited Fillmore and Thayer counties to the east. Rainfall-wise, the vast majority of affected areas received well under 1. ||In the mid-upper levels, forcing was provided by the southern reaches of a broad shortwave trough tracking east across the Central and especially Northern Plains, with this trough ushering in increasing west-southwest flow aloft. At the surface, the well-defined, northeast-southwest oriented cold front steadily swept through South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening. Ahead of the boundary, afternoon temperatures across most of the local area topped out between 75-80 F as dewpoints rose to between 50-55 F on gusty south winds. By the time storms initiated, the combination of mixed-layer CAPE values on the order of 1000 J/kg and 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-50 knots was plenty sufficient for large hail production.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea sized hail covered the ground, with some quarter sized hail mixed in.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of the 22nd, a couple severe thunderstorms visited Sedgwick and Sumner counties where quarter to golfball-sized hail occurred.  Later that afternoon and evening, more storms moved across the central sections of the state producing hail and wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The quarter-sized hail was reported, via face book, on the west of side of Valley Center. The time of occurrence is estimated from radar.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pea sized hail was also reported with the strong winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail fell on the north side of town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail stones were completely covering the ground.  Sixty five mph winds were also reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust was reported by local law enforcement.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced hail up to the size of golf balls in a few locations on this Tuesday afternoon. Just after 2 p.m. CST, an isolated thunderstorm developed along the Buffalo-Sherman County line. This storm advanced slowly to the east and weakened by 3:30 p.m. By 2:45 p.m., another storm joined it over northern Sherman County. This storm moved north into Valley County by 3:30 p.m. and exited the county by 5 p.m. Both of these storms produced hail up to the size of golf balls. The second storm produced golf ball size hail near Arcadia and near Fort Hartsuff State Park. ||These storms formed well ahead of a backdoor cold front that was pressing into northeastern Nebraska. However, convective initiation was more likely a result of a small area of low-level convergence between Broken Bow, where winds were from the west, and Ord, where winds were from the east. In the upper levels, a subtropical high was over Oklahoma, with a ridge extending north through the Dakotas. Troughs were located over the western and eastern United States. At mid-afternoon, surface temperatures were in the middle 90s, with dewpoints in the middle to upper 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 7 deg C/km, MLCAPE was around 2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was near 25 knots.

The mid-late afternoon hours on this Tuesday featured a smattering of strong to marginally severe thunderstorms primarily within the southwestern quadrant of South Central Nebraska (generally near/south of Interstate 80 and west of Highway 281). Within this area, there were a handful of severe-criteria wind gust and/or wind damage reports, including estimated 60 MPH gusts with four-inch tree limbs down eight miles south of Elwood, some minor tree damage in Red Cloud and also some limited tree damage and a power line down in Gibbon. There were no reports of large hail. Although there was no ground-truth confirmation of flooding, locally heavy rain in excess of three inches drenched portions of southeastern Harlan and far southwestern Franklin counties due to a combination of not only afternoon convection, but also redevelopment of a few strong storms during the night between 9 p.m. and 3 a.m. CDT. Within this small zone, event-total rain totals featured 3.75 two miles northwest of Republican City (NeRAIN observer) and 3.37 at Naponee (NWS coop observer). ||Focusing on timing, weak convection got underway early in the afternoon within extreme western portions of South Central Nebraska. However, it took a few hours for strong to severe activity initially over southwestern Nebraska to create a sufficient cold pool and push eastward into the local area between 3-4 p.m. CDT in the form of a north-to-south oriented bowing line segment. While this initial surge of winds resulted in the damage reports from Gosper and Buffalo counties, newly developing multicell storms soon blossomed farther east within counties along the state line, including the one responsible for tree damage in Red Cloud. While there were no reports of severe weather after 4:30 p.m. CDT, fairly widespread coverage of showers and storms persisted within much of South Central Nebraska through around 8 p.m. CDT. Beyond sunset, isolated to scattered thunderstorms redeveloped over several state-line counties along the nose of a modest low level jet, producing the aforementioned heavy downpours in Harlan/Franklin counties. Finally, by 6 a.m. CDT, the vast majority of South Central Nebraska was rain-free. In the larger scale of the mid-upper levels, this event was instigated by a slow-moving, elongated shortwave trough gradually sinking from northwest-to-southeast through the Central Plains. At the surface, afternoon convection intensified just to the north of a quasi-stationary front stretched west-to-east across northern Kansas. Around the time severe storms first entered the local area temperatures were only in the 70s F, but the mesoscale environment contained around 1500 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and deep layer wind shear of 30-35 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 24 hour rainfall total of 3.37 inches occurred in Naponee. Rain began in the early afternoon on August 4th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Between 10:30 a.m. and 12:30 p.m. CDT on this Thursday, an isolated, elevated supercell storm dropped east-southeast out of Nebraska and across primarily northern and eastern Phillips County along with parts of Smith County, before rapidly weakening. Along the way, there were a handful of severe-criteria hail reports, including stones up to golf ball size near Agra and quarter size in Kensington. As the storm began to weaken, penny size hail fell southeast of Smith Center. In the wake of this supercell, a few additional strong storms brushed across far northern Smith and Jewell counties during the early afternoon, but all of this six-county North Central Kansas area was pretty much storm-free by 3 p.m. CDT. ||The development of this isolated severe storm was fairly unexpected, given rather weak forcing aloft and also warm mid level temperatures. However, in the mid-upper levels, the broad quasi-zonal flow in place over northern Kansas did in fact feature a subtle disturbance moving in from the west, along the southern periphery of a better-defined, low amplitude shortwave trough tracking out of the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Despite temperatures at the 700-millibar level averaging at least 12-14 C, this rogue severe storm thrived in a mesoscale environment featuring most-unstable CAPE around 2000 J/kg and seasonably strong deep-layer wind shear of 40-50 knots.

On the afternoon and evening of the 25th a line of storms developed along a boundary in a very unstable environment. These storms produced large hail and then proceeded to move over the same areas causing flash flooding.

On the morning of the 22nd, a couple severe thunderstorms visited Sedgwick and Sumner counties where quarter to golfball-sized hail occurred.  Later that afternoon and evening, more storms moved across the central sections of the state producing hail and wind gusts.
Garden variety thunderstorms produced a very weak and brief landspout west of Whitewater KS.  The landspout was occurred along the intersection of two boundaries that collided.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An off duty weather service employee reported a very weak landspout in open country. The width of the landspout was 40 yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In a couple rounds of severe thunderstorms early morning storms did some wind damage in eastern Kansas and western Missouri. Later in the day more storms moved in causing some wind damage as well as some flash flooding.

Although severe thunderstorm winds only affected a small portion of North Central Kansas on this Saturday evening, the community of Osborne took a direct hit around 10 p.m. CDT as a wall of 65-70 MPH gusts blasted through town. Notable tree damage resulted, including larger limbs and a few completely uprooted. An empty semi trailer at a local business was tipped over, and a number of power poles were either damaged or snapped. In addition, an airport outbuilding sustained damage and an abandoned mobile home lost most of its roof. In addition to various estimated wind reports, a KSU mesonet station near the north edge of Osborne measured a peak 68 MPH gust. Although wind damage was clearly the main story across town, up to quarter size hail was also reported, along with a quick deluge of 1.50-2.00 of rain. As supported by radar data, damaging winds likely only impacted a narrow corridor as this multicell storm peaked in intensity within no more than 5-10 miles southwest-through-northeast of Osborne, and had weakened considerably by the time it reached the Mitchell County line around 10:30 p.m. CDT. ||This severe storm was not the first convection of the day within this six county North Central Kansas area. As early as 4-5 p.m. CDT, non-severe storms brushed into Mitchell County, splitting off the north edges of a more concentrated cluster of strong to severe storms centered just south of the local area. Then a few hours later, additional sub-severe activity flared up over parts of Rooks/Osborne counties. Between 9-10 p.m. CDT, some of this weaker convection merged with a stronger storm tracking northeast out of Ellis County, eventually producing the Osborne wind damage. Once this severe storm dissipated, only weak activity lingered thereafter, with all of North Central Kansas storm-free by 2 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, a seasonably-typical quasi-zonal flow pattern was in place over Kansas, containing weak, embedded shortwave disturbances along the northern periphery of a subtropical high centered over Texas. At the surface, afternoon/evening convection within northern and western Kansas was largely tied to convergence along a quasi-stationary front. Despite warm mid level air with 700-millibar temperatures running 12-14 C, the presence of a well-mixed, hot and moist airmass featuring afternoon temperatures in the 90s F and dewpoints generally between 65-70 F was enough to breach the cap and result in vigorous, outflow-dominant multicell storms. Around the time of the Osborne wind damage, mesoscale parameters featured at least 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.

Scattered severe thunderstorms developed out ahead of a surface trough along a couple of confluence zones in an area with steep mid level lapse rates and limited instability. There were a couple severe hail reports...the largest of which occurred from a splitting cell over Colfax county.

Thunderstorms developed in two areas of eastern Nebraska on the afternoon of May 3rd. The first and most intense developed near Lincoln at the intersection of a surface trough and a thermal boundary, which was the result of earlier day weaker thunderstorms. Although moisture and thus instability were limited, favorable shear and boundary interaction allowed for a couple of supercells to track southeast across southeast Nebraska producing significant hail and one weak tornado. The other area of thunderstorm development was across northeast Nebraska associated with a cold front. This area had limited instability as well, but also weaker shear than farther south and resulted in less intense storms. The threat of severe weather generally ended shortly after midnight as the storms weakened.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranged in size at different times from penny size to as large as 2 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several small, discrete supercells developed late in the afternoon on this Wednesday, and continued into the evening. While there were many reports of wall clouds and funnel clouds, these storms did not produce much severe weather. Most storms exhibited classic supercell characteristics on radar, with some supercells splitting. The only confirmed severe weather was 1.5 inch hail in Red Cloud, which is in Webster county, and a measured wind gust of 67 mph near the town of Chester, in southern Thayer county.||These storms formed north of a cold front that moved through the previous night and became stationary over northern Kansas. In the upper-levels, a subtropical high was over Texas, with a ridge extending north to Minnesota. Troughs were along the East Coast and over the western United States. A shortwave trough was embedded, in the western trough, from Montana south to Utah. Surface temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s and lower 70s. Mid-level lapse rates were low, resulting in MLCAPE between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 30-35 knots. Low-level (0-3 km) SRH was between 150 and 300 m2/s2. However, 0-1 km shear was less than optimal, between 10 and 15 knots. While this environment was supportive of supercells, the lack of low-level shear may have contributed to the lack of tornadoes.

Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.

During an 18-hour stretch between noon CDT on Tuesday the 4th and 6 a.m. on Wednesday the 5th, two fairly distinct rounds of widespread thunderstorm activity soaked much (but not all) of this six county North Central Kansas area with 1-4 inches of rain, and localized pockets as high as 6-8. Not surprisingly, short term flooding of rural roads and fields ensued within the zones of highest rainfall, along with minor flooding along the South Fork Solomon River in southern Smith and northeastern Osborne counties. Although a few storms exhibited radar signatures indicative of marginally severe hail and/or wind, there were no confirming ground truth reports. As a result, flooding concerns took center stage in an environment characterized by precipitable water values averaging 1.50-2.00.  The primary swath of 2-4 amounts (and locally higher) was roughly 10-20 miles wide and oriented northwest-to-southeast through most of Smith and Mitchell counties, along with adjacent portions of northern Osborne, southwestern Jewell and far southeastern Phillips counties. Within this broader zone of highest totals, there were mainly three smaller-scale maximums of at least 4-6. The largest of these zones included much of the northern half of Smith County, and particularly the northwest quadrant, where radar estimated a small zone of (unverified) 6-8 amounts. The majority of rain within Smith County fell during the overnight hours, and the highest-known ground truth report was 4.02 from the NWS coop observer in Lebanon. There were at least a few rural roads washed out within the county. The second zone of enhanced rainfall was a small, roughly 5x5 mile section of southeast Mitchell County, featuring a CoCoRaHS total of 6.15 six miles northwest of Barnard. However, rain here did not fall all at once, and was a combination of both afternoon and late-night activity. The third area of primary interest was a tiny, likely no more than 4x4 mile portion of extreme southeastern Phillips County south of Kirwin, where an unofficial total of 5 accumulated in 2-3 hours during the afternoon, resulting in water over numerous rural roads. Given that Smith County bore the brunt of excessive rainfall, much of the runoff steadily worked its way into the North Fork Solomon River upstream of Waconda Lake. At the automated gauge near Portis, the river breached minor flood stage of 15.0 ft. on the morning of the 5th and crested at 16.9 ft. on the morning of the 6th, before slipping below flood late that afternoon. In sharp contrast to the aforementioned pockets of heaviest rain within the six-county area, the majority of Rooks County along with central portions of Phillips and Osborne counties received well under 1, if hardly any at all.  ||Focusing on timing of this multi-part heavy rain event, round 1 was centered between 1-8 p.m. CDT on the 4th as various clusters of multicell convection traversed the area, largely tied to convergence along a quasi-stationary surface front stretched across the heart of northern Kansas. During this time, the only notable flooding was the localized deluge south of Kirwin. Following a relative minimum in storm activity for a few hours, round 2 got underway around 11 p.m. CDT and persisted through the remainder of the night before vacating local counties shortly before sunrise. This round, which featured repeated development of storms within a northwest-to-southeast axis centered through Smith and Mitchell counties, was largely driven by classic warm air advection/moisture transport along the nose of a modest 25-30 knot low level jet evident at 850 millibars. In the larger scale scene of the mid/upper levels, this entire heavy rain event was instigated by a slow-moving, elongated shortwave trough gradually sinking from northwest-to-southeast through the Central Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous county roads had water rushing across them, especially in the area south of Kirwin Reservoir. As of 3:30 p.m. CDT, an unofficial rainfall total of 5 inches was reported three miles south of Kirwin.
