Given that Smith County bore the brunt of excessive rainfall, much of the runoff steadily worked its way into the North Fork Solomon River upstream of Waconda Lake. At the automated gauge near Portis, the river breached minor flood stage of 15.0 ft. on the morning of the 5th and crested at 16.9 ft. on the morning of the 6th, before slipping below flood late that afternoon. In sharp contrast to the aforementioned pockets of heaviest rain within the six-county area, the majority of Rooks County along with central portions of Phillips and Osborne counties received well under 1, if hardly any at all.  ||Focusing on timing of this multi-part heavy rain event, round 1 was centered between 1-8 p.m. CDT on the 4th as various clusters of multicell convection traversed the area, largely tied to convergence along a quasi-stationary surface front stretched across the heart of northern Kansas. During this time, the only notable flooding was the localized deluge south of Kirwin. Following a relative minimum in storm activity for a few hours, round 2 got underway around 11 p.m. CDT and persisted through the remainder of the night before vacating local counties shortly before sunrise. This round, which featured repeated development of storms within a northwest-to-southeast axis centered through Smith and Mitchell counties, was largely driven by classic warm air advection/moisture transport along the nose of a modest 25-30 knot low level jet evident at 850 millibars. In the larger scale scene of the mid/upper levels, this entire heavy rain event was instigated by a slow-moving, elongated shortwave trough gradually sinking from northwest-to-southeast through the Central Plains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Culverts were washed out one mile north of Gaylord and also two miles northeast of Smith Center. Twenty-four hour rain totals as of 7 a.m. CDT on August 5th included: 4.02 inches in Lebanon and 3.26 in Smith Center (NWS cooperative observers).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Although severe thunderstorm winds only affected a small portion of North Central Kansas on this Saturday evening, the community of Osborne took a direct hit around 10 p.m. CDT as a wall of 65-70 MPH gusts blasted through town. Notable tree damage resulted, including larger limbs and a few completely uprooted. An empty semi trailer at a local business was tipped over, and a number of power poles were either damaged or snapped. In addition, an airport outbuilding sustained damage and an abandoned mobile home lost most of its roof. In addition to various estimated wind reports, a KSU mesonet station near the north edge of Osborne measured a peak 68 MPH gust. Although wind damage was clearly the main story across town, up to quarter size hail was also reported, along with a quick deluge of 1.50-2.00 of rain. As supported by radar data, damaging winds likely only impacted a narrow corridor as this multicell storm peaked in intensity within no more than 5-10 miles southwest-through-northeast of Osborne, and had weakened considerably by the time it reached the Mitchell County line around 10:30 p.m. CDT. ||This severe storm was not the first convection of the day within this six county North Central Kansas area. As early as 4-5 p.m. CDT, non-severe storms brushed into Mitchell County, splitting off the north edges of a more concentrated cluster of strong to severe storms centered just south of the local area. Then a few hours later, additional sub-severe activity flared up over parts of Rooks/Osborne counties. Between 9-10 p.m. CDT, some of this weaker convection merged with a stronger storm tracking northeast out of Ellis County, eventually producing the Osborne wind damage. Once this severe storm dissipated, only weak activity lingered thereafter, with all of North Central Kansas storm-free by 2 a.m. CDT. In the mid-upper levels, a seasonably-typical quasi-zonal flow pattern was in place over Kansas, containing weak, embedded shortwave disturbances along the northern periphery of a subtropical high centered over Texas. At the surface, afternoon/evening convection within northern and western Kansas was largely tied to convergence along a quasi-stationary front. Despite warm mid level air with 700-millibar temperatures running 12-14 C, the presence of a well-mixed, hot and moist airmass featuring afternoon temperatures in the 90s F and dewpoints generally between 65-70 F was enough to breach the cap and result in vigorous, outflow-dominant multicell storms. Around the time of the Osborne wind damage, mesoscale parameters featured at least 1000-2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and around 30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were both estimated and measured between 65 and 70 MPH in the area. There was notable tree damage in Osborne, including larger limbs and a few uprooted trees. An empty semi trailer at a local business was tipped over. A number of power poles were either damaged or snapped. There was damage to an outbuilding located at the airport approximately 1 mile east of town. An abandoned mobile home lost the majority of its roof. The 68 MPH wind gusts was measured by a KSU mesonet site located 1 mile north-northwest of Osborne.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in some minor shingle damage at an area home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.

Primarily between 4-8 p.m. CDT on this Sunday, several multicell thunderstorms rumbled across various portions of South Central Nebraska, but with the overall-greatest coverage focused within counties north of Interstate 80. While most of these storms produced nothing more than small hail and non-severe wind gusts, one flared up to severe levels over Sherman County mainly between 5:30-6:00 p.m. CDT, yielding a couple quarter size hail reports from the Loup City and Ashton areas. A few miles south of Ashton, one resident reported vinyl siding damage along with a destroyed garden. As the early evening hours wore on, this scattered convection steadily faded away with the loss of daytime heating. ||In the most basic sense, this largely diurnally-driven convection was sparked by a combination of strong surface heating and high instability near a weak, west-east oriented cold front sagging down from northern Nebraska, along with limited support aloft from a subtle disturbance embedded within broad northwesterly flow. Despite somewhat warm mid level temperatures, the combination of afternoon highs rising well into the 90s F and dewpoints averaging in the mid-60s to low-70s helped promote considerable instability with mixed-layer CAPE on the order of 2000-4000 J/kg. Storm organization was likely limited somewhat by only modest deep-layer wind shear generally on the order of 30-35 knots.

This Sunday afternoon and evening featured a rather localized-but-significant flooding event within primarily central and northeast portions of Furnas County, including the community of Edison, which was ground zero for flooding rains and also a brief bout of severe wind gusts estimated up to 65 MPH, along with hail up to quarter size. According to a trained spotter two miles southwest of Edison, an unofficial rain total of 5 inches poured down in a 90-minute span between 3:30-5:00 p.m. CDT, washing out part of a driveway. In Edison itself, the NWS cooperative observer recorded a slightly lower storm total of 3.74, but this was still more than enough rain in a short time to cause significant flooding of several roads and some structures. Some of the worst damage occurred at Ag Valley Coop, where a shallow depth of water infiltrated much of the first floor office. Even after the last drops of lingering light rain vacated Edison around 9 p.m. CDT, impactful flooding persisted well into the morning hours of the 17th. Although the Furnas County flooding situation was the big story from this event, radar data suggested that other pockets of flooding might have also occurred in portions of eastern Gosper and western Phelps counties, where rain totals of at least 2-3 were also fairly common. ||For the vast majority of the 16th, all the way from the pre-dawn hours through midnight, at least isolated to scattered showers and mainly weak thunderstorms affected at least some portion of South Central Nebraska, primarily within counties northwest of line from Franklin to York. While most of this convection was fairly disorganized and weak, the mid-afternoon through early evening hours featured a noticeable uptick in storm coverage and intensity, especially in southwestern counties such as Furnas, Gosper, and Phelps. Within this area, an initially weak cluster of convection rapidly intensified between 3-6 p.m. CDT, morphing into a nearly solid, southward-sinking line of slow-moving strong to severe storms. The primary synoptic scale trigger for this event was a very slow-moving, southwest-to-northeast oriented surface cold front roughly bisecting Nebraska during the afternoon and evening. Considerable moisture pooled in the vicinity of this boundary, featuring surface dewpoints in the mid-60s to low-70s F and precipitable water values averaging 1.50-2.00. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was rather subtle and weak, with southern Nebraska positioned well-south of a primary shortwave trough shifting from the Northern Rockies into the Dakotas. Around the time of the most intense Furnas County convection, mesoscale parameters featured at least 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE, but weak deep-layer wind shear only around 25 knots, helping promote slow storm motions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple roads were under water in and around the Edison area due to flash flooding. In Edison, Ag Valley Coop sustained some of the worst damage as flood waters infiltrated the first floor office. Other homes and buildings in and around Edison were also flooded. As of 4:25 pm CDT, 4.25 inches of rain was reported to have fallen two miles southwest of Edison (fell in one approximately one hour) and washed a dip in a driveway 2 feet deep. By 5 p.m. CDT, rainfall at that location was unofficially up to 5. In addition, the NWS cooperative observer in Edison reported a storm total of 3.74.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Despite a fairly favorable setup for severe thunderstorms on this Thursday afternoon and evening, the ingredients didn't quite come together across the vast majority of South Central Nebraska, with radar data suggesting only the presence of a few strong storms roaming counties along and north of Interstate 80. However, a delayed storm report received the next day revealed that a tiny fraction of the area did in fact experience a severe wind event: a Merrick County farmer reported a flipped irrigation pivot and significant crop damage in a localized area near Silver Creek. Although radar data was inconclusive regarding the severity of these winds (due in part to the  lowest beam height situated 6,000 feet above ground level at that distance), a fairly strong reflectivity core did pass through that area around 9 p.m. CDT within an environment featuring strong low level wind shear (see below). A few hours prior to the Merrick County damage, northwestern portions of South Central Nebraska narrowly avoided a severe weather threat from a cluster of splitting supercells in Custer County. However, these storms weakened before entering local counties such as Dawson and Valley. Then, between 8-10 p.m. CDT, a handful of strong multicell storms flared up within the northeast quadrant of South Central Nebraska in response to a strengthening low level jet, including the Merrick County storm. While additional non-severe storms lingered over northeast counties such as Nance, Merrick and Polk past the midnight hour, all of South Central Nebraska was storm-free by 2:30 a.m. CDT.||This was a somewhat unusual severe weather setup by late-August standards, as a seasonably well-defined surface low and attendant eastward-arcing warm front became established over the heart of South Central Nebraska during the afternoon and evening. Although mid/upper level flow wasn't overly strong, a fairly compact vort max tracked over central Nebraska, well to the north of an expansive ridge anchored over northern Mexico. In addition, a seasonably-strong southerly low level jet ramped up to around 40 knots over much of central and eastern Nebraska by early evening. The combination of this low level jet and the underlying surface warm front yielded an impressive 30 knots of 0-1 kilometer low level wind shear around the time of the Merrick County wind damage. Other early-evening mesoscale parameters were more modest, including roughly 1000 J/kg most-unstable CAPE and 30 knots of deep-layer wind shear.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated near 70 MPH blew over an irrigation pivot and resulted in significant crop damage within a localized area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fairly significant-but-localized rural flooding event unfolded within north central and northeast portions of Polk County, ramping up during the early morning hours of Tuesday Aug. 18th and persisting into the afternoon of Wednesday the 19th before markedly improving (severe weather in the form of large hail/damaging winds were not an issue). The worst flooding impacts were confined to a rather narrow, roughly 5-8 mile wide corridor extending west-to-east several miles north of Osceola and Shelby, where generally 6-10 of rain accumulated over the course of roughly 36 hours (see below for timing details). Within this zone, county officials reported that 25-30 gravel roads were under water or closed, with a few completely washed out. In addition, Clear Creek flooded within northeastern portions of the county, as the gauge 10 miles north of Shelby crested just above the minor flood stage of 8 ft. on the morning of the 19th. Although ground-truth, event-total reports were limited within the narrow corridor of maximum rainfall, a NeRAIN observer seven miles north of Osceola measured 6.69, and an unofficial public gauge six miles south of Duncan captured 8.50. Another nearby NeRAIN observer commented that this was the worst road flooding they had observed within the local area in at least 63 years. ||This was a somewhat unique flooding event considering that it did not occur solely as a result of one significant rainfall. Instead, it stemmed from the cumulative effect of primarily three rounds of heavy rain over the course of roughly 36 hours, with the third and final round serving as the proverbial final straw, resulting in the impactful flooding. In the mid-upper levels, broad quasi-zonal flow was in place over Nebraska during most of this time, before a larger scale shortwave trough finally passed through on the 18th, sweeping rain chances out of the local area. The first concentrated round of heavy rain moved through the county on the evening of Sunday the 16th, part of a larger complex of showers and thunderstorms focused near a slow-moving cold front. Following a rather short lull, the second primary round of rain flared up during the morning hours of Monday the 17th. Combined, these first two rounds dropped generally 2-4, but not enough to instigate flooding. Although a few spotty showers affected the area during the afternoon and early evening of the 17th, this was largely a dry period before a strengthening nocturnal low level jet sparked a narrow axis of persistent heavy rain over northern Polk County mainly between 9:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. CDT. This third round, which soaked the area with another 2-5, was clearly the one that prompted significant flooding issues, although one final burst of rain also passed through a few hours later around sunrise on the 18th. Fortunately, a solid stretch of dry weather returned to Polk County thereafter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many roads were flooded. Around 25 to 30 county roads (many were gravel roads) were closed in north central and northeastern portions of Polk County. At least one paved road had water running over it a few miles west of the Highway 81 and 64 junction. Some gravel roads were washed out in spots. Gauge readings and radar estimation indicated a narrow swath of six to 10 inches of rain fell in separate rounds over the course of roughly 30 hours. Minor flooding occurred along Clear Creek within northeast portions of the county. An NeRAIN observer seven miles north of Osceola reported 6.69 inches of rain between the evening of August 16th and the early morning of August 18th. The majority of the rain fell between 930 p.m. CDT August 17th through 1230 a.m. August 18th. Also, an unofficial public report of 8.50 of storm total rain occurred six miles south of Duncan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fairly significant-but-localized rural flooding event unfolded within north central and northeast portions of Polk County, ramping up during the early morning hours of Tuesday Aug. 18th and persisting into the afternoon of Wednesday the 19th before markedly improving (severe weather in the form of large hail/damaging winds were not an issue). The worst flooding impacts were confined to a rather narrow, roughly 5-8 mile wide corridor extending west-to-east several miles north of Osceola and Shelby, where generally 6-10 of rain accumulated over the course of roughly 36 hours (see below for timing details). Within this zone, county officials reported that 25-30 gravel roads were under water or closed, with a few completely washed out. In addition, Clear Creek flooded within northeastern portions of the county, as the gauge 10 miles north of Shelby crested just above the minor flood stage of 8 ft. on the morning of the 19th. Although ground-truth, event-total reports were limited within the narrow corridor of maximum rainfall, a NeRAIN observer seven miles north of Osceola measured 6.69, and an unofficial public gauge six miles south of Duncan captured 8.50. Another nearby NeRAIN observer commented that this was the worst road flooding they had observed within the local area in at least 63 years. ||This was a somewhat unique flooding event considering that it did not occur solely as a result of one significant rainfall. Instead, it stemmed from the cumulative effect of primarily three rounds of heavy rain over the course of roughly 36 hours, with the third and final round serving as the proverbial final straw, resulting in the impactful flooding. In the mid-upper levels, broad quasi-zonal flow was in place over Nebraska during most of this time, before a larger scale shortwave trough finally passed through on the 18th, sweeping rain chances out of the local area. The first concentrated round of heavy rain moved through the county on the evening of Sunday the 16th, part of a larger complex of showers and thunderstorms focused near a slow-moving cold front. Following a rather short lull, the second primary round of rain flared up during the morning hours of Monday the 17th. Combined, these first two rounds dropped generally 2-4, but not enough to instigate flooding. Although a few spotty showers affected the area during the afternoon and early evening of the 17th, this was largely a dry period before a strengthening nocturnal low level jet sparked a narrow axis of persistent heavy rain over northern Polk County mainly between 9:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. CDT. This third round, which soaked the area with another 2-5, was clearly the one that prompted significant flooding issues, although one final burst of rain also passed through a few hours later around sunrise on the 18th. Fortunately, a solid stretch of dry weather returned to Polk County thereafter.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around 25 to 30 county roads (many were gravel roads) were closed due to standing water in north central and northeastern portions of Polk County. At least one paved road had water running over it a few miles west of the Highway 81 and 64 junction. Some gravel roads were washed out in spots. Gauge readings and radar estimation indicated a narrow swath of six to 10 inches of rain fell in separate rounds over the course of roughly 30 hours. Minor flooding occurred along Clear Creek within northeast portions of the county. An NeRAIN observer seven miles north of Osceola reported 6.69 inches of rain between the evening of August 16th and the early morning of August 18th. The majority of the rain fell between 930 p.m. CDT August 17th through 1230 a.m. August 18th. Also, an unofficial public report of 8.50 of storm total rain occurred six miles south of Duncan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of storms moved across Central Kansas bringing copious amounts of rain prompting several flood warnings and a few flash flood warnings.  Wind gusts of 50 to 70 mph were also noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several low water crossings had water covering them causing problems for travel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the morning of April 8, several severe thunderstorms rolled through the area, bringing with it mostly large hail. These storms even brought 1.5 inch hail to the NWS office in Pleasant Hill, Missouri. On the Kansas side, the only hail reports were from the morning convection, but in Missouri the second round in the afternoon and evening brought a long swatch of wind that went into Central Missouri. In the Kansas City metro area a left-moving short-lived storm brought 2 inch hail that afternoon to the northern part of the metro.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.

Severe thunderstorms moved over Northwest Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  The majority of the severe weather occurred during the afternoon in Logan county with several tornado reports in the Winona and Monument area.  The largest hail size reported was 1.75 inches near Winona, the same storm that produced the tornado.  Later on a line of storms over Thomas county produced severe wind gusts measuring 63 MPH at the Colby airport.
Evening thunderstorms over portions of the northwest Nebraska Panhandle produced  large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed three miles northwest of the Chadron Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two separate thunderstorm events produced a little severe weather and flash flooding on this Friday. The first episode was associated with a couple supercells that formed near McCook, Nebraska the prior evening. These storms evolved into a small multicell cluster that was joined by a few other storms as it moved southeast across north-central Kansas between midnight at 3 a.m. CST. This small cluster was mostly sub-severe, producing penny size hail and measured winds of 50-55 mph in a few spots. However, it did produce a severe wind gust of 61 mph in Logan. Later in the day, between 5 and 6 pm CST, several thunderstorms formed over Rooks, Phillips, and Smith Counties. They quickly congealed into a multicell cluster. This cluster remained quasi-stationary between 5:30 and 8:30 p.m., with the most persistent heavy rain over southeastern Phillips and northeastern Rooks Counties. Three to six inches of rain were measured in this short time span and this resulted in flash flooding, with numerous gravel roads under water and some washed out in spots. One of these storms did produce hail to the size of quarters in Stockton, which is in Rooks County.||The overnight storms occurred near a dissipating frontal boundary, with no forcing aloft. The late afternoon and evening storms formed along a weak cold front that had dropped through Nebraska, during the day, and was slowing its forward progress over north central Kansas. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.

Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours in Sheridan County and moved southward through the eastern panhandle and portions of southwest Nebraska during the evening hours. Isolated thunderstorms also occurred in Blaine County of north central Nebraska during the early evening hours producing damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 80 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front led to the development of a line of showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon and evening of July, 6th, 2015.  Wet microbursts along the slow moving line led to damaging winds of 70-80 mph across portions of South Central Kansas.   Also the slow moving storms led to torrential downpours across portions of the Wichita metro area.  Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches, produced flash flooding across the heart of the Wichita metro area, including submerging numerous vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported the gust just north of El Dorado. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in central Cherry County and moved southeast producing large hail, heavy rain, and gusty winds. Other thunderstorms developed in the southeast Nebraska Panhandle and southwest that also produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain. The heavy rainfall led to localized flash flooding in portions of Keith, Perkins, Lincoln, and Hayes counties.
Thunderstorms were confined to mostly the far southwest part of the area along a dryline in the vicinity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a lot of pea sized hail that covered the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the third day in a row with severe weather.  Even though the atmosphere was not terribly unstable, the high shear environment along a stationary front provided the ingredients for severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight inches of rain fell in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was day 4 in a row with severe weather.  A dryline was one focusing mechanism for severe weather.  Otherwise, supercell thunderstorms developed in a the atmosphere was unstable enough with shear to produce severe weather.
Slow moving, severe thunderstorms developed producing heavy rain and large hail across Chase and Hayes counties during the evening of July 25th. Hail to teacup size fell.

This was a rather active weather night for South Central Nebraska, highlighted by a handful of severe-criteria wind reports within counties along and south of Interstate 80. Although widespread precipitation affected the area for several hours on this Friday night into early Saturday morning, all severe wind reports occurred between 11:30 p.m. and 12:30 a.m. CDT as a north-to-south oriented bowing segment charged through. Along and near the leading edge of the surging outflow, wind gusts around 60 MPH were reported near Gibbon, in rural southeastern Adams and southwestern Clay counties, and also near Superior. Well-behind this bowing line, severe gusts associated with a well-defined mesoscale convective vortex (MCV) brought down numerous tree limbs in Cozad. Although there were no confirmed tornadoes, the presence of seasonably-strong low level shear aided the development of a few brief, radar-indicated rotational signatures, one of which prompted a short-fused Tornado Warning for southern Adams County. Rainfall-wise, though many areas roughly southwest of a Ravenna-Hastings-Hebron line picked up 1-2, the fairly progressive nature of the heaviest cores held flooding issues to a minimum, save for typical short-term street flooding in communities such as Elm Creek. ||Timing-wise, most of South Central Nebraska remained rain-free until after dark, save for a narrow band of weak convection that lifted through several northern and eastern counties during the early evening. However, a pair of expanding severe storm clusters gradually took aim on the local area as they approached from southwest Nebraska and northwest Kansas, eventually merging into an organized mesoscale convective system (MCS) that surged into western portions of South Central Nebraska between 10-11 p.m. CDT. By the midnight to 1 a.m. CDT time frame, the primary bowing segment raced through counties south of Interstate 80 and east of Highway 281 before departing into southeast Nebraska and northeast Kansas. In its wake, a large shield of light to moderate rain persisted across the local area for most of the night. In the mid/upper levels, this event featured slightly-stronger-than-average forcing by early August standards, as a well-defined lead disturbance moved out of the Central Rockies into the Central Plains in quasi-zonal flow aloft, downstream from a larger scale parent trough centered over Nevada. By the time the MCS entered the local area, convection was being sustained/enhanced by a 30-40 knot southerly low level jet evident at 850 millibars. At the surface, South Central Nebraska featured a light easterly flow regime, to the north of a quasi-stationary front loosely draped across the southern half of Kansas. Around the time of the severe wind reports, mesoscale parameters featured 1000-2000 J/kg most unstable CAPE, deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots and rather strong 0-1 kilometer low level shear of 20-30 knots.

In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms over Banner and Kimball counties produced several funnel clouds, damaging winds and torrential rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two funnel clouds were sighted 11 miles northwest of the Kimball Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a stationary front across western Nebraska and northeastern Colorado during the late afternoon hours on July 18th. As this activity moved east it became severe across the western Nebraska Sandhills and southwestern Nebraska. Damaging winds impacted crops and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public reported thunderstorm wind gusts around 70 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High terrain thunderstorms moved out of Colorado associated with a passing short wave trough and helped trigger thunderstorms, some severe.  One storm in particular developed and became supercellular and turned south.  It caused extensive damage along it's path shredding corn fields to nubs and killing numerous wildlife.  Thirty-three pivot sprinklers were overturned.  Several high voltage transmission line structures were crumpled by the high wind with speeds in excess of 110 MPH likely.||There was also reports of corn fields (6 foot high stalks) that were completely shredded with nothing but nubs left.  Wildlife in these fields were killed with numerous reports of dead deer, rapids and other critters.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 80 to 100 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front led to the development of a line of showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon and evening of July, 6th, 2015.  Wet microbursts along the slow moving line led to damaging winds of 70-80 mph across portions of South Central Kansas.   Also the slow moving storms led to torrential downpours across portions of the Wichita metro area.  Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches, produced flash flooding across the heart of the Wichita metro area, including submerging numerous vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report via social media of 60 to 70 mph winds. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several waves of tropical moisture moved into portions of eastern KS causing widespread heavy rain. This rain fell on top of already saturated ground, which lead to flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water flowing across the road at least 6 inches deep at 173rd and Ratner rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving thunderstorms over Kimball and Cheyenne counties produced torrential rainfall that resulted in flash flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of rain in two hours produced flash flooding along Lodgepole Creek and US Highway 30 from east of Potter through Brownson to just west of Sidney.  Extensive lowland flooding was reported north and south of Interstate 80.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms produced hail across a couple of counties.

Isolated thunderstorms developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 27th.  They developed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure, and moved to the east northeast into the western Nebraska Sandhills and portions of the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle. Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gust of 60 MPH measured with a Davis instrument.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of strong to severe storms developed during the afternoon and evening over Northwest Kansas, some of them remaining stationary at times.  The largest hail size reported was quarter size near Blakeman, however over three inches of small hail was reported near Edson.  The strongest wind gust reported was an estimated 70 MPH at Winona, which occurred when the town to lose power.  A measured wind speed of 65 MPH was reported near Leoti ahead of a line of storms.  Flash flooding occurred near Winona with these storms as water 18 inches deep and roughly 100 yards wide was reported over Road 230.
An upper level short wave trough interacted with an unstable atmosphere and stationary front to produce thunderstorms, some of which were severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered to numerous, semi-discrete and multicell thunderstorms blossomed across much of South Central Nebraska on this Saturday afternoon and evening, with a few storms becoming severe and producing hail ranging from 1-2 in diameter. The first severe storm of the afternoon developed near Kearney around 5 p.m. CDT, and was likely the most prolific hail-producer as it slowly drifted north-northwest through central and northwest Buffalo County for nearly two hours. Just north of Kearney, a few vehicles slid off of Highway 10 as it became hail-covered and slick. This storm also produced the largest reported hail of the day (2) north of Riverdale. Between 6-9 p.m. CDT, several other storms either flared up over various parts of the area or pushed northward out of Kansas, with quarter size hail reported near the state line south of Red Cloud and also in Wood River. Even though the mesoscale environment was potentially supportive of a somewhat greater severe weather threat, the fairly rapid development of plentiful convection and resultant storm-scale outflow interference likely mitigated this. With the loss of diurnal heating, storms steadily weakened and diminished in coverage within a few hours after nightfall. Although most affected areas received less than 1 of rainfall, much of northern Kearney County along with adjacent portions of southeast Buffalo, southwest Hall and northwest Adams counties received higher amounts to around 2. ||In the mid-upper levels, the primary player was an expansive closed low churning slowly eastward through eastern Colorado, with several smaller-scale disturbances shifting northward into the Central Plains along its eastern flank. At the surface, there were no distinct synoptic features within South Central Nebraska, only fairly weak, broad low pressure and prevailing light southerly to easterly breezes. Despite afternoon temperatures only rising into the low-70s F, the combination of surface dewpoints in the low to mid-50s and notably cold air aloft (evidenced by 500 millibar temps around -18 C) yielded surface-based CAPE around 1000 J/kg in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ditches were running out of their banks and down the streets.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in central Cherry County and moved southeast producing large hail, heavy rain, and gusty winds. Other thunderstorms developed in the southeast Nebraska Panhandle and southwest that also produced large hail, damaging winds, and heavy rain. The heavy rainfall led to localized flash flooding in portions of Keith, Perkins, Lincoln, and Hayes counties.

During the early morning hours of the 8th a powerful storm developed in north central KS. As it moved southeastward it began to strengthen as it approached I-70. It then proceeded to move across Topeka causing 70 to 90 mph winds and damage to trees and power lines.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of 4 inch diameter tree limbs down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon over Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was two inches in diameter near Colby and Bird City.  Some thunderstorms also produced high winds, with the highest wind gusts of 64 MPH reported at the Oakley airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall is also accompanying the hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of severe thunderstorms developed during the early afternoon over Northwest Kansas.  The largest hail size reported was two inches in diameter near Colby and Bird City.  Some thunderstorms also produced high winds, with the highest wind gusts of 64 MPH reported at the Oakley airport.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail fell for two minutes then stopped.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed during the late afternoon of the 25th as modified gulf moisture returned north into the middle Missouri River Valley. As moisture returned to the area, instability increased and allowed for the thunderstorm development. The majority of the thunderstorms were non-severe in nature due to the weak atmospheric shear and limited instability, but isolated large hail was observed in southeast Nebraska and southwest Iowa.

Between 6-9 p.m. CDT on this late Sunday afternoon and evening, a fairly compact-but-intense supercell storm tracked eastward across mainly central sections of Smith and Jewell counties. This storm yielded several reports of large hail and also the first tornado of 2015 within this six-county North Central Kansas area, an EF-0 that touched down three miles north of Smith Center and tracked for about one mile, damaging the roof of an outbuilding. Prior to this brief tornado, there had been several reports of a funnel cloud or multiple funnels as the storm traversed west-central Smith County. For most of its path, this supercell was primarily a hail-producer, as quarter size stones fell in Lebanon, Burr Oak and Formoso, and larger stones up to golf ball size rained down on Mankato for several minutes. ||Focusing on event timing, this storm initiated over the Smith-Phillips County line around 6 p.m. CDT, just ahead of an approaching cold front. At first, it appeared storm mode might assume a southwest-northeast oriented line segment, but a more discrete supercell structure quickly evolved as it tracked east down the Highway 36 corridor. As this storm reached eastern Jewell County around 8 p.m. CDT, it began morphing into a more linear structure that expanded southwestward into Mitchell County for a time. However, there were no further severe weather reports as all thunderstorms exited the local area by 930 p.m. CDT, in tandem with the passing cold front. In the mid-upper levels, forcing was provided by the southern reaches of a broad shortwave trough tracking east across the Central and especially Northern Plains, with this trough ushering in increasing west-southwest flow aloft. At the surface, the well-defined, northeast-southwest oriented cold front steadily swept through North Central Kansas during the evening. Ahead of this boundary, afternoon temperatures across most of the local area topped out between 75-80 F as dewpoints rose into the mid-upper 50s on gusty south winds. The presence of a weak surface low and attendant warm front in the immediate area likely contributed to tornado development, as local surface observations revealed a backing of wind direction to southeasterly ahead of the storm. As for basic severe weather parameters, mixed-layer CAPE values peaked in the 1000-1500 J/kg range in the presence of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear of 40-50 knots.

A cold front advanced across the area during the afternoon and evening.  There were also residual outflow boundaries from convection the day before that provided a focusing area for thunderstorm development.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief and weak tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Daytime heating of a moist atmosphere and a surface through provided the necessary ingredients for severe weather.

Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several long-track supercell thunderstorms developed during the evening hours and moved north. Seven tornadoes were reported over four hours, with some producing EF1-EF2 damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Road signs were damaged 1 mile west of Bird City. Time is estimated from Doppler radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stationary boundary was draped across Central Kansas during the overnight and early morning hours of June 5th, 2015.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along this front (generally along Interstate 70), and trained along this boundary.   As the ealry morning progressed and complex of storms moved out of Northwest Kansas and moved along this boundary as well, to produce torrential rainfall across Central Kansas.  So reports of flash flooding occurred, due to rainfall amounts of 2 to 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to three feet of water was flowing over Scanlan Road near the airport. Rainfall amounts were reported ranged from 2.13 inches to 4.15 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front and associated upper level trough moved across the southeast Kansas. Severe storms and some supercells developed which had damaging winds, large hail, and isolated tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was reported from the size of quarters to up to ping pong size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong short wave trough lifting out of the Rockies combined with an atmosphere that was recovering from earlier thunderstorms.  There likely was mesoscale interactions with old outflow boundaries.  Tornadoes formed along a warm front lifting north.  Many storm spotters and chasers were unable to see the tornadoes due to the proximately to dense fog on the cold side of the front.  Those that did observe the tornadoes were astonished at the apparent width and magnitude of the tornadoes.  However, it appears that the condensation part of the tornadoes were exceptionally large due to the cold and moist airmass being entrained into them.  They appeared to be much stronger than they actually were, likely because of the amount of condensation and associated very low cloud bases.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 4 inches was observed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An MCS in northwest flow aloft moved out across the plains.  Early on though widely scattered thunderstorms in a very unstable airmass were able to produce severe weather, including a landspout tornado that was highly visible and which moved across a lake.

Numerous thunderstorms produced torrential rains across parts of South-Central Kansas for much of the afternoon and evening. Major flooding occurred. The most serious was that of a flash flood that occurred in Wichita. In parts of South and Southeast Wichita as well as West Wichita vehicles were submerged. Most of the parking lots at the Towne West Mall were flooded to depths around 3 feet. Rainfalls from 3-6 inches were widespread. Many streets were barricaded. Among them was Maple Avenue from I-235 to West Streets. The situation was exacerbated by heavy thunderstorms that produced torrential rains early in the morning. In fact, a staggering 5.60 inches was measured in Harper that morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports of submerged cars in Southeast Wichita. This would include Pawnee and 31st St. S. as well as on W. Harry and Southwest Blvd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon and early evening thunderstorms produced strong winds and large hail across portions of the western Nebraska Panhandle.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated at 60 mph were observed on the west side of Minatare.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late afternoon thunderstorms over the northwest Nebraska Panhandle produced several reports of large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was observed 20 miles north of Harrison.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a very unstable atmosphere aided by a short wave trough and residual outflow boundaries.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This landspout also moved northwest as did the one that formed at 402 PM CDT.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed early this Wednesday afternoon and evening, and predominantly produced tornadoes and flash flooding. With no cap in place, scattered thunderstorms began developing as early as the noon hour over north central Kansas. Most storms rapidly became supercellular. These supercells rapidly lifted north into south central Nebraska and began producing severe weather by 330 p.m. CDT. Most of the tornadoes occurred over Nuckolls and Thayer counties. One tornado did occur over Adams county and a brief spin-up also occurred over Hall county. Eventually, an MCS developed. The leading edge of the cold pool becoming stationary. New storms repeatedly developed over north central Kansas and lifted northeast along the boundary, through Nuckolls and Thayer counties and further downstream into southeastern Nebraska. Cell training produced a swath of 5-11 inches of rain over portions of Nuckolls and Thayer counties. The highest amount reported was 10.91 inches just west of Hebron. This amount of rainfall in 24 hours typically occurs once in 1,000 years at any given location, or stated another way, has a .1% chance of occurrence in a given 24 hour period. Cooperative observers in Hebron and Superior reported 8.59 and 7.13 inches, respectively. These were the highest 24-hour rainfall amounts ever recorded at these locations, dating back to 1893. Flash flooding damaged roads and some bridges were washed out. U.S. Highways 81 and 136 were closed for a time due to the flooding.||A complex low pressure system extended from the Canadian Prairies into the western United States. These storms developed in the warm sector, far away from any discernible surface boundaries. However, an axis of confluence was present over north central Kansas. A deep upper-level trough was over the western U.S., with a ridge over the East. In the southwest flow between these features, a shortwave trough was lifting through the Central Plains. These storms formed in the southeast quadrant of the associated vorticity maximum. Around the time thunderstorms developed, temperatures were in the lower 70s with dewpoints in the lower 60s, resulting in low cloud bases. Even at mid-afternoon, cloud bases were only 2000-2500 feet. The surface conditions and mid-level lapse rates of 7 degrees C/km resulted in SBCAPE around 1500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was only 25-30 knots. However, low-level wind fields were strong with 40-45 knots at 850 mb. This resulted in large hodographs with 0-1 km SRH values of 200-250 m2/s2, and 0-3 km SRH of 250-300 m2/s2. Combined with low cloud bases, this created a favorable environment for supercells and tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado touched down about 3 miles south of Roseland, clipping the east side of town before lifting just north-northeast of town. This tornado was rated an EF1, with an estimated peak wind speed of 110 MPH. The most widespread damage from this tornado was on the east side of town, and while several homes and outbuildings sustained damage, 2 sustained considerable damage. One of those homes slide from its foundation and another lost its entire roof structure. A large metal building with wood post frame construction was destroyed and tree damage was widespread throughout town. The tornado traveled just a few hundred feet east of Silver Lake School.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In what had already been a very active start to June across parts of South Central Nebraska, what transpired on the afternoon of Wednesday the 10th into the early morning of Thursday the 11th was the final, truly widespread severe weather/flooding event of the month before a noticeably quieter weather pattern settled in over the next few weeks. Focusing first on the severe weather aspect, the afternoon and evening featured several reports of large hail and damaging winds within various counties. Storm mode was primarily multicell, some of which started out as semi-discrete before eventually merging into larger clusters and lines. Most hail reports were in the nickel to half dollar size range, with 1.25 diameter stones reported near Elwood and Lexington. However, one storm that tracked north of Lexington around 6 p.m. CDT was a prolific hail-producer, as a storm chaser reported a short stretch of Highway 21 completely hail-covered with most stones averaging golf ball size but one as large as 3 in diameter. As for damaging winds, there were primarily three noteworthy storms. First off, a cluster of severe storms shifted eastward into the Valley/Sherman counties area between 5:30-6:30 p.m. CDT. In Arcadia, the NWS cooperative observer estimated 70 MPH gusts, with 10-12 diameter tree limbs down. A bit later, a storm became severe near the Franklin/Kearney County line around 7 p.m. CDT and rapidly tracked northeast during the next few hours. Along the way, estimated 70 MPH winds overturned seven empty freight cars of a 72-car train near Kenesaw in extreme western Adams County. This storm weakened before reaching Grand Island, with only 50-60 MPH gusts reported on the south side of town around 8:30 p.m. CDT. While the train-toppling storm was in progress, a separate severe storm to its northeast passed through Merrick and northern Hamilton counties, causing tree and power line damage in Central City and Hordville around 8 p.m. CDT. By 9 p.m. CDT, storms had largely settled below severe-limits, with just one additional 60 MPH wind report along the Franklin/Webster County line. Through the remainder of the night, scattered to numerous showers and non-severe storms persisted over much of South Central Nebraska, with most counties finally rain-free by sunrise. As for rainfall amounts, the majority of the 24-county area totaled 1-2. However, there were a few smaller pockets of at least 2-3, most notably within York, northern Hamilton and southwestern Polk counties, where NeRAIN observers reported 3.46 near Hordville and 3.24 near Benedict.  Although a few dry days leading up to this event had allowed the York County area to start drying out in the wake of flooding rains that fell primarily on the 4th-5th, this event resulted in renewed short-term flooding issues. Most notably this involved the West Fork Big Blue River near McCool Junction, which again came out of its banks during the day on the 11th, only a few days after historic flooding occurred. Fortunately, flooding was not as severe this time around, and the river largely fell back into its banks by the end of the day on Friday the 12th (please refer to the June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. episode narrative for much more detail regarding multiple days of flooding along the West Fork Big Blue River). ||Most of the timing details of this severe weather event were already covered in the preceding paragraph, as all hail/strong wind reports occurred between 4:00-9:30 p.m. CDT. However, the first strong storms of the afternoon actually developed eastward into the Dawson/Gosper counties area as early as 2:30-4:00 p.m. CDT. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale setup: the primary trigger aloft was a series of fairly subtle disturbances gradually overspreading the Central Plains, out ahead of a modest shortwave trough drifting southeast toward the region from the Northern Rockies. At the surface, a few different boundaries helped to focus convection, including a generally west-to-east oriented quasi-stationary front draped through central Nebraska and also a trough axis extending southwest from the local area to weak low pressure centered near the KS/CO border. With afternoon temperatures rising between 90-95 degrees, storms erupted in an environment featuring around 2000 J/kg mixed-layer CAPE and 30-40 knots of 0-6 kilometer deep layer wind shear. During the night, widespread weak convection persisted within the exit region of a 30-40 knot low level jet.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A small stretch of Highway 21 was completely covered in hail. Most hail stones were near the size of golf balls, with some as large as 3 in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a stationary front across western Nebraska and northeastern Colorado during the late afternoon hours on July 18th. As this activity moved east it became severe across the western Nebraska Sandhills and southwestern Nebraska. Damaging winds impacted crops and power lines.

A cold front moved into eastern Nebraska during the afternoon of the 1st. Ahead of the cold front some moisture return from the southern Pains coupled with steep lapse-rates aloft to create marginal instability. Isolated to scattered thunderstorms developed along the cold front by late afternoon, developing into a line of thunderstorms before moving southeast through eastern Nebraska and into western Iowa. Isolated severe weather was reported along this line.

Thunderstorms developed in two areas of eastern Nebraska on the afternoon of May 3rd. The first and most intense developed near Lincoln at the intersection of a surface trough and a thermal boundary, which was the result of earlier day weaker thunderstorms. Although moisture and thus instability were limited, favorable shear and boundary interaction allowed for a couple of supercells to track southeast across southeast Nebraska producing significant hail and one weak tornado. The other area of thunderstorm development was across northeast Nebraska associated with a cold front. This area had limited instability as well, but also weaker shear than farther south and resulted in less intense storms. The threat of severe weather generally ended shortly after midnight as the storms weakened.

Strong to severe thunderstorms developed over portions of north central Nebraska in association with a surface trough of low pressure across the Nebraska Panhandle. A second area of strong to severe thunderstorms formed across southwestern Nebraska, along and north of a warm front which was draped over far southwestern Nebraska.

Strong to severe thunderstorms developed over portions of north central Nebraska in association with a surface trough of low pressure across the Nebraska Panhandle. A second area of strong to severe thunderstorms formed across southwestern Nebraska, along and north of a warm front which was draped over far southwestern Nebraska.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gust to 60 MPH reported at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed across the Nebraska panhandle and northeast Colorado during the afternoon. The storms intensified and expanded as they moved into southwest Nebraska, producing severe wind gusts and large hail. Training storms over Chase and Hayes counties led to rainfall amounts up to 3 in spots and localized flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roads were rendered impassible near Hayes Center due to heavy rain and washouts in spots.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unstable atmosphere, residual outflow boundaries and an approaching shortwave trough helped to produce thunderstorms, some severe.
A severe thunderstorm moved over northern Red Willow County during the evening producing hail up to tennis ball size.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hailstones were as large as tennis balls.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous strong to occasionally severe multicell storms blossomed across South Central Nebraska from the late evening of Wednesday the 3rd into the morning hours of Thursday the 4th, serving as round 1 of an active few days of severe storms and flooding rainfall. With storms ranging in character from semi-discrete to clusters and line segments, they primarily produced hail up to around quarter size, along with heavy rain. Although convection affected parts of several counties at some point during the night, the majority of ground-truth severe weather reports emanated from Adams and Clay counties, including quarter size hail on the east side of Hastings, hail up to golf ball size in Clay Center, and several hours later, a combination of quarter size hail and estimated 60 MPH winds six miles east-southeast of Clay Center. Rainfall-wise, the big story of the night was a concentrated swath of generally 1.50-3.00 that fell over southern Hall/northern Adams counties, southeastward through most of Clay, Fillmore and northern Thayer counties. Within this corridor, a few of the highest overnight totals from NeRAIN observers included 3.13 near Alexandria and 3.00 a few miles northwest of Hastings. As a result, minor flooding affected several creeks and streams and some roadways. In fact, the southbound lanes of Highway 281 in far-southern Hall County were closed for a few hours during the night due to flooding. Although this generally minor flooding subsided during the day of the 4th, unfortunately many of these same areas would soon be drenched with another 2-4 on the evening of the 4th into the morning of the 5th, resulting in 36-hour totals of 3-7 and a more serious, widespread flooding situation (please refer to the separate June 4th p.m.-June 5th a.m. severe weather episode for further details). ||Breaking down the overall event timing, all convection through the pre-dark hours focused to the south over northern Kansas. Then, between 10 p.m.-midnight CDT, storms began developing northward into the southern two rows of South Central Nebraska counties, largely in response to a strengthening, northward-lifting low level jet. Over the course of the next several hours, numerous strong to occasionally severe storms continued spreading north and east across the area, with half dollar size hail reported as far north as southern Greeley County. Within the aforementioned primary zone of heavy rain, the majority fell between 2:30-6:00 a.m. CDT. As one area of storms was in the process of exiting eastern counties of the local area around sunrise, a separate, quick-moving line of non-severe convection moved in from the southwest, sweeping across most of South Central Nebraska between 5-9 a.m. CDT. Although a few storms persisted here and there through late-morning, most places began a brief respite before the next round of evening/overnight storms arrived. Turning to the synoptic and mesoscale situation: with a generally west-east oriented surface front residing near the Nebraska-Kansas border through the night, seasonably-strong instability and shear in place, and a strengthening 30-40 knot southerly low level jet taking direct aim on the local area, this was a well-anticipated nocturnal convective flare-up. On the large scale, the Central Plains was under broad west-southwest flow aloft, well-downstream from a large trough centered over the West Coast. At the time of the first severe-criteria hail reports around 11:30 p.m. CDT, the environment featured most-unstable CAPE of 1000-2000 J/kg and 0-6 kilometer deep-layer wind shear of 30-40 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dime to quarter size hail occurred at Dove Hill Avenue and Highway 30.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late afternoon and into the evening a strong thunderstorm produced hail up to dime size along with flash flooding over Rawlins county.  Northwest of Atwood 1.20 inches of rain fell in 20 minutes, which lead to part of the North Beaver creek rising out of its banks.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Also reported 2.33 inches of heavy rainfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front led to the development of a line of showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon and evening of July, 6th, 2015.  Wet microbursts along the slow moving line led to damaging winds of 70-80 mph across portions of South Central Kansas.   Also the slow moving storms led to torrential downpours across portions of the Wichita metro area.  Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches, produced flash flooding across the heart of the Wichita metro area, including submerging numerous vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A public report via twitter of roof damage to a home. Winds were estimated of 60 to 70 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Appanoose creek covering Idaho rd with 2 feet of water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several MCSs affected northeast Kansas during this 2-day event. Each round of storms brought hail, gusty winds, and flooding rains. Each of the MCSs formed near the NE/KS state line and moved southeastward across the area. The environment was able to recover after each round, and the convection remained partially surface based through out the event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous 5 inch diameter tree branches were snapped by wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong shortwave trough and associated 130 knot upper jet moved across western Kansas during the afternoon and evening.  At the surface frontogenesis along an secondary cold front ignited severe thunderstorms.  The thunderstorms moved rapidly and developed a very pronounced Rear Inflow Jet. As a consequence, the storms generated very high surface winds.   From Scott County the storms moved into Pratt county.  There were approximately 150 pivot irrigation sprinklers overturned or damaged along this stretch.  Total dollar amount for this entire area probably exceeded $7 million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was damage to a grain bin, shed and the home had broken windows.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm moved near McCook which produced nickel size hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Relayed through Spotter Network.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered morning thunderstorms drenched most of Harper County with 2-3 inches that proved sufficient to cause flooding in the town of Harper.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KWCH Channel 12 reported street flooding was in progress in Harper. No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms produced a report of minor wind damage and several reports of minor flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highway 69 and Grove Road was flooded and closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of the 26th a line of storms formed in northern KS. As the storms moved to the southeast they produced isolated areas of severe wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree down across a power line.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed in a very unstable atmosphere aided by a short wave trough and residual outflow boundaries.

An area of upper level low pressure slowly moved across the central Plains during the September 22nd through the 23rd time frame. Significant moisture was in place across the mid Missouri River Valley ahead of this system. This combination led to scattered to numerous thunderstorms over eastern Nebraska and western Iowa starting on the 22nd and continuing into the day on the 23rd. The heavy persistent thunderstorms, especially late in the night and into the early morning hours on the 23rd led to significant flash flooding across parts of western Iowa, specifically in Council Bluffs.

Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary near the Kansas and Nebraska border. The moisture combined with steep lapse rates to create moderate instability along this boundary during the afternoon and evening hours. Scattered thunderstorms developed along this boundary by mid afternoon and continued into the evening hours as an upper level disturbance moved into the central Plains. One storm in particular moved along the Kansas and Nebraska border and produced sporadic significant severe in the form of very large hail and damaging winds.

An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.

This was the last of five significant severe hail events this month, in terms of size and the number of reports. Each of these events contained at least one report of 2 inch hail or greater. The uniqueness of this event was that it occurred during the morning hours on this Friday. Around 5 a.m. CST, scattered showers began to develop across much of south central Nebraska. Over the following couple hours, they increased in coverage and strengthened into thunderstorms. By 7:30 a.m. CST, several strong to severe storms were along and north of Interstate 80 from Lexington to Grand Island to Osceola. A couple of them became supercells. One supercell in particular produced most of the hail as it tracked from northern Adams County into southern Hamilton and York counties. Tennis ball to baseball size hail occurred near from near Hansen to Giltner to Trumbull. By 10 a.m. CST, it was all over. The storms hail had exited into eastern Nebraska.||South central Nebraska was in the cold sector. A cold front extended from the Great Lakes southwest across Kansas. High pressure was over the Northern Plains, while a low pressure center was making its way along the front over Kansas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough extended from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. A fairly potent shortwave trough was embedded within this cyclonic flow, just west of the region, and extended from Montana into Wyoming. These storms formed in an area of mid-level warm air advection around 700 mb and frontogenesis between 850 mb and 700 mb. Meanwhile, under the frontal surface, cold air advection was occurring with surface temperatures in the 50s. MUCAPE was between 500 and 1000 J/kg, and deep layer shear was around 40 knots.

Several damaging thunderstorms raked across portions of north central Kansas on this Thursday afternoon and evening. A small multicell cluster of thunderstorms developed along the Nebraska-Kansas state line and began moving into western Phillips County just before 3 p.m. CST. The leading storm intensified and became a supercell. This cluster moved southeast across portions of Rooks and Osborne counties through 5:30 p.m. CST, continuing to be anchored by the supercell. This supercell produced prolific amounts of hail along its path, covering the ground in some areas. The largest reported was the size of baseballs near the town of Speed, in Phillips County. Significant damage occurred to the roof, siding, windows, and several vehicles on one farm. Radar signatures strongly suggested this storm may have produced hail of similar size in other areas, but no reports were received due to low population. This storm also damaged trees in southwest Osborne County. Between 5 and 6 p.m. CST, a broken line of thunderstorms dropped out of Nebraska into north central Kansas. A couple of these storms were severe as well. One was a supercell that tracked through Phillips and Osborne counties, a little north of the previous storm. This storm produced hail to at least the size of golf balls. The other storm raked across Jewell county between 5:30 and 6:30 p.m. CST. This storm was responsible for multiple reports of measured winds in excess of 65 MPH, including one of 80 MPH. Hail was reported up to 1.5 inches in diameter. Wind driven hail broken windows in some homes on the north side of the town of Jewell.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures were in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the 50s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates were near 7 degrees C/km, resultant MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-200 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail reaching the size of baseballs resulted in significant damage to vehicles and homes in the area. Numerous windows and windshields were damaged or destroyed. There was extensive crop damage. Tree limbs up to 5 inches in diameter were downed, but an estimated wind speed was not available.
