EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late night thunderstorm brought severe wind to Scott county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two inch diameter tree branches were broken by the high wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving out of northern Kansas moved into a very unstable airmass during the late afternoon and evening.  In addition, an upper level wind maxima was moving across the plains.  Both features combined to produce thunderstorms, many which were severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water 4 to 5 inches deep was flowing across Highway 27.

Isolated thunderstorms developed across the southern Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of September 7th.  As the storms tracked to the southeast, some of the storms became severe and produced winds up to 60 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts of 60 MPH reported at this location.

A cold front dropped south into Central Kansas on the afternoon of September 7th, 2015.  Severe storms developed along this front across Central Kansas.  The multicell thunderstorms produced isolated reports of damaging wind gusts across Central Kansas. One such storm developed supercell characteristics as it moved southeast, producing damaging winds across Marion County, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was reported along Interstate 70.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a warm front in southern Lincoln County during the early evening hours of September 22nd. As the storms moved north toward North Platte, they became severe with wind gusts estimated at 60 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of a roof was blown off of a mobile home in southeast North Platte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a warm front in southern Lincoln County during the early evening hours of September 22nd. As the storms moved north toward North Platte, they became severe with wind gusts estimated at 60 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Off duty NWS Employee estimated wind gusts of 60 MPH on the south side of North Platte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a warm front in southern Lincoln County during the early evening hours of September 22nd. As the storms moved north toward North Platte, they became severe with wind gusts estimated at 60 MPH.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown onto a roof on the northeast side of North Platte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front dropped south into Central Kansas on the afternoon of September 7th, 2015.  Severe storms developed along this front across Central Kansas.  The multicell thunderstorms produced isolated reports of damaging wind gusts across Central Kansas. One such storm developed supercell characteristics as it moved southeast, producing damaging winds across Marion County, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported the gust.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The strong winds damaged a gutter on a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front dropped south into Central Kansas on the afternoon of September 7th, 2015.  Severe storms developed along this front across Central Kansas.  The multicell thunderstorms produced isolated reports of damaging wind gusts across Central Kansas. One such storm developed supercell characteristics as it moved southeast, producing damaging winds across Marion County, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm chaser estimated 55 to 65 mph winds. A stop sign was snapped off at the base.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several damaging thunderstorms raked across portions of north central Kansas on this Thursday afternoon and evening. A small multicell cluster of thunderstorms developed along the Nebraska-Kansas state line and began moving into western Phillips County just before 3 p.m. CST. The leading storm intensified and became a supercell. This cluster moved southeast across portions of Rooks and Osborne counties through 5:30 p.m. CST, continuing to be anchored by the supercell. This supercell produced prolific amounts of hail along its path, covering the ground in some areas. The largest reported was the size of baseballs near the town of Speed, in Phillips County. Significant damage occurred to the roof, siding, windows, and several vehicles on one farm. Radar signatures strongly suggested this storm may have produced hail of similar size in other areas, but no reports were received due to low population. This storm also damaged trees in southwest Osborne County. Between 5 and 6 p.m. CST, a broken line of thunderstorms dropped out of Nebraska into north central Kansas. A couple of these storms were severe as well. One was a supercell that tracked through Phillips and Osborne counties, a little north of the previous storm. This storm produced hail to at least the size of golf balls. The other storm raked across Jewell county between 5:30 and 6:30 p.m. CST. This storm was responsible for multiple reports of measured winds in excess of 65 MPH, including one of 80 MPH. Hail was reported up to 1.5 inches in diameter. Wind driven hail broken windows in some homes on the north side of the town of Jewell.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures were in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the 50s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates were near 7 degrees C/km, resultant MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-200 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail up to the size of golf balls resulted in vehicle damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very small area of wind damage occurred during the predawn hours on this Friday morning. Shortly after midnight, scattered showers and generally weak thunderstorms developed over south central Nebraska. Most of this activity occurred east of Highway 281, between 2 a.m. and 5 a.m. CST. The small storm that produced this damage moved into southwestern Hamilton County from northwestern Clay County shortly before 3 am CST. It was at 3 a.m. that a very small downburst occurred just southwest and west of Giltner. These were outflow winds immediately ahead of the storm. Grain bins were damaged as a result, with two having roofs pushed in. Another grain bin in a different but nearby location was removed from its location and deposited in a field. This downburst was very brief. Radar indicated strong outflow winds of 50 knots at the lowest elevation angle, at the time of the event, and there was no indication of these winds 5 minutes before or 5 minutes after.||These storms developed in an area of warm air advection associated with a 45 knot low-level jet, in the warm sector of low pressure over the Dakotas. A lee-side trough extended from this low across western Nebraska and Kansas. The flow aloft was moderately amplified with a ridge over the Plains and a trough along the West Coast. Mid-level winds were very weak over Nebraska, on the order of 5-10 knots. Surface temperatures were in the lower to middle 70s, with dewpoints in the 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were steep, nearly 8 deg C/km, resulting in MUCAPE around 1000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was a little less than 20 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in roof damage to a few grain bins west of Giltner.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hail at least the size of tennis balls fell over Thayer County on this Labor Day Monday. Scattered elevated showers, and a few embedded, weak thunderstorms, progressed through south central Nebraska during the morning and afternoon hours. Much of the area was cloudy through early afternoon, as low stratus lingered from the nighttime hours. Between noon and 1 p.m. CST, the southernmost thunderstorm emerged into Webster County. This storm rapidly intensified and became an isolated, classic supercell as it emerged from an area of cloudiness into sunshine and moved crossed Nuckolls and Thayer Counties. This area was the only portion of south central Nebraska that had seen prolonged sunshine. This storm produced very large hail over Thayer County, and those reports were on the fringe of the most intense core. Given the impressive radar signatures, hail larger than tennis balls may have fallen from west-to-east across central Thayer County. However, the core tracked just north of Highway 136, where population is extremely low. As the storm skirted to the north of Hebron, some wind damage occurred associated with the rear flank downdraft. This storm occurred early in the afternoon and exited Thayer county by 230 p.m. CST. Between 4 and 9 p.m. CST, other storms developed over south central Nebraska. While most were not severe, one storm that developed over Adams County produced hail up to the size of golf balls in Hastings.||South central Nebraska was behind a weak cold front that had moved through Sunday. As the day progressed, this front appeared to lift north back into Nebraska, as differential heating occurred between the cloudy and sunny areas. The equipment at the Hebron airport measured temperatures in the upper 80s and dewpoints in the lower 70s within the storm inflow. Combined with mid-level lapse rates between 7 and 7.5 deg C/km, the resulting MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. 0-3 km SRH was between 200 and 300 m2/s2, with deep layer shear 45 to 50 knots. Shear and instability were similar into the evening hours, even though temperatures had cooled into the middle 70s. In the upper-levels, a low was over the Canadian Prairies with a broad trough underneath over the Northern Rockies and Northern Plains. Nebraska was on the southern fringe of the Westerlies.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 65 MPH resulted in tree damage in Hebron.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the last of five significant severe hail events this month, in terms of size and the number of reports. Each of these events contained at least one report of 2 inch hail or greater. The uniqueness of this event was that it occurred during the morning hours on this Friday. Around 5 a.m. CST, scattered showers began to develop across much of south central Nebraska. Over the following couple hours, they increased in coverage and strengthened into thunderstorms. By 7:30 a.m. CST, several strong to severe storms were along and north of Interstate 80 from Lexington to Grand Island to Osceola. A couple of them became supercells. One supercell in particular produced most of the hail as it tracked from northern Adams County into southern Hamilton and York counties. Tennis ball to baseball size hail occurred near from near Hansen to Giltner to Trumbull. By 10 a.m. CST, it was all over. The storms hail had exited into eastern Nebraska.||South central Nebraska was in the cold sector. A cold front extended from the Great Lakes southwest across Kansas. High pressure was over the Northern Plains, while a low pressure center was making its way along the front over Kansas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough extended from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. A fairly potent shortwave trough was embedded within this cyclonic flow, just west of the region, and extended from Montana into Wyoming. These storms formed in an area of mid-level warm air advection around 700 mb and frontogenesis between 850 mb and 700 mb. Meanwhile, under the frontal surface, cold air advection was occurring with surface temperatures in the 50s. MUCAPE was between 500 and 1000 J/kg, and deep layer shear was around 40 knots.

A cold front moving out of northern Kansas moved into a very unstable airmass during the late afternoon and evening.  In addition, an upper level wind maxima was moving across the plains.  Both features combined to produce thunderstorms, many which were severe.

A cold front moving out of northern Kansas moved into a very unstable airmass during the late afternoon and evening.  In addition, an upper level wind maxima was moving across the plains.  Both features combined to produce thunderstorms, many which were severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail accumulated to a depth of more than 4 inches.  Also, three inches of rain fell resulting in local flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall of 3 inches fell during the period resulting in minor local flooding.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs of up to five inches in diameter were broken.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One EF0 tornado occurred too.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Damage survey revealed minor hedge row tree damage and one power pole broken near beginning of path.  Circulation then traveled over pastureland into non-accessible area of Shawnee County where dual pol radar showed a weak damage or debris signature approx. 2 miles southeast of start point.  The tornado continued southeast to cause tree damage including snapped trunk of large trees and causing minor roof damage to a home at 109th street 1 mile east of Carlson Road before lifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One EF0 tornado occurred too.

A cold front dropped south into Central Kansas on the afternoon of September 7th, 2015.  Severe storms developed along this front across Central Kansas.  The multicell thunderstorms produced isolated reports of damaging wind gusts across Central Kansas. One such storm developed supercell characteristics as it moved southeast, producing damaging winds across Marion County, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs were reported down in town. Some minor awning damage occurred to a house. Reported via Kake TV on Twitter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front dropped south into Central Kansas on the afternoon of September 7th, 2015.  Severe storms developed along this front across Central Kansas.  The multicell thunderstorms produced isolated reports of damaging wind gusts across Central Kansas. One such storm developed supercell characteristics as it moved southeast, producing damaging winds across Marion County, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A swing set was ripped from its concrete foundation. Three inch tree limbs were also reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front dropped south across portions of Central Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of September 10th, 2015.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along this front across Central Kansas, and produced reports of large hail and damaging winds. The storms eventually propagated southeast as a complex of storms as it moved across the Flint Hills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported the hail.

In the upper-levels, a low was over the Canadian Prairies with a broad trough underneath over the Northern Rockies and Northern Plains. Nebraska was on the southern fringe of the Westerlies.

Several storms produced prolific amounts of hail on this Wednesday. Thunderstorm activity was continuous, in some shape or form, from late morning all the way through midnight. The hailers began early, as a short line segment of individual storms developed over Custer and Dawson counties. The southernmost storms in this line produced some one inch hail over northeast Dawson and northwest Buffalo counties just prior to noon. Those storm gradually dissipated during the early afternoon hours, but other very isolated storms did form behind the dissipating storms through mid-afternoon. By 5 p.m. CST, three discrete storms were in progress over parts of Valley, Sherman, and Buffalo counties. They had intensified, become supercells, and were severe. These storms propagated southeastward over the following couple hours, affecting parts of Howard, Hall, and Hamilton counties as well. Each of these storms produced swaths of hail up to the size of golf balls. Some storms produced so much hail that the ground appeared white. A mesonet site in Farwell, in western Howard County, measured winds of 59 MPH as well. Another line of multicell storms formed from northwest to southeast behind these storms. The strongest storm within this line developed over Howard County around 9 p.m. CST. It tracked southeast from near St. Paul, across Aurora, and all the way down to Hebron, exiting Thayer County shortly after midnight. This storm produced one inch hail in several locations along its path. Cell training resulted in a swath of two to three inches of rain across Valley, Howard, Merrick, northern Hamilton, and York counties. The highest total was 2.90 in Scotia, in Greeley County. One of the isolated storms that developed in the middle of the afternoon was a slow-moving supercell (right-mover) that propagated into Furnas County. As this storm headed southeast, another small storm briefly developed and moved into the northwest corner of the county before dissipating. Both of these storms affected the Cambridge area between 3 p.m. and 4:45 p.m. CST, dropping two to three inches of rain. This resulted in a flash flood, with several inches of water flowing across Highway 6.||Given the sustained and persistent thunderstorm activity, the lack of forcing was very surprising. A modified continental air mass was in place. Weak high pressure was over the region to begin the day. As the high departed, a surface trough migrated into Nebraska, ahead of a strong cold front that was dropping through the Dakotas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough was over the central United States. The band of Westerlies was north of Nebraska, associated with the approaching front. There was a weak shortwave trough approaching by early evening, but it was still upstream over Montana and Wyoming. During peak heating, surface temperatures were in the 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were poor, but despite this MLCAPE varied between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 45-50 kts, with 0-3 km SRH 150-250 m2/s2. This shear was more than sufficient for the observed mixture of multicell and supercell convective modes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the last of five significant severe hail events this month, in terms of size and the number of reports. Each of these events contained at least one report of 2 inch hail or greater. The uniqueness of this event was that it occurred during the morning hours on this Friday. Around 5 a.m. CST, scattered showers began to develop across much of south central Nebraska. Over the following couple hours, they increased in coverage and strengthened into thunderstorms. By 7:30 a.m. CST, several strong to severe storms were along and north of Interstate 80 from Lexington to Grand Island to Osceola. A couple of them became supercells. One supercell in particular produced most of the hail as it tracked from northern Adams County into southern Hamilton and York counties. Tennis ball to baseball size hail occurred near from near Hansen to Giltner to Trumbull. By 10 a.m. CST, it was all over. The storms hail had exited into eastern Nebraska.||South central Nebraska was in the cold sector. A cold front extended from the Great Lakes southwest across Kansas. High pressure was over the Northern Plains, while a low pressure center was making its way along the front over Kansas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough extended from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. A fairly potent shortwave trough was embedded within this cyclonic flow, just west of the region, and extended from Montana into Wyoming. These storms formed in an area of mid-level warm air advection around 700 mb and frontogenesis between 850 mb and 700 mb. Meanwhile, under the frontal surface, cold air advection was occurring with surface temperatures in the 50s. MUCAPE was between 500 and 1000 J/kg, and deep layer shear was around 40 knots.

A cold front moving out of northern Kansas moved into a very unstable airmass during the late afternoon and evening.  In addition, an upper level wind maxima was moving across the plains.  Both features combined to produce thunderstorms, many which were severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Winds were estimated to be 60 MPH.

An isolated severe thunderstorm brought large hail to parts of Barber county.
One EF0 tornado occurred too.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail cracked storm windows on the north side of the house. Estimated winds at least 50 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front dropped south across portions of Central Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of September 10th, 2015.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along this front across Central Kansas, and produced reports of large hail and damaging winds. The storms eventually propagated southeast as a complex of storms as it moved across the Flint Hills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eighty percent of the roof was blown off the gymnasium at Lincoln Elementary.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Roof damage occurred to a nursing home.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter estimated 65 to 70 mph wind with pea to dime size hail.

Each of these storms produced swaths of hail up to the size of golf balls. Some storms produced so much hail that the ground appeared white. A mesonet site in Farwell, in western Howard County, measured winds of 59 MPH as well. Another line of multicell storms formed from northwest to southeast behind these storms. The strongest storm within this line developed over Howard County around 9 p.m. CST. It tracked southeast from near St. Paul, across Aurora, and all the way down to Hebron, exiting Thayer County shortly after midnight. This storm produced one inch hail in several locations along its path. Cell training resulted in a swath of two to three inches of rain across Valley, Howard, Merrick, northern Hamilton, and York counties. The highest total was 2.90 in Scotia, in Greeley County. One of the isolated storms that developed in the middle of the afternoon was a slow-moving supercell (right-mover) that propagated into Furnas County. As this storm headed southeast, another small storm briefly developed and moved into the northwest corner of the county before dissipating. Both of these storms affected the Cambridge area between 3 p.m. and 4:45 p.m. CST, dropping two to three inches of rain. This resulted in a flash flood, with several inches of water flowing across Highway 6.||Given the sustained and persistent thunderstorm activity, the lack of forcing was very surprising. A modified continental air mass was in place. Weak high pressure was over the region to begin the day. As the high departed, a surface trough migrated into Nebraska, ahead of a strong cold front that was dropping through the Dakotas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough was over the central United States. The band of Westerlies was north of Nebraska, associated with the approaching front. There was a weak shortwave trough approaching by early evening, but it was still upstream over Montana and Wyoming. During peak heating, surface temperatures were in the 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were poor, but despite this MLCAPE varied between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 45-50 kts, with 0-3 km SRH 150-250 m2/s2. This shear was more than sufficient for the observed mixture of multicell and supercell convective modes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather was widespread across south central Nebraska on this Thursday afternoon and evening, mainly south of Highway 6. This was the second day in a row of numerous thunderstorms that produce prolific amounts of severe hail. Just as with the previous day, scattered thunderstorms developed early. Some were isolated single cells while other were organized into broken lines that still exhibited some cell individuality. By mid afternoon, one of these lines had organized from west to east across most of Dawson and Buffalo counties. This line moved southeast and expanded during the subsequent hours. By 6:30 p.m. CST, the most intense portion of the line had exited into northern Kansas. There were a couple isolated storms that formed ahead of this line. Most of the severe weather occurred south of Highway 6 with these isolated cells as well as within the line, between the times of 3 and 6 p.m. CST. Several storms produced severe hail, but the largest hail occurred with discrete supercells that produced tennis ball size hail in Furnas County and three inch hail over Thayer County. Damage reported was severe with the Thayer County storm. Vehicles were dented, windows were broken, vinyl siding was damaged, and crops were decimated. There was so much hail with some of these storms, that the ground was turned white. The storm over Webster County contained strong winds which were measured as high as 69 MPH.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures had climbed into the lower 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates had increased from the day before and were between 7 and 7.5 degrees C/km, resulting in MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-250 m2/s2.

By 6:30 p.m. CST, the most intense portion of the line had exited into northern Kansas. There were a couple isolated storms that formed ahead of this line. Most of the severe weather occurred south of Highway 6 with these isolated cells as well as within the line, between the times of 3 and 6 p.m. CST. Several storms produced severe hail, but the largest hail occurred with discrete supercells that produced tennis ball size hail in Furnas County and three inch hail over Thayer County. Damage reported was severe with the Thayer County storm. Vehicles were dented, windows were broken, vinyl siding was damaged, and crops were decimated. There was so much hail with some of these storms, that the ground was turned white. The storm over Webster County contained strong winds which were measured as high as 69 MPH.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures had climbed into the lower 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates had increased from the day before and were between 7 and 7.5 degrees C/km, resulting in MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-250 m2/s2.

Severe weather was widespread across south central Nebraska on this Thursday afternoon and evening, mainly south of Highway 6. This was the second day in a row of numerous thunderstorms that produce prolific amounts of severe hail. Just as with the previous day, scattered thunderstorms developed early. Some were isolated single cells while other were organized into broken lines that still exhibited some cell individuality. By mid afternoon, one of these lines had organized from west to east across most of Dawson and Buffalo counties. This line moved southeast and expanded during the subsequent hours. By 6:30 p.m. CST, the most intense portion of the line had exited into northern Kansas. There were a couple isolated storms that formed ahead of this line. Most of the severe weather occurred south of Highway 6 with these isolated cells as well as within the line, between the times of 3 and 6 p.m. CST. Several storms produced severe hail, but the largest hail occurred with discrete supercells that produced tennis ball size hail in Furnas County and three inch hail over Thayer County. Damage reported was severe with the Thayer County storm. Vehicles were dented, windows were broken, vinyl siding was damaged, and crops were decimated. There was so much hail with some of these storms, that the ground was turned white. The storm over Webster County contained strong winds which were measured as high as 69 MPH.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures had climbed into the lower 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates had increased from the day before and were between 7 and 7.5 degrees C/km, resulting in MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-250 m2/s2.

This was the second day in a row of numerous thunderstorms that produce prolific amounts of severe hail. Just as with the previous day, scattered thunderstorms developed early. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Some wind damage occurred in Lexington on this Tuesday afternoon. Early in the afternoon, scattered showers developed over northwest Kansas. They expanded into portions of south central Nebraska as the afternoon progressed, becoming a northeast-southwest oriented line. Some of the showers intensified into what appeared to be weak thunderstorms. The storm that produced the damage in Lexington was a small storm that formed over northern Gosper County around 3:45 p.m. CST, just ahead of the line. This storm crossed the border into Dawson County and produced the damage around 4:10 p.m. CST, not long after it formed. Some large tree limbs were snapped off, resulting in power outages. One tree was uprooted at Greenwood Cemetery.||South central Nebraska was in the warm sector of low pressure located along the Montana-North Dakota border. The circulation around this low had forced the lee-side trough eastward into central South Dakota, Nebraska, and western Kansas. These showers and storms formed along this trough. In the upper-levels, southwest flow was over the Central Plains, with a trough along the Pacific Northwest Coast and a ridge over the eastern United States. The band main of Westerlies was over the west. Winds aloft over the Central Plains were fairly weak. Just before the storm moved through, the temperature at the Lexington airport was in the middle 90s with dewpoints in the 50s. Despite steep mid-levels lapse rates, the deeply mixed boundary layer limited MLCAPE to just under 1000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was marginal, approaching 30 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts estimated to be near 60 MPH resulted in tree damage in the area, with some limbs upwards of 6 to 8 inches in diameter. Power outages were reported in Lexington.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced an isolated, solitary severe wind gust on this Wednesday evening. A mesoscale convective vortex formed from thunderstorms over western Kansas and southwest Nebraska the prior night. This vortex headed northeast into the Nebraska Sandhills during the day. New thunderstorms developed in the sunshine in the southwest quadrant of this vortex. They expanded and marched across most of south central Nebraska, north of Interstate 80. One of these storms produced a highly localized wind gust of 67 MPH at the Central Nebraska Regional Airport in Grand Island around mid-evening. A row of plastic jersey barriers was blown over at the airport, but it was unknown if they were weighted down.||A modified continental polar air mass encompassed the United States east of the Rockies, with high pressure over eastern Canada. By late afternoon, the lee-side trough did migrate east into central Nebraska. Aloft, the Westerlies were displaced far to the north, over southern Canada. A weak trough was over Wyoming and Colorado. Temperatures were in the lower 70s and dewpoints were in the lower 60s as the storm approached Grand Island; temperatures remained cool all day under extensive cloud cover with scattered showers. MUCAPE was just under 500 J/kg and deep layer shear was around 25 knots. So, conditions were not very favorable for severe thunderstorms, but this storm still produced a severe wind gust.

This was the last of five significant severe hail events this month, in terms of size and the number of reports. Each of these events contained at least one report of 2 inch hail or greater. The uniqueness of this event was that it occurred during the morning hours on this Friday. Around 5 a.m. CST, scattered showers began to develop across much of south central Nebraska. Over the following couple hours, they increased in coverage and strengthened into thunderstorms. By 7:30 a.m. CST, several strong to severe storms were along and north of Interstate 80 from Lexington to Grand Island to Osceola. A couple of them became supercells. One supercell in particular produced most of the hail as it tracked from northern Adams County into southern Hamilton and York counties. Tennis ball to baseball size hail occurred near from near Hansen to Giltner to Trumbull. By 10 a.m. CST, it was all over. The storms hail had exited into eastern Nebraska.||South central Nebraska was in the cold sector. A cold front extended from the Great Lakes southwest across Kansas. High pressure was over the Northern Plains, while a low pressure center was making its way along the front over Kansas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough extended from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. A fairly potent shortwave trough was embedded within this cyclonic flow, just west of the region, and extended from Montana into Wyoming. These storms formed in an area of mid-level warm air advection around 700 mb and frontogenesis between 850 mb and 700 mb. Meanwhile, under the frontal surface, cold air advection was occurring with surface temperatures in the 50s. MUCAPE was between 500 and 1000 J/kg, and deep layer shear was around 40 knots.

A cold front dropped south across portions of Central Kansas during the afternoon and evening hours of September 10th, 2015.  Showers and thunderstorms developed along this front across Central Kansas, and produced reports of large hail and damaging winds. The storms eventually propagated southeast as a complex of storms as it moved across the Flint Hills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail was described as golf ball size. Storm chaser lost his windshield with estimated 70 mph winds.

The storms eventually propagated southeast as a complex of storms as it moved across the Flint Hills.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Measured by a Davis Weather station at the Barton County Landfill.

Moisture pooled along a stalled frontal boundary near the Kansas and Nebraska border. The moisture combined with steep lapse rates to create moderate instability along this boundary during the afternoon and evening hours. Scattered thunderstorms developed along this boundary by mid afternoon and continued into the evening hours as an upper level disturbance moved into the central Plains. One storm in particular moved along the Kansas and Nebraska border and produced sporadic significant severe in the form of very large hail and damaging winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving out of northern Kansas moved into a very unstable airmass during the late afternoon and evening.  In addition, an upper level wind maxima was moving across the plains.  Both features combined to produce thunderstorms, many which were severe.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pictures on social media indicate hail up to baseball size in the city of Fairbury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon and evening over Sherman and western Thomas counties.  Large hail up to half dollar in size was reported 5 E of Goodland.  This same storm produced the strongest wind gust, with an estimated speed of 85 MPH 8 E of Goodland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The storm chaser also reported blowing dust and reduced visibilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.

On the afternoon and evening of the 7th scattered storms developed. A few of these storms were severe causing wind damage. These storms turned into an area of heavy rain which caused urban flooding in some locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding reported along Alabama between 23rd and 25th and Bob Billings between Iowa and the Orchards golf course.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon and evening of the 7th scattered storms developed. A few of these storms were severe causing wind damage. These storms turned into an area of heavy rain which caused urban flooding in some locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flash flooding at Gage on the Shunganunga creek which exceeded the 15 ft flood stage. Other flooding was reported in Topeka including stalled vehicles and flooding of the railroad underpass at 2nd and Golden.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures started the month of September across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. As the upper level ridge of high pressure started to break down as a storm system moved across the northern Plains, a cold front moved into the area. With the hot and humid conditions ahead of the front, strong instability developed across the area. Thunderstorms developed along the front during the late afternoon and continued into the overnight hours. Some of these storms were severe producing large hail and damaging winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moisture returned to eastern Nebraska ahead of a slow moving cold front. The increasing low-level moisture combined with cool temperatures aloft to create moderate instability across the area during the afternoon and into the overnight hours. Seasonably strong shear combined with the developing instability to create an atmosphere favorable for isolated severe weather. Thunderstorms developed over northeast Nebraska by mid afternoon and slowly sank southward through the evening and overnight hours, sporadically producing severe weather.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of upper level low pressure slowly moved across the central Plains during the September 22nd through the 23rd time frame. Significant moisture was in place across the mid Missouri River Valley ahead of this system. This combination led to scattered to numerous thunderstorms over eastern Nebraska and western Iowa starting on the 22nd and continuing into the day on the 23rd. The heavy persistent thunderstorms, especially late in the night and into the early morning hours on the 23rd led to significant flash flooding across parts of western Iowa, specifically in Council Bluffs.

Hail at least the size of tennis balls fell over Thayer County on this Labor Day Monday. Scattered elevated showers, and a few embedded, weak thunderstorms, progressed through south central Nebraska during the morning and afternoon hours. Much of the area was cloudy through early afternoon, as low stratus lingered from the nighttime hours. Between noon and 1 p.m. CST, the southernmost thunderstorm emerged into Webster County. This storm rapidly intensified and became an isolated, classic supercell as it emerged from an area of cloudiness into sunshine and moved crossed Nuckolls and Thayer Counties. This area was the only portion of south central Nebraska that had seen prolonged sunshine. This storm produced very large hail over Thayer County, and those reports were on the fringe of the most intense core. Given the impressive radar signatures, hail larger than tennis balls may have fallen from west-to-east across central Thayer County. However, the core tracked just north of Highway 136, where population is extremely low. As the storm skirted to the north of Hebron, some wind damage occurred associated with the rear flank downdraft. This storm occurred early in the afternoon and exited Thayer county by 230 p.m. CST. Between 4 and 9 p.m. CST, other storms developed over south central Nebraska. While most were not severe, one storm that developed over Adams County produced hail up to the size of golf balls in Hastings.||South central Nebraska was behind a weak cold front that had moved through Sunday. As the day progressed, this front appeared to lift north back into Nebraska, as differential heating occurred between the cloudy and sunny areas. The equipment at the Hebron airport measured temperatures in the upper 80s and dewpoints in the lower 70s within the storm inflow. Combined with mid-level lapse rates between 7 and 7.5 deg C/km, the resulting MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. 0-3 km SRH was between 200 and 300 m2/s2, with deep layer shear 45 to 50 knots. Shear and instability were similar into the evening hours, even though temperatures had cooled into the middle 70s. In the upper-levels, a low was over the Canadian Prairies with a broad trough underneath over the Northern Rockies and Northern Plains. Nebraska was on the southern fringe of the Westerlies.

Several storms produced prolific amounts of hail on this Wednesday. Thunderstorm activity was continuous, in some shape or form, from late morning all the way through midnight. The hailers began early, as a short line segment of individual storms developed over Custer and Dawson counties. The southernmost storms in this line produced some one inch hail over northeast Dawson and northwest Buffalo counties just prior to noon. Those storm gradually dissipated during the early afternoon hours, but other very isolated storms did form behind the dissipating storms through mid-afternoon. By 5 p.m. CST, three discrete storms were in progress over parts of Valley, Sherman, and Buffalo counties. They had intensified, become supercells, and were severe. These storms propagated southeastward over the following couple hours, affecting parts of Howard, Hall, and Hamilton counties as well. Each of these storms produced swaths of hail up to the size of golf balls. Some storms produced so much hail that the ground appeared white. A mesonet site in Farwell, in western Howard County, measured winds of 59 MPH as well. Another line of multicell storms formed from northwest to southeast behind these storms. The strongest storm within this line developed over Howard County around 9 p.m. CST. It tracked southeast from near St. Paul, across Aurora, and all the way down to Hebron, exiting Thayer County shortly after midnight. This storm produced one inch hail in several locations along its path. Cell training resulted in a swath of two to three inches of rain across Valley, Howard, Merrick, northern Hamilton, and York counties. The highest total was 2.90 in Scotia, in Greeley County. One of the isolated storms that developed in the middle of the afternoon was a slow-moving supercell (right-mover) that propagated into Furnas County. As this storm headed southeast, another small storm briefly developed and moved into the northwest corner of the county before dissipating. Both of these storms affected the Cambridge area between 3 p.m. and 4:45 p.m. CST, dropping two to three inches of rain. This resulted in a flash flood, with several inches of water flowing across Highway 6.||Given the sustained and persistent thunderstorm activity, the lack of forcing was very surprising. A modified continental air mass was in place. Weak high pressure was over the region to begin the day. As the high departed, a surface trough migrated into Nebraska, ahead of a strong cold front that was dropping through the Dakotas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough was over the central United States. The band of Westerlies was north of Nebraska, associated with the approaching front. There was a weak shortwave trough approaching by early evening, but it was still upstream over Montana and Wyoming. During peak heating, surface temperatures were in the 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were poor, but despite this MLCAPE varied between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 45-50 kts, with 0-3 km SRH 150-250 m2/s2. This shear was more than sufficient for the observed mixture of multicell and supercell convective modes.

In the upper-levels, a broad trough was over the central United States. The band of Westerlies was north of Nebraska, associated with the approaching front. There was a weak shortwave trough approaching by early evening, but it was still upstream over Montana and Wyoming. During peak heating, surface temperatures were in the 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were poor, but despite this MLCAPE varied between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 45-50 kts, with 0-3 km SRH 150-250 m2/s2. This shear was more than sufficient for the observed mixture of multicell and supercell convective modes.

Several storms produced prolific amounts of hail on this Wednesday. Thunderstorm activity was continuous, in some shape or form, from late morning all the way through midnight. The hailers began early, as a short line segment of individual storms developed over Custer and Dawson counties. The southernmost storms in this line produced some one inch hail over northeast Dawson and northwest Buffalo counties just prior to noon. Those storm gradually dissipated during the early afternoon hours, but other very isolated storms did form behind the dissipating storms through mid-afternoon. By 5 p.m. CST, three discrete storms were in progress over parts of Valley, Sherman, and Buffalo counties. They had intensified, become supercells, and were severe. These storms propagated southeastward over the following couple hours, affecting parts of Howard, Hall, and Hamilton counties as well. Each of these storms produced swaths of hail up to the size of golf balls. Some storms produced so much hail that the ground appeared white. A mesonet site in Farwell, in western Howard County, measured winds of 59 MPH as well. Another line of multicell storms formed from northwest to southeast behind these storms. The strongest storm within this line developed over Howard County around 9 p.m. CST. It tracked southeast from near St. Paul, across Aurora, and all the way down to Hebron, exiting Thayer County shortly after midnight. This storm produced one inch hail in several locations along its path. Cell training resulted in a swath of two to three inches of rain across Valley, Howard, Merrick, northern Hamilton, and York counties. The highest total was 2.90 in Scotia, in Greeley County. One of the isolated storms that developed in the middle of the afternoon was a slow-moving supercell (right-mover) that propagated into Furnas County. As this storm headed southeast, another small storm briefly developed and moved into the northwest corner of the county before dissipating. Both of these storms affected the Cambridge area between 3 p.m. and 4:45 p.m. CST, dropping two to three inches of rain. This resulted in a flash flood, with several inches of water flowing across Highway 6.||Given the sustained and persistent thunderstorm activity, the lack of forcing was very surprising. A modified continental air mass was in place. Weak high pressure was over the region to begin the day. As the high departed, a surface trough migrated into Nebraska, ahead of a strong cold front that was dropping through the Dakotas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough was over the central United States. The band of Westerlies was north of Nebraska, associated with the approaching front. There was a weak shortwave trough approaching by early evening, but it was still upstream over Montana and Wyoming. During peak heating, surface temperatures were in the 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were poor, but despite this MLCAPE varied between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 45-50 kts, with 0-3 km SRH 150-250 m2/s2. This shear was more than sufficient for the observed mixture of multicell and supercell convective modes.

Moisture returned to eastern Nebraska ahead of a slow moving cold front. The increasing low-level moisture combined with cool temperatures aloft to create moderate instability across the area during the afternoon and into the overnight hours. Seasonably strong shear combined with the developing instability to create an atmosphere favorable for isolated severe weather. Thunderstorms developed over northeast Nebraska by mid afternoon and slowly sank southward through the evening and overnight hours, sporadically producing severe weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The emergency manager reported significant damage in the town of Wymore. Damage included a couple of destroyed garages, widespread tree damage, and downed power lines. Images from the city indicates isolated pockets of winds to near 80 mph. There was also siding and roof damage from the wind driven small hail that drifted to several inches deep.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms develop during the early morning hours of September 14th associated with a nocturnal low-level jet and moisture return to the central and northern Plains. Although the far majority of these remained below severe limits, one thunderstorm briefing became severe during the morning before all the thunderstorms dissipated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The report indicated that the hail lasted for 10 min in duration.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent short-wave trough moving across the northern Plains allowed for a cold front to sweep through eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the morning on September 18th. Ahead of the cold front warm and moist was pulled northward on a strong low level jet. Scattered showers and thunderstorms occurred overnight, but as the system approached during the morning, these thunderstorms increased in coverage and intensity as they moved east producing mainly large hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported the hail at 56th and O Streets in Lincoln.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.
A thunderstorm produced large hail in southwest Sioux County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter size hail was reported 18 miles southwest of Agate.

Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Several storms produced prolific amounts of hail on this Wednesday. Thunderstorm activity was continuous, in some shape or form, from late morning all the way through midnight. The hailers began early, as a short line segment of individual storms developed over Custer and Dawson counties. The southernmost storms in this line produced some one inch hail over northeast Dawson and northwest Buffalo counties just prior to noon. Those storm gradually dissipated during the early afternoon hours, but other very isolated storms did form behind the dissipating storms through mid-afternoon. By 5 p.m. CST, three discrete storms were in progress over parts of Valley, Sherman, and Buffalo counties. They had intensified, become supercells, and were severe. These storms propagated southeastward over the following couple hours, affecting parts of Howard, Hall, and Hamilton counties as well. Each of these storms produced swaths of hail up to the size of golf balls. Some storms produced so much hail that the ground appeared white. A mesonet site in Farwell, in western Howard County, measured winds of 59 MPH as well. Another line of multicell storms formed from northwest to southeast behind these storms. The strongest storm within this line developed over Howard County around 9 p.m. CST. It tracked southeast from near St. Paul, across Aurora, and all the way down to Hebron, exiting Thayer County shortly after midnight. This storm produced one inch hail in several locations along its path. Cell training resulted in a swath of two to three inches of rain across Valley, Howard, Merrick, northern Hamilton, and York counties. The highest total was 2.90 in Scotia, in Greeley County. One of the isolated storms that developed in the middle of the afternoon was a slow-moving supercell (right-mover) that propagated into Furnas County. As this storm headed southeast, another small storm briefly developed and moved into the northwest corner of the county before dissipating. Both of these storms affected the Cambridge area between 3 p.m. and 4:45 p.m. CST, dropping two to three inches of rain. This resulted in a flash flood, with several inches of water flowing across Highway 6.||Given the sustained and persistent thunderstorm activity, the lack of forcing was very surprising. As the high departed, a surface trough migrated into Nebraska, ahead of a strong cold front that was dropping through the Dakotas. By 5 p.m. CST, three discrete storms were in progress over parts of Valley, Sherman, and Buffalo counties. They had intensified, become supercells, and were severe. These storms propagated southeastward over the following couple hours, affecting parts of Howard, Hall, and Hamilton counties as well. Each of these storms produced swaths of hail up to the size of golf balls. Some storms produced so much hail that the ground appeared white. A mesonet site in Farwell, in western Howard County, measured winds of 59 MPH as well. Another line of multicell storms formed from northwest to southeast behind these storms. The strongest storm within this line developed over Howard County around 9 p.m. CST. It tracked southeast from near St. Paul, across Aurora, and all the way down to Hebron, exiting Thayer County shortly after midnight. This storm produced one inch hail in several locations along its path. Cell training resulted in a swath of two to three inches of rain across Valley, Howard, Merrick, northern Hamilton, and York counties. The highest total was 2.90 in Scotia, in Greeley County. One of the isolated storms that developed in the middle of the afternoon was a slow-moving supercell (right-mover) that propagated into Furnas County. As this storm headed southeast, another small storm briefly developed and moved into the northwest corner of the county before dissipating. Both of these storms affected the Cambridge area between 3 p.m. and 4:45 p.m. CST, dropping two to three inches of rain. This resulted in a flash flood, with several inches of water flowing across Highway 6.||Given the sustained and persistent thunderstorm activity, the lack of forcing was very surprising. A modified continental air mass was in place. Weak high pressure was over the region to begin the day. As the high departed, a surface trough migrated into Nebraska, ahead of a strong cold front that was dropping through the Dakotas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough was over the central United States. The band of Westerlies was north of Nebraska, associated with the approaching front. There was a weak shortwave trough approaching by early evening, but it was still upstream over Montana and Wyoming. During peak heating, surface temperatures were in the 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates were poor, but despite this MLCAPE varied between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 45-50 kts, with 0-3 km SRH 150-250 m2/s2. This shear was more than sufficient for the observed mixture of multicell and supercell convective modes.

Severe weather was widespread across south central Nebraska on this Thursday afternoon and evening, mainly south of Highway 6. This was the second day in a row of numerous thunderstorms that produce prolific amounts of severe hail. Just as with the previous day, scattered thunderstorms developed early. Some were isolated single cells while other were organized into broken lines that still exhibited some cell individuality. By mid afternoon, one of these lines had organized from west to east across most of Dawson and Buffalo counties. This line moved southeast and expanded during the subsequent hours. By 6:30 p.m. CST, the most intense portion of the line had exited into northern Kansas. There were a couple isolated storms that formed ahead of this line. Most of the severe weather occurred south of Highway 6 with these isolated cells as well as within the line, between the times of 3 and 6 p.m. CST. Several storms produced severe hail, but the largest hail occurred with discrete supercells that produced tennis ball size hail in Furnas County and three inch hail over Thayer County. Damage reported was severe with the Thayer County storm. Vehicles were dented, windows were broken, vinyl siding was damaged, and crops were decimated. There was so much hail with some of these storms, that the ground was turned white. The storm over Webster County contained strong winds which were measured as high as 69 MPH.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures had climbed into the lower 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates had increased from the day before and were between 7 and 7.5 degrees C/km, resulting in MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-250 m2/s2.

The storm over Webster County contained strong winds which were measured as high as 69 MPH.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures had climbed into the lower 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates had increased from the day before and were between 7 and 7.5 degrees C/km, resulting in MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-250 m2/s2.

Severe weather was widespread across south central Nebraska on this Thursday afternoon and evening, mainly south of Highway 6. This was the second day in a row of numerous thunderstorms that produce prolific amounts of severe hail. Just as with the previous day, scattered thunderstorms developed early. Some were isolated single cells while other were organized into broken lines that still exhibited some cell individuality. By mid afternoon, one of these lines had organized from west to east across most of Dawson and Buffalo counties. This line moved southeast and expanded during the subsequent hours. By 6:30 p.m. CST, the most intense portion of the line had exited into northern Kansas. There were a couple isolated storms that formed ahead of this line. Most of the severe weather occurred south of Highway 6 with these isolated cells as well as within the line, between the times of 3 and 6 p.m. CST. Several storms produced severe hail, but the largest hail occurred with discrete supercells that produced tennis ball size hail in Furnas County and three inch hail over Thayer County. Damage reported was severe with the Thayer County storm. Vehicles were dented, windows were broken, vinyl siding was damaged, and crops were decimated. There was so much hail with some of these storms, that the ground was turned white. The storm over Webster County contained strong winds which were measured as high as 69 MPH.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures had climbed into the lower 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 50s and lower 60s. Mid-level lapse rates had increased from the day before and were between 7 and 7.5 degrees C/km, resulting in MLCAPE was between 1500 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 40-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-250 m2/s2.

Several damaging thunderstorms raked across portions of north central Kansas on this Thursday afternoon and evening. A small multicell cluster of thunderstorms developed along the Nebraska-Kansas state line and began moving into western Phillips County just before 3 p.m. CST. The leading storm intensified and became a supercell. This cluster moved southeast across portions of Rooks and Osborne counties through 5:30 p.m. CST, continuing to be anchored by the supercell. This supercell produced prolific amounts of hail along its path, covering the ground in some areas. The largest reported was the size of baseballs near the town of Speed, in Phillips County. Significant damage occurred to the roof, siding, windows, and several vehicles on one farm. Radar signatures strongly suggested this storm may have produced hail of similar size in other areas, but no reports were received due to low population. This storm also damaged trees in southwest Osborne County. Between 5 and 6 p.m. CST, a broken line of thunderstorms dropped out of Nebraska into north central Kansas. A couple of these storms were severe as well. One was a supercell that tracked through Phillips and Osborne counties, a little north of the previous storm. This storm produced hail to at least the size of golf balls. The other storm raked across Jewell county between 5:30 and 6:30 p.m. CST. This storm was responsible for multiple reports of measured winds in excess of 65 MPH, including one of 80 MPH. Hail was reported up to 1.5 inches in diameter. Wind driven hail broken windows in some homes on the north side of the town of Jewell.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures were in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the 50s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates were near 7 degrees C/km, resultant MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-200 m2/s2.

A potent short-wave trough moving across the northern Plains allowed for a cold front to sweep through eastern Nebraska and western Iowa during the morning on September 18th. Ahead of the cold front warm and moist was pulled northward on a strong low level jet. Scattered showers and thunderstorms occurred overnight, but as the system approached during the morning, these thunderstorms increased in coverage and intensity as they moved east producing mainly large hail.

A cold front slowly moving through eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa produced a couple of isolated thunderstorms during the evening on September 17th. The thunderstorms, largely non-severe, persisted for a couple of hours during the evening before the cold front pushed into northeast Kansas and northwest Missouri ending the thunderstorm threat.

Very hot temperatures started the month of September across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. As the upper level ridge of high pressure started to break down as a storm system moved across the northern Plains, a cold front moved into the area. With the hot and humid conditions ahead of the front, strong instability developed across the area. Thunderstorms developed along the front during the late afternoon and continued into the overnight hours. Some of these storms were severe producing large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of large hail, some as big a tennis balls were received, mainly from social media, but also from spotters within the city of Lincoln. The largest hail fell on the southeast side of the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures started the month of September across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. As the upper level ridge of high pressure started to break down as a storm system moved across the northern Plains, a cold front moved into the area. With the hot and humid conditions ahead of the front, strong instability developed across the area. Thunderstorms developed along the front during the late afternoon and continued into the overnight hours. Some of these storms were severe producing large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports were received from social media and the broadcast media of wind damage in the city of Lincoln. The damage was mainly to trees, but some structural damage was also reported to a manufactured home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures started the month of September across eastern Nebraska and western Iowa. As the upper level ridge of high pressure started to break down as a storm system moved across the northern Plains, a cold front moved into the area. With the hot and humid conditions ahead of the front, strong instability developed across the area. Thunderstorms developed along the front during the late afternoon and continued into the overnight hours. Some of these storms were severe producing large hail and damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter estimated winds to near 60 mph, and there were tree branches blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several damaging thunderstorms raked across portions of north central Kansas on this Thursday afternoon and evening. A small multicell cluster of thunderstorms developed along the Nebraska-Kansas state line and began moving into western Phillips County just before 3 p.m. CST. The leading storm intensified and became a supercell. This cluster moved southeast across portions of Rooks and Osborne counties through 5:30 p.m. CST, continuing to be anchored by the supercell. This supercell produced prolific amounts of hail along its path, covering the ground in some areas. The largest reported was the size of baseballs near the town of Speed, in Phillips County. Significant damage occurred to the roof, siding, windows, and several vehicles on one farm. Radar signatures strongly suggested this storm may have produced hail of similar size in other areas, but no reports were received due to low population. This storm also damaged trees in southwest Osborne County. Between 5 and 6 p.m. CST, a broken line of thunderstorms dropped out of Nebraska into north central Kansas. A couple of these storms were severe as well. One was a supercell that tracked through Phillips and Osborne counties, a little north of the previous storm. This storm produced hail to at least the size of golf balls. The other storm raked across Jewell county between 5:30 and 6:30 p.m. CST. This storm was responsible for multiple reports of measured winds in excess of 65 MPH, including one of 80 MPH. Hail was reported up to 1.5 inches in diameter. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures were in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the 50s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates were near 7 degrees C/km, resultant MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-200 m2/s2.

Wind driven hail broken windows in some homes on the north side of the town of Jewell.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures were in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the 50s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates were near 7 degrees C/km, resultant MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-200 m2/s2.

Several damaging thunderstorms raked across portions of north central Kansas on this Thursday afternoon and evening. A small multicell cluster of thunderstorms developed along the Nebraska-Kansas state line and began moving into western Phillips County just before 3 p.m. CST. The leading storm intensified and became a supercell. This cluster moved southeast across portions of Rooks and Osborne counties through 5:30 p.m. CST, continuing to be anchored by the supercell. This supercell produced prolific amounts of hail along its path, covering the ground in some areas. The largest reported was the size of baseballs near the town of Speed, in Phillips County. Significant damage occurred to the roof, siding, windows, and several vehicles on one farm. Radar signatures strongly suggested this storm may have produced hail of similar size in other areas, but no reports were received due to low population. This storm also damaged trees in southwest Osborne County. Between 5 and 6 p.m. CST, a broken line of thunderstorms dropped out of Nebraska into north central Kansas. A couple of these storms were severe as well. One was a supercell that tracked through Phillips and Osborne counties, a little north of the previous storm. This storm produced hail to at least the size of golf balls. The other storm raked across Jewell county between 5:30 and 6:30 p.m. CST. This storm was responsible for multiple reports of measured winds in excess of 65 MPH, including one of 80 MPH. Hail was reported up to 1.5 inches in diameter. Wind driven hail broken windows in some homes on the north side of the town of Jewell.||These storms formed along and head of a strong Canadian cold front. In the upper-levels, a trough was over the central United States, and an embedded shortwave trough was moving into the Central Plains. In the pre-storm environment, surface temperatures were in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the 50s. Combined with mid-level lapse rates were near 7 degrees C/km, resultant MLCAPE was around 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 35-45 knots, with 0-3 km SRH 100-200 m2/s2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front slowly moving through eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa produced a couple of isolated thunderstorms during the evening on September 17th. The thunderstorms, largely non-severe, persisted for a couple of hours during the evening before the cold front pushed into northeast Kansas and northwest Missouri ending the thunderstorm threat.

A cold front slowly moving through eastern Nebraska and southwest Iowa produced a couple of isolated thunderstorms during the evening on September 17th. The thunderstorms, largely non-severe, persisted for a couple of hours during the evening before the cold front pushed into northeast Kansas and northwest Missouri ending the thunderstorm threat.

An area of upper level low pressure slowly moved across the central Plains during the September 22nd through the 23rd time frame. Significant moisture was in place across the mid Missouri River Valley ahead of this system. This combination led to scattered to numerous thunderstorms over eastern Nebraska and western Iowa starting on the 22nd and continuing into the day on the 23rd. The heavy persistent thunderstorms, especially late in the night and into the early morning hours on the 23rd led to significant flash flooding across parts of western Iowa, specifically in Council Bluffs.

An upper level low sat over the Intermountain West at the beginning of this time frame then slowly moved eastward through the Central Rockies and Central Plains through November 30th. Upper level shortwaves ejected eastward towards western Kansas as the low shifted eastward.||At the surface,  low pressure located east of the area with a trough of low pressure across eastern Colorado allowed copious amounts of low to mid-level moisture to be advected northward from the Gulf of Mexico. A strong cold front moved through the area overnight on the 26th pushing this moisture into the mid levels. Precipitation fell behind this front as isentropic lift increased overnight. A wide range of precipitation fell overnight into the next morning with rain changing over to a mix of sleet, freezing rain, and snow. Over a quarter of an inch of ice was reported across portions of south central Kansas stretching westward as far as Liberal to Dodge City to Great Bend. A mix of sleet and snow was reported west of this line with minimal accumulations by the afternoon of the 27th. Periodic episodes of light freezing rain continued across portions of south central Kansas over the remainder of the 27th through the 29th with light freezing drizzle at times across the remainder of the forecast area. Another strong upper level shortwave moved through the area the night of the 29th into the morning of the 30th bringing another round of precipitation across western Kansas. Additional freezing rain, sleet, and snow were reported across central and south central Kansas with sleet and snow reported elsewhere. Up to 3 inches was reported across portions of west central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed eastward. Ice accumulations over three quarters of an inch were reported across portions of south central Kansas with lesser amounts as you headed westward.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was the last of five significant severe hail events this month, in terms of size and the number of reports. Each of these events contained at least one report of 2 inch hail or greater. The uniqueness of this event was that it occurred during the morning hours on this Friday. Around 5 a.m. CST, scattered showers began to develop across much of south central Nebraska. Over the following couple hours, they increased in coverage and strengthened into thunderstorms. By 7:30 a.m. CST, several strong to severe storms were along and north of Interstate 80 from Lexington to Grand Island to Osceola. A couple of them became supercells. One supercell in particular produced most of the hail as it tracked from northern Adams County into southern Hamilton and York counties. Tennis ball to baseball size hail occurred near from near Hansen to Giltner to Trumbull. By 10 a.m. CST, it was all over. The storms hail had exited into eastern Nebraska.||South central Nebraska was in the cold sector. A cold front extended from the Great Lakes southwest across Kansas. High pressure was over the Northern Plains, while a low pressure center was making its way along the front over Kansas. In the upper-levels, a broad trough extended from the Northern Rockies into the Northern Plains. A fairly potent shortwave trough was embedded within this cyclonic flow, just west of the region, and extended from Montana into Wyoming. These storms formed in an area of mid-level warm air advection around 700 mb and frontogenesis between 850 mb and 700 mb. Meanwhile, under the frontal surface, cold air advection was occurring with surface temperatures in the 50s. MUCAPE was between 500 and 1000 J/kg, and deep layer shear was around 40 knots.
