Isolated thunderstorms developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 27th.  They developed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure, and moved to the east northeast into the western Nebraska Sandhills and portions of the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle. Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts of 70 MPH estimated at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 27th.  They developed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure, and moved to the east northeast into the western Nebraska Sandhills and portions of the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle. Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds.

Isolated thunderstorms developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 27th.  They developed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure, and moved to the east northeast into the western Nebraska Sandhills and portions of the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle. Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts, estimated at 60 MPH, lasted 15 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late evening a severe thunderstorm moved over Decatur county.  The high winds from the thunderstorm caused a porch awning to be peeled back on top of the house, did some damage to signs in the Oberlin area and blew a mobile home off its foundation near Oberlin.

A severe thunderstorm produced damaging winds across portions of Mitchell County on this Wednesday evening. This thunderstorm entered southwestern Mitchell County, from Russell county, around 7 p.m. CST, and tracked from southwest to northeast across the county between 7 and 8 p.m. As this storm passed through the Beloit area, winds measured as high as 78 mph snapped multiple power poles and large tree branches. Power outages lasted as much as 12 hours. A portion of the tin roof was also blown off from an auto parts store. ||This storm formed near cold front that moved into northern Kansas, the previous night, and became stationary. In the upper levels, a subtropical high was over Texas, with a ridge extending north to Minnesota. Troughs were along the East Coast and over the western United States. A shortwave trough was embedded, in the western trough, from Montana south to Utah. Surface temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s and lower 70s. Mid-level lapse rates were low, resulting in MLCAPE between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 30-35 knots.

Isolated thunderstorms developed along a stationary front located over southwestern Nebraska. These storms then migrated to the east northeast into portions of central Nebraska. Large hail and damaging winds were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Along with estimated thunderstorm wind gusts to 60 MPH, heavy rain and small hail was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over Sheridan County during the afternoon hours of July 26th.  One supercell developed to produce golfball sized hail.

Thunderstorms developed over Custer county Nebraska during the evening hours of July 31st.  As they moved into eastern portions of the county, they became severe with large hail and damaging winds being reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In addition to golf ball sized hail, thunderstorm wind gusts of 50 to 60 MPH were reported which led to downed tree limbs at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed over Custer county Nebraska during the evening hours of July 31st.  As they moved into eastern portions of the county, they became severe with large hail and damaging winds being reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 60 MPH brought down tree limbs of 6 to 8 inches in diameter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late in the morning a severe thunderstorm moved over Norton county from Nebraska.  Ping-pong ball size hail was reported near Almena with this storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm report was relayed via social media.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late evening a severe thunderstorm moved over Decatur county.  The high winds from the thunderstorm caused a porch awning to be peeled back on top of the house, did some damage to signs in the Oberlin area and blew a mobile home off its foundation near Oberlin.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A porch awning was peel back against the house and porch furniture was blown off.  There was also sign damage in the Oberlin area and a mobile home was blown off its foundation.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms tracked through much of central Nebraska on this Friday evening, north of Interstate 80. While many of the storms were strong, only one turned severe. Quarter size hail was reported in Sherman county around 9 p.m. CST. A lightning strike from a different storm snapped off a very large tree limb in Valley county, severely damaging two vehicles in the town of Ord.||A low pressure system was over the Canadian Prairies. These storms formed along and ahead of the associated cold front that was slowly advancing through the Northern and Central Plains. In the upper levels, the flow was generally west-southwest across the United States, with low amplitude. A subtropical high over the Gulf Coast, and a trough was over the West, with a closed low over Saskatchewan. The near-storm environment was characterized by surface temperatures in the upper 80s, with dewpoints in the lower to middle 70s. With mid-level lapse rates near 7.5 deg C/km, instability of significant with MLCAPE between 3000 and 4000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was around 35 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning struck a tree, breaking off a large limb approximately 20 inches in diameter. This limb landed on 2 vehicles, causing significant damage to the cab of a pickup and the passenger compartment of a car.

Slow moving, severe thunderstorms developed producing heavy rain and large hail across Chase and Hayes counties during the evening of July 25th. Hail to teacup size fell.
Slow moving, severe thunderstorms developed producing heavy rain and large hail across Chase and Hayes counties during the evening of July 25th. Hail to teacup size fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail ranged in size from golf ball to teacup.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Slow moving, severe thunderstorms developed producing heavy rain and large hail across Chase and Hayes counties during the evening of July 25th. Hail to teacup size fell.

In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: We received a delayed report of baseball-sized hail that caused damage to an unspecified number of local businesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of severe thunderstorms developed over West Central Kansas during the early evening.  As the storms moved northeast they expanded in coverage.  Wind speeds of 60 to over 80 MPH were reported along the leading edge of the squall line.  The sudden high winds over the dry ground caused widespread blowing dust along the edge of the squall line, with zero visibility reported in Wichita, Logan and Rawlins counties.  The highest wind gust reported was 83 MPH, which was measured at the Oakley airport.  Quarter size hail was also reported with the squall line from a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of penny to quarter size hail fell, along with an estimated 50 MPH wind gusts and heavy rain.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Near zero visibility due to blowing dust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms produced predominantly damaging winds on this Friday afternoon and evening. An area of showers moved into central Nebraska at mid-afternoon. A lone thunderstorm developed on the southern edge of these showers and briefly became severe over Merrick County, producing hail up to the size of quarters. The main event occurred later in the evening, beginning with several multicell storms that developed from Dawson County west into southern Lincoln County. These storms were initially not severe, but as they headed east, new storms initiated downstream, forming a large cluster of multicell storms. These storms produced multiple reports of strong winds and wind damage over Hall, Hamilton, Clay, York, and Fillmore Counties, mostly along and within 15 miles on either side of Interstate 80. These storms were severe in the 8 to 10 p.m. CST time frame. Tree limbs of various sizes were reported down in multiple locations and winds were measured as high as 62 mph in Grand Island and 59 mph in York and Henderson. There were a couple reports of hail. The largest was the size of ping pong balls in Heartwell, which is in Kearney county.||These storms formed just north of a weak cold front that dropped through most of Nebraska during the morning hours. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.

The highest wind gust reported was 83 MPH, which was measured at the Oakley airport.  Quarter size hail was also reported with the squall line from a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous five inch diameter tree limbs blown down and dumpsters blown over.  Zero visibility due to the blowing dust from the high winds.  Minor damage sustained to vehicles and buildings from the high winds and hail.  There was a power outage west of town for two hours.  The sustained wind reached 60 MPH for a brief time during the high winds, with winds gusting up to 82 MPH.

Thunderstorms developed along a stationary frontal boundary, which was draped across northern Nebraska.  With favorable wind shear aloft, storms became quickly severe with damaging winds and large hail. A couple of brief tornadoes touched down, although no damage occurred.  Strong to severe storms redeveloped overnight and continued into the early morning hours on July 27th.

Two separate thunderstorm events produced a little severe weather and flash flooding on this Friday. The first episode was associated with a couple supercells that formed near McCook, Nebraska the prior evening. These storms evolved into a small multicell cluster that was joined by a few other storms as it moved southeast across north-central Kansas between midnight at 3 a.m. CST. This small cluster was mostly sub-severe, producing penny size hail and measured winds of 50-55 mph in a few spots. However, it did produce a severe wind gust of 61 mph in Logan. Later in the day, between 5 and 6 pm CST, several thunderstorms formed over Rooks, Phillips, and Smith Counties. They quickly congealed into a multicell cluster. This cluster remained quasi-stationary between 5:30 and 8:30 p.m., with the most persistent heavy rain over southeastern Phillips and northeastern Rooks Counties. Three to six inches of rain were measured in this short time span and this resulted in flash flooding, with numerous gravel roads under water and some washed out in spots. One of these storms did produce hail to the size of quarters in Stockton, which is in Rooks County.||The overnight storms occurred near a dissipating frontal boundary, with no forcing aloft. The late afternoon and evening storms formed along a weak cold front that had dropped through Nebraska, during the day, and was slowing its forward progress over north central Kansas. In the upper levels, a broad ridge encompassed the Plains atop a subtropical high over the Southern Plains. The Central Plains were on the southern fringe of the Westerlies. Surface temperatures in advance of the storms were in the mid 80s, with dewpoints near 70. With mid-level lapse rates of 7.5 deg C/km, MLCAPE values were between 2000 and 3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was between 30 and 40 knots.

A strong tornado moved southwest from Rice into Reno county causing significant damage to two different homesteads.  One home was completely demolished while another took a glancing blow.  Numerous trees were uprooted and those that were not had a significant amount of debarking.  Several other storms moved across the area producing severe wind and hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A strong tornado moved southwest towards the town of Nickerson.  One home was completely destroyed as it was blown off of its foundation.  There were no anchor bolts present in the foundation (DI2 DOD9).  The second more significant damage sight was where many trees were completely uprooted.  Those that were not uprooted only had the main trunk left and it was completely debarked.  The home took a glancing blow and only had minor damage.  The family took shelter in an above ground shelter in their garage. The damage path for this portion of the tornado that moved out of Rice County was 350 yards wide.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the early morning hours of the 27th a cluster of elevated storms developed in southeast KS. One particular storm was able to rotate and storm enough to produce at least ping pong sized hail. Given the scattered coverage and slower movement a few areas were able to experience minor flash flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed over Central & South-Central Kansas in the afternoon of the 25th. The thunderstorms barely achieved severity with half dollar-sized hail the largest reported. One severe thunderstorm produced gusts around 52 knots in & near Salina but the most significant event occurred in Southeast Ellsworth County where 4-5 inches of rain caused a flash flood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A road was washed out just south of Highway 4 and Highway 141 north of Langley where 4.50 inches of rain was measured.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts of 60 MPH reported at this location.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: KWCH Channel 12 relayed the report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple severe thunderstorms produced hail up to one inch in diameter on this Monday afternoon and evening, as well as a little wind damage. Scattered mostly single cell thunderstorms developed during the early to mid-afternoon hours, with a few small multicell clusters. These storms formed over the Sandhills and progressed southeastward through the late afternoon and evening hours, affecting portions of central and south central Nebraska. One of the storms that became severe moved out of western Polk County around 3:45 p.m. CST, and then dropped almost due south through York County. This storm blew an irrigation pivot over near Benedict and produced hail up to one inch in diameter just north of York.  One storm produced wind strong enough to snap off some 5 inch diameter tree limbs in Central City. As this storm continued southeastward, it produced hail up to the size of quarters in Henderson.||These storms developed along and head of a weak cold front which was sagging into Nebraska from the north. Northwest flow was established over the Plains, with a longwave ridge over the western United States, and a trough over the East. A subtropical high was situated over the Desert Southwest. Despite poor mid-level lapse rates, temperatures in the lower 90s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s, resulted in MLCAPE values of 2000-3000 J/kg. Deep layer shear increased from 25 kts, early in the event, to around 30 knots during its peak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A left-moving supercell produced severe hail over extreme southwestern Dawson County on this Thursday evening. Late this afternoon, a few isolated thunderstorms developed over southwestern Nebraska. One storm was a supercell that formed over Frontier County. Between 5:30 and 6:30 p.m. CST, the storm split. The left-mover headed northeast and briefly became severe, producing hail up to the size of quarters in the town of Farnam around 730 p.m. After producing this hail, the storm rapidly weakened and dissipated.||These thunderstorms formed ahead of the lee-side trough. The flow aloft was characterized by a broad ridge over the Plains, anchored by a subtropical high over Texas. Synoptic forcing was negligible with the Westerlies north of the region. Surface temperatures in the pre-storm environment were in the lower 90s, with dewpoints around 70. Mid-level lapse rates were around 7 deg C/km, resulting in MLCAPE around 3500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 30-35 knots. Low-level winds were not strong. So, 0-3 km SRH was unimpressive, with values of only 100 m2/s2. However, low-level winds were veering with height. So, SRH was sufficient to result in supercell convective mode.

During the late morning and into the afternoon a series of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Southwest Nebraska.  Large hail up to quarter size was reported southeast of McCook and Northwest of Herndon, KS.  The prolonged rainfall northeast of Trenton along Highway 34 south to the Republican river drained through a culvert east of Trenton, washing out the culvert under North River Drive just east of Trenton.  The same series of storms moved east producing rapid, heavy rainfall over McCook.  This sudden, heavy rainfall caused cars to stall in town and lifted manhole covers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Vehicles have stalled on roads and manhole covers were lifted with water gushing out of them.  There is quite a bit of debris mixed in with the rushing water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms developed over Central & South-Central Kansas in the afternoon of the 25th. The thunderstorms barely achieved severity with half dollar-sized hail the largest reported. One severe thunderstorm produced gusts around 52 knots in & near Salina but the most significant event occurred in Southeast Ellsworth County where 4-5 inches of rain caused a flash flood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was flowing over Highway 4 between 5th and 6th avenues. KDOT is barricading the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rains moved over an already unsaturated ground causing flooding of roads at many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rains around 2 inches just outside of Geneseo caused isolated flooding of flat low lying areas.  County roads in the area were covered by water.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rains moved over an already unsaturated ground causing flooding of roads at many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to 14 inches of water was reported across the intersection of Hwy 56 and Heitzer Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rains moved over an already unsaturated ground causing flooding of roads at many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several roads had become inundated with water in the far western sections of Great Bend and the rural areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very heavy rains moved over an already unsaturated ground causing flooding of roads at many locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Deep water had completely inundated the road making it impassable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 75 MPH destroyed a pole barn damaging a vehicle and a combine barked inside.  A metal building sustained damage to one side of the building along with large tree limb damage at a farmstead east of Gross.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind gusts estimated at 70 MPH, removed half of a roof off of a barn and destroyed a small shed at a farmstead north of Lynch.  Large tree limb damage occurred at this location as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced quarter size hail near Dixon in extreme northeast Nebraska on the early afternoon of May 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large hail was accompanied by strong but not damaging wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several clusters of strong to severe storms developed during the afternoon and evening over Northwest Kansas, some of them remaining stationary at times.  The largest hail size reported was quarter size near Blakeman, however over three inches of small hail was reported near Edson.  The strongest wind gust reported was an estimated 70 MPH at Winona, which occurred when the town to lose power.  A measured wind speed of 65 MPH was reported near Leoti ahead of a line of storms.  Flash flooding occurred near Winona with these storms as water 18 inches deep and roughly 100 yards wide was reported over Road 230.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The entire town has lost power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late morning and into the afternoon a series of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Southwest Nebraska.  Large hail up to quarter size was reported southeast of McCook and Northwest of Herndon, KS.  The prolonged rainfall northeast of Trenton along Highway 34 south to the Republican river drained through a culvert east of Trenton, washing out the culvert under North River Drive just east of Trenton.  The same series of storms moved east producing rapid, heavy rainfall over McCook.  This sudden, heavy rainfall caused cars to stall in town and lifted manhole covers.

During the late morning and into the afternoon a series of slow moving thunderstorms moved across Southwest Nebraska.  Large hail up to quarter size was reported southeast of McCook and Northwest of Herndon, KS.  The prolonged rainfall northeast of Trenton along Highway 34 south to the Republican river drained through a culvert east of Trenton, washing out the culvert under North River Drive just east of Trenton.  The same series of storms moved east producing rapid, heavy rainfall over McCook.  This sudden, heavy rainfall caused cars to stall in town and lifted manhole covers.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A culvert was washed out on North River Drive between Trenton and Culbertson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In the evening, a few severe thunderstorms dropped hail across parts of Sedgwick, Sumner, Butler, and Greenwood Counties. Of these counties, by far the largest and most destructive hail occurred in Butler County, where most of El Dorado was pummeled by golf ball to baseball-sized hail.||No doubt, damage was widespread. The most serious occurred along and south of Central Avenue (K-254) from Boyer Road to the Walnut River.||Most vehicles sustained significant damage that no doubt included shattered wind shields. Perhaps the most note worthy was to the John K. Fisher Chevrolet/Cadillac Dealership where around 50 cars were heavily damaged. There was major damage to roofs and siding of countless homes and businesses. The very large hail caused major roof damage on the Butler County Community College campus where most of their vehicles were heavily damaged. Extensive roof damage, that included many broken sky lights, caused the closure of Walmart. Many traffic signals were also damaged and some cases, destroyed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail ranged in size from golf balls to hen eggs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed along a stationary frontal boundary, which was draped across northern Nebraska.  With favorable wind shear aloft, storms became quickly severe with damaging winds and large hail. A couple of brief tornadoes touched down, although no damage occurred.  Strong to severe storms redeveloped overnight and continued into the early morning hours on July 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency manager reports thunderstorm winds of 60 to 70 MPH.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall was also occurring with the quarter size hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lone severe thunderstorm produced hail up to 2 inches in diameter, over Mitchell County, on this Sunday evening. A couple isolated thunderstorms formed over north central Kansas late this afternoon and into the early evening hours. These storms did not live long. The storm that produced the hail over Mitchell County formed over Osborne County just before 6 p.m. CST. It intensified as it crossed into western Mitchell County. The severe hail fell just south of Waconda Lake. The storm rapidly weakened, over the eastern part of the county, between 7 and 7:30 p.m. CST.||These storms formed near a long surface trough that extended from South Dakota through central Kansas to the Texas Panhandle. This trough separated maritime tropical air to the east, and continental tropical air to the west. Dewpoints ahead of it were in the lower to middle 70s, while they were in the 50s to lower 60s to the west. Aloft, subtropical high pressure was over Texas with a ridge extending north into the Central Plains. Troughs were along both the East and West Coasts. The lack of synoptic forcing was the reason for the paucity of thunderstorms. MLCAPE was near 3,000 J/kg and deep layer shear was around 45 knots.

A modest dryline developed  across South Central and Central Kansas during the afternoon hours of May 6th, 2015.  Moderate instability and shear combined to produce supercell thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and Central Kansas. |The supercell thunderstorms produced some large hail, but also produced five  tornadoes across the area.  One of the tornadoes was rated an EF3, with another rated an EF2.

One of the tornadoes was rated an EF3, with another rated an EF2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half dollar sized hail was reported accumulating and drifting. Via a Kake TV storm spotter.

Severe thunderstorms produced hail up to the size of golf balls in a few locations on this Tuesday afternoon. Just after 2 p.m. CST, an isolated thunderstorm developed along the Buffalo-Sherman County line. This storm advanced slowly to the east and weakened by 3:30 p.m. By 2:45 p.m., another storm joined it over northern Sherman County. This storm moved north into Valley County by 3:30 p.m. and exited the county by 5 p.m. Both of these storms produced hail up to the size of golf balls. The second storm produced golf ball size hail near Arcadia and near Fort Hartsuff State Park. ||These storms formed well ahead of a backdoor cold front that was pressing into northeastern Nebraska. However, convective initiation was more likely a result of a small area of low-level convergence between Broken Bow, where winds were from the west, and Ord, where winds were from the east. In the upper levels, a subtropical high was over Oklahoma, with a ridge extending north through the Dakotas. Troughs were located over the western and eastern United States. At mid-afternoon, surface temperatures were in the middle 90s, with dewpoints in the middle to upper 60s. With mid-level lapse rates near 7 deg C/km, MLCAPE was around 2500 J/kg. Deep layer shear was near 25 knots.

An isolated heavy precipitation supercell produced some large hail, damaging winds and flash flooding over portions of Central Kansas on the afternoon and evening of July 10th, 2015.  The damaging winds and hail and flash flooding was the worst over Chase county, Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One to two feet of water was flowing over US highway 50 near YY road.  Rainfall amounts were 2 to 2.5 inches of rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front led to the development of a line of showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon and evening of July, 6th, 2015.  Wet microbursts along the slow moving line led to damaging winds of 70-80 mph across portions of South Central Kansas.   Also the slow moving storms led to torrential downpours across portions of the Wichita metro area.  Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches, produced flash flooding across the heart of the Wichita metro area, including submerging numerous vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kake TV reported via social media multiple stranded cars due to high water on 13th street between Broadway and Waco.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front led to the development of a line of showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon and evening of July, 6th, 2015. Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches, produced flash flooding across the heart of the Wichita metro area, including submerging numerous vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous stalled cars due to high water near Harry and Rock Roads.  Reported by Kake TV.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water was almost a foot deep along 2nd Street near St Francis.  The information was relayed by Kake TV.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several small, discrete supercells developed late in the afternoon on this Wednesday, and continued into the evening. While there were many reports of wall clouds and funnel clouds, these storms did not produce much severe weather. Most storms exhibited classic supercell characteristics on radar, with some supercells splitting. The only confirmed severe weather was 1.5 inch hail in Red Cloud, which is in Webster county, and a measured wind gust of 67 mph near the town of Chester, in southern Thayer county.||These storms formed north of a cold front that moved through the previous night and became stationary over northern Kansas. In the upper-levels, a subtropical high was over Texas, with a ridge extending north to Minnesota. Troughs were along the East Coast and over the western United States. A shortwave trough was embedded, in the western trough, from Montana south to Utah. Surface temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s and lower 70s. Mid-level lapse rates were low, resulting in MLCAPE between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 30-35 knots. Low-level (0-3 km) SRH was between 150 and 300 m2/s2. However, 0-1 km shear was less than optimal, between 10 and 15 knots. While this environment was supportive of supercells, the lack of low-level shear may have contributed to the lack of tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This gust was measured by the PECAN project team.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A fast moving upper level disturbance combined with an arctic cold front to produce heavy snow with some blowing and drifting to portions of western and north central Nebraska.  Snowfall amounts ranged from 4 to 8 inches with local amounts up to 10 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A cooperative observer located 10 miles northeast of Oshkosh reported 6 inches of snowfall.  Additional calls to general public indicated 4 to 8 inches of snowfall fell across Garden County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Isolated thunderstorms developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 27th.  They developed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure, and moved to the east northeast into the western Nebraska Sandhills and portions of the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle. Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds.

Isolated thunderstorms developed over the Nebraska Panhandle during the early evening hours of July 27th.  They developed in the vicinity of a surface trough of low pressure, and moved to the east northeast into the western Nebraska Sandhills and portions of the northeastern Nebraska Panhandle. Severe thunderstorms produced damaging winds.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Weather spotter estimated winds of 60 MPH on the west side of Hyannis.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Storms across the far sections of Southeast Kansas produced one tornado and several funnel clouds.  Wind gusts to 65 mph were also noted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak rope tornado briefly touched down in open country and did not cause any damage. The tornado width was 50 yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced damaging winds across portions of Mitchell County on this Wednesday evening. This thunderstorm entered southwestern Mitchell County, from Russell county, around 7 p.m. CST, and tracked from southwest to northeast across the county between 7 and 8 p.m. As this storm passed through the Beloit area, winds measured as high as 78 mph snapped multiple power poles and large tree branches. Power outages lasted as much as 12 hours. A portion of the tin roof was also blown off from an auto parts store. ||This storm formed near cold front that moved into northern Kansas, the previous night, and became stationary. In the upper levels, a subtropical high was over Texas, with a ridge extending north to Minnesota. Troughs were along the East Coast and over the western United States. A shortwave trough was embedded, in the western trough, from Montana south to Utah. Surface temperatures were in the lower to middle 80s, with dewpoints in the upper 60s and lower 70s. Mid-level lapse rates were low, resulting in MLCAPE between 1000 and 2000 J/kg. Deep layer shear was 30-35 knots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts were estimated to be near 60 MPH.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Light rainfall transitioned to snow from north to south during the afternoon as cooler air filtered into the area with a cold front. Snowfall amounts ranged from 5.4 inches to nine inches, with snowfall amounts mostly in the seven to eight inch range.  The highest amount reported was 9 inches 13.2 SW of Goodland.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A snowfall amount of eight inches was reported at Leoti.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon, and into the evening, scattered strong to severe storms moved into Northwest Kansas from the south.  These storms were on the warmer half of a strong winter storm system that would bring blizzard conditions to Northwest Kansas the next day.  Six separate tornadoes were reported over Northwest Kansas, the most tornadoes reported for the month of November.  The tornadoes were reported over Gove, Sheridan and Norton counties.  The longest tornado track was 17 miles, lasting over 30 minutes, as it traveled from Grainfield to near Tasco.  In addition to the tornadoes, large hail up to golf ball size was reported near Tasco.  Severe thunderstorm wind gusts up to 90 MPH were reported with some of the storms.  The high winds caused near zero visibilities near Wheeler due to blowing dirt.  Many power poles were destroyed by either tornado or high winds, leaving many people without power.  In Hill City the roof was blown off the power plant, causing the town to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado was reported in Grainfield causing damage to numerous trees as it moved northeast.  A wood structure at the Coop sustained unspecified damage. An abandoned house in town had the roof blown off it. A quonset was destroyed, but only minor damage was done to the implements inside.  Power lines were brought down, windows and sheds were destroyed in town.  The majority of the tornado path was to the northeast into Sheridan county.  The tornado crossed into Sheridan county just east of the Gove 48 and Gove Ee intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds associated with a powerful storm system and pressure gradient caused minor damage and power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A large tree fell across Turkey Creek Road northeast of Galena. There were multiple reports of power lines and pole poles blown down across the county causing power outages. A tree was blown down onto a house near Columbus. There were numerous power outages reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong winds associated with a powerful storm system and pressure gradient caused minor damage and power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was blown down on to a home near East 21st Street in Pittsburg, Kansas. A tree was blown down at the 800 block of E Atkinson Ave. Several trees were also reported down near Girard.  A 55 mph wind gusts was reported at the AWOS in Pittsburg.  There were multiple reports of power lines blown down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Widespread heavy rain moved across central Kansas causing widespread inconveniences to area travelers with some road closures in low lying areas and a water rescue at another. Rainfall amounts over a 48 hour period ranged from around 1.5 inches to just over 4 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A water rescue was performed by the Wichita Fire Department at the intersection of 85th st. N and 215th st. W. The car was stranded in running water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapidly running water was rushing across the road at the merger of Emma east and Emma west creeks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nuisance flooding was causing standing water of 6 to 8 inches over the road.  This was non-life threatening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 5 to 8 inches in extreme northeast Nebraska from the morning into the evening of November 20th. The snow was accompanied by light winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 5 to 8 inches, with 6.5 inches reported at North Sioux City. The snow was accompanied by light winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 5 to 8 inches in extreme northeast Nebraska from the morning into the evening of November 20th. The snow was accompanied by light winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 5 to 8 inches, with 8 inches reported at Ponca. The snow was accompanied by light winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the late evening thunderstorms producing heavy rainfall moved over Dundy county.  Rainfall amounts in the county around Benkelman ranged from 1.5-2.  Law enforcement had to close old Highway 34 on the northeast side of Benkelman due to water running over the highway making it impassable.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law Enforcement had to close old Highway 34 on the northeast side of Benkelman due to water running over the road making it impassable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm moved near Benkelman, NE producing hail up to penny size.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mostly pea size hail fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon, and into the evening, scattered strong to severe storms moved into Northwest Kansas from the south.  These storms were on the warmer half of a strong winter storm system that would bring blizzard conditions to Northwest Kansas the next day.  Six separate tornadoes were reported over Northwest Kansas, the most tornadoes reported for the month of November.  The tornadoes were reported over Gove, Sheridan and Norton counties.  The longest tornado track was 17 miles, lasting over 30 minutes, as it traveled from Grainfield to near Tasco.  In addition to the tornadoes, large hail up to golf ball size was reported near Tasco.  Severe thunderstorm wind gusts up to 90 MPH were reported with some of the storms.  The high winds caused near zero visibilities near Wheeler due to blowing dirt.  Many power poles were destroyed by either tornado or high winds, leaving many people without power.  In Hill City the roof was blown off the power plant, causing the town to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado moved north-northeast out of Gove county into Sheridan county, east of Rd 10W in Sheridan county and the Gove Ee intersection.  Law enforcement reported power lines down along K-23 where the tornado crossed the highway 15 miles south of Hoxie.  Power poles were also blown down 13 miles south and 1 east of Hoxie.  Just east of road 80S/40E intersection 8.5 miles southeast of Hoxie, grain bins and power lines were damaged, and two stock trailers were flipped over.  Minor damage was reported to the house there, and a 20'x40' shop was destroyed.  Not long after causing this damage the tornado track shifted more to the north.   The tornado track ended south of Tasco where damage was done to a home and some outbuildings.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon, and into the evening, scattered strong to severe storms moved into Northwest Kansas from the south.  These storms were on the warmer half of a strong winter storm system that would bring blizzard conditions to Northwest Kansas the next day.  Six separate tornadoes were reported over Northwest Kansas, the most tornadoes reported for the month of November.  The tornadoes were reported over Gove, Sheridan and Norton counties.  The longest tornado track was 17 miles, lasting over 30 minutes, as it traveled from Grainfield to near Tasco.  In addition to the tornadoes, large hail up to golf ball size was reported near Tasco.  Severe thunderstorm wind gusts up to 90 MPH were reported with some of the storms.  The high winds caused near zero visibilities near Wheeler due to blowing dirt.  Many power poles were destroyed by either tornado or high winds, leaving many people without power.  In Hill City the roof was blown off the power plant, causing the town to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado tracked northeast through Lenora, then turned more to the north.  In Lenora windows and garage doors were blown out/damaged.  In addition to the window damage, an aluminum door was folded and mangled at the Coop.  Trees were blown through windows in town along with some minor damage to outbuildings.  A Nex-Tech building had the roof blown off of it and onto the highway.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration winter storm (primarily freezing rain) event began during the evening of Nov 26th and continued into Friday Nov 27th. There was a brief 6-8 hour break in the freezing rain on Friday afternoon into Friday evening. However another round of freezing rain developed and impacted much of the area on Saturday November 28th and continued through Saturday night into early Sunday morning November 29th. Light rain and freezing rain was reported on Sunday with more widespread rain, freezing rain and snow reported across north central Kansas Sunday night into early Monday morning on the 30th. For the sake of clarity this event will be split into 3 episodes, the initial freezing rain and sleet episode that occurred Thursday night through Friday and the longer, larger ice storm episode that occurred late Friday night into early Sunday morning and the final bout of freezing rain that occurred Sunday night into early Monday. ||This episode deals with the second larger ice storm event. ||All told, many areas of northeast Kansas received anywhere from one quarter to three quarters of an inch of ice on flat surfaces and on trees and power lines. The cumulative impacts of repeated bouts of freezing precipitation began to cause tree limbs to break, power lines to fall and associated power outages Saturday through Sunday mainly across Morris, Wabaunsee, Pottawatomie, Riley, Dickinson, Clay, Geary and Lyon counties where the greatest impacts were reported by Sunday into Monday. Thousands of residents of those counties were without power by Sunday morning. Total measured ice accumulations from official ASOS sensors for the storm period defined as 6pm Thursday through 6am Monday included: Salina (proxy for Dickinson CO) 0.59, Manhattan 0.49, Topeka Forbes Field 0.47, Emporia 0.77, Lawrence 0.22, Falls City, NE 0.32 Concordia 0.38. Those totals reflect a 4 day ice accumulation amount as reported by the ice sensors on ASOS sites. NWS Topeka issued 3 separate Warnings for this event including one ice storm warning on Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Westar Energy reported numerous power outages across the county affecting over one thousand people.  Outages were due to downed tree limbs on power lines and power lines failing due to around one half to three quarters of an inch of ice Sunday morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration winter storm (primarily freezing rain) event began during the evening of Nov 26th and continued into Friday Nov 27th. There was a brief 6-8 hour break in the freezing rain on Friday afternoon into Friday evening. However another round of freezing rain developed and impacted much of the area on Saturday November 28th and continued through Saturday night into early Sunday morning November 29th. Light rain and freezing rain was reported on Sunday with more widespread rain, freezing rain and snow reported across north central Kansas Sunday night into early Monday morning on the 30th. For the sake of clarity this event will be split into 3 episodes, the initial freezing rain and sleet episode that occurred Thursday night through Friday and the longer, larger ice storm episode that occurred late Friday night into early Sunday morning and the final bout of freezing rain that occurred Sunday night into early Monday. ||This episode deals with the second larger ice storm event. ||All told, many areas of northeast Kansas received anywhere from one quarter to three quarters of an inch of ice on flat surfaces and on trees and power lines. The cumulative impacts of repeated bouts of freezing precipitation began to cause tree limbs to break, power lines to fall and associated power outages Saturday through Sunday mainly across Morris, Wabaunsee, Pottawatomie, Riley, Dickinson, Clay, Geary and Lyon counties where the greatest impacts were reported by Sunday into Monday. Thousands of residents of those counties were without power by Sunday morning. Total measured ice accumulations from official ASOS sensors for the storm period defined as 6pm Thursday through 6am Monday included: Salina (proxy for Dickinson CO) 0.59, Manhattan 0.49, Topeka Forbes Field 0.47, Emporia 0.77, Lawrence 0.22, Falls City, NE 0.32 Concordia 0.38. Those totals reflect a 4 day ice accumulation amount as reported by the ice sensors on ASOS sites. NWS Topeka issued 3 separate Warnings for this event including one ice storm warning on Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Westar Energy reported numerous power outages across the county affecting over one thousand people.  Outages were due to downed tree limbs on power lines and power lines failing due to around one half to three quarters of an inch of ice Sunday morning. County dispatch also reported tree limbs down county wide due to ice accumulation as of early Sunday morning.

Those totals reflect a 4 day ice accumulation amount as reported by the ice sensors on ASOS sites. NWS Topeka issued 3 separate Warnings for this event including one ice storm warning on Sunday morning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong tornado moved southwest from Rice into Reno county causing significant damage to two different homesteads.  One home was completely demolished while another took a glancing blow.  Numerous trees were uprooted and those that were not had a significant amount of debarking.  Several other storms moved across the area producing severe wind and hail.

A strong tornado moved southwest from Rice into Reno county causing significant damage to two different homesteads.  One home was completely demolished while another took a glancing blow.  Numerous trees were uprooted and those that were not had a significant amount of debarking.  Several other storms moved across the area producing severe wind and hail.

A slow moving cold front led to the development of a line of showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon and evening of July, 6th, 2015.  Wet microbursts along the slow moving line led to damaging winds of 70-80 mph across portions of South Central Kansas.   Also the slow moving storms led to torrential downpours across portions of the Wichita metro area.  Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches, produced flash flooding across the heart of the Wichita metro area, including submerging numerous vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sixty five to 70 mph winds were reported with some tree damage.

Also the slow moving storms led to torrential downpours across portions of the Wichita metro area.  Widespread rainfall amounts of 3 to 4 inches, produced flash flooding across the heart of the Wichita metro area, including submerging numerous vehicles.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seventy to 80 mph winds were reported by a trained spotter.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A modest dryline developed  across South Central and Central Kansas during the afternoon hours of May 6th, 2015.  Moderate instability and shear combined to produce supercell thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and Central Kansas. |The supercell thunderstorms produced some large hail, but also produced five  tornadoes across the area.  One of the tornadoes was rated an EF3, with another rated an EF2.

A modest dryline developed  across South Central and Central Kansas during the afternoon hours of May 6th, 2015.  Moderate instability and shear combined to produce supercell thunderstorms across South Central Kansas and Central Kansas. |The supercell thunderstorms produced some large hail, but also produced five  tornadoes across the area.  One of the tornadoes was rated an EF3, with another rated an EF2.

A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A channeled microburst began near the Kansas Heart Hospital with portions of the roof blown off.   A tenth of mile of power poles were snapped off at the base along Webb Road, all leaning to the east.  At Jabara Airport a large aircraft hanger was completely destroyed with debris from the hanger spread to the east.   Aircraft that were located inside the hanger were also damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong wind event moved across portions of Greenwood and Chase counties causing some minor structural damage and wind gusts to near 60 mph.  The main story was the heavy rains that moved across the southern half of the state producing widespread minor flooding to virtually every county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding was being reported with some water running across the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A couple of upper-level perturbations that moved east/northeast across Oklahoma and extreme Southern Kansas interacted with a moisture-laden air mass to generate very heavy rains across South-Central & Southeast Kansas on the 23rd and 24th. Most of South-Central and Southeast Kansas received 2 to 3 inches from the morning of the 23rd through the morning of the 24th. For most areas, the flooding continued well into the 25th. No doubt, most of the rivers and creeks, primarily in South-Central & Southeast Kansas, rose to the occasion with most venturing into Minor Flood Country. However, 2 rivers ventured into Moderate Flooding Country. The more notable, by far, was the Neosho, along which the forecast points at Chanute, Erie, Parsons, and Oswego all achieved Moderate Flood status. The other was the Walnut, on which Winfield achieved Moderate Food status.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter sent video, via twitter, of water flowing across streets and other low-lying areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong November severe weather episode occurred across the region.  A very strong upper level low approached with with strong winds aloft.  An unusually high amount of moisture and unseasonably unstable airmass were transported north into Kansas.  Storms developed along a dry line but quickly moved off the dryline and became supercellular.  Large, long tracked and rapidly moving tornadoes occurred along with instances of large and damaging hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado moved out of Gray county at 19:02.  It damaged pivot irrigation sprinklers, outbuildings, trees and a home.  It narrowly missed a storm spotter that had been parked at a rest stop, but did not see it because of the darkness.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving cold front advanced into an extremely unstable air mass over eastern Kansas and northwestern and west central Missouri. Thunderstorms developed along the front producing extremely heavy rain, with some areas seeing up to 5, flash flooding, damaging winds and a few tornadoes.

During the afternoon, and into the evening, scattered strong to severe storms moved into Northwest Kansas from the south.  These storms were on the warmer half of a strong winter storm system that would bring blizzard conditions to Northwest Kansas the next day.  Six separate tornadoes were reported over Northwest Kansas, the most tornadoes reported for the month of November.  The tornadoes were reported over Gove, Sheridan and Norton counties.  The longest tornado track was 17 miles, lasting over 30 minutes, as it traveled from Grainfield to near Tasco.  In addition to the tornadoes, large hail up to golf ball size was reported near Tasco.  Severe thunderstorm wind gusts up to 90 MPH were reported with some of the storms.  The high winds caused near zero visibilities near Wheeler due to blowing dirt.  Many power poles were destroyed by either tornado or high winds, leaving many people without power.  In Hill City the roof was blown off the power plant, causing the town to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado tracked to the north-northeast.  Twelve electrical poles were taken down on the south side of Highway 36 just west of the prison.  The tornado also disabled KQNK radio station's ability to broadcast, and a flagpole was bent in half.  A trailer house and outbuildings were also damaged.

Thousands of residents of those counties were without power by Sunday morning.  Total measured ice accumulations from official ASOS sensors for the storm period defined as 6pm Thursday through 6am Monday included:  Salina (proxy for Dickinson CO) 0.59, Manhattan 0.49, Topeka Forbes Field 0.47, Emporia 0.77, Lawrence 0.22, Falls City, NE 0.32 Concordia 0.38.  Those totals reflect a 4 day ice accumulation amount as reported by the ice sensors on ASOS sites.  NWS Topeka issued 3 separate Warnings for this event including one ice storm warning on Sunday morning.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: COOP observer estimated 0.30 of ice accumulated on flat surfaces around 9am on Friday November 27th. Location was in Beattie in Marshall County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5 to 8 inches followed a period of freezing drizzle in extreme northeast Nebraska. The freezing drizzle fell after midnight on November 30th, then the accumulating snow developed that morning and continued through the morning of December 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing drizzle was quickly followed by snow. The snow accumulated 5 to 9 inches over a 24 hour period, including 8.0 inches a mile west of South Sioux City. The storm resulted in cancellations or cutbacks of school classes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Snowfall of 5 to 8 inches followed a period of freezing drizzle in extreme northeast Nebraska. The freezing drizzle fell after midnight on November 30th, then the accumulating snow developed that morning and continued through the morning of December 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing drizzle was quickly followed by snow. The snow accumulated 5 to 8 inches over a 24 hour period, including 7.3 inches just east of Allen. The storm resulted in cancellations or cutbacks of school classes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several rounds of heavy rainfall across portions of southeast Kansas caused minor flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive rainfall caused several areas across Cherokee County to flood. Cherry and Lightning Creeks were impacted and flooded out of their banks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong November severe weather episode occurred across the region.  A very strong upper level low approached with with strong winds aloft.  An unusually high amount of moisture and unseasonably unstable airmass were transported north into Kansas.  Storms developed along a dry line but quickly moved off the dryline and became supercellular.  Large, long tracked and rapidly moving tornadoes occurred along with instances of large and damaging hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was a brief spin-up underneath the mesocyclone.

Large, long tracked and rapidly moving tornadoes occurred along with instances of large and damaging hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado kicked up dirt but there was nothing to be damaged.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado moved out of Oklahoma and into Comanche County.  It struck a farmstead damaging an older home, outbuildings and farm implements.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: This was the second tornado from the parent supercell thunderstorm.  This tornado broke large branches from trees and took down a 1/4 mile stretch of power poles.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusually strong November severe weather episode occurred across the region.  A very strong upper level low approached with with strong winds aloft.  An unusually high amount of moisture and unseasonably unstable airmass were transported north into Kansas.  Storms developed along a dry line but quickly moved off the dryline and became supercellular.  Large, long tracked and rapidly moving tornadoes occurred along with instances of large and damaging hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A fast moving small vortex destroyed round hay bales.  There was an eye witness report of seeing the funnel part of the tornado that lasted briefly.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the afternoon, and into the evening, scattered strong to severe storms moved into Northwest Kansas from the south.  These storms were on the warmer half of a strong winter storm system that would bring blizzard conditions to Northwest Kansas the next day.  Six separate tornadoes were reported over Northwest Kansas, the most tornadoes reported for the month of November.  The tornadoes were reported over Gove, Sheridan and Norton counties.  The longest tornado track was 17 miles, lasting over 30 minutes, as it traveled from Grainfield to near Tasco.  In addition to the tornadoes, large hail up to golf ball size was reported near Tasco.  Severe thunderstorm wind gusts up to 90 MPH were reported with some of the storms.  The high winds caused near zero visibilities near Wheeler due to blowing dirt.  Many power poles were destroyed by either tornado or high winds, leaving many people without power.  In Hill City the roof was blown off the power plant, causing the town to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado developed northeast of Norton and moved almost due north across the rest of the county.  No damage was reported from this tornado, however fence posts and a windmill that were in the path of the tornado were all leaning at a 45 degree angle.  The tornado crossed into Furnas county Nebraska east of the RD 702 and DR 432 intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level disturbance moving through eastern Nebraska and western Iowa on Christmas Eve combined with a strong temperature gradient across the area to produce a narrow heavy band of snowfall. The snow began across the area early in the morning on Thursday and continued through the morning before diminishing in the afternoon. The heaviest of the snow fell during the mid to late morning across the area. There was little wind with the snow, but due to the intensity of the snowfall, with rates at times 1 to 2 inches per hour, travel was significant affected across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of heavy snowfall were received across Douglas County from the media, spotters, and National Weather Service employees. Snowfall ranged from 6 to as much as 9 inches across the county.

There was little wind with the snow, but due to the intensity of the snowfall, with rates at times 1 to 2 inches per hour, travel was significant affected across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of heavy snowfall were received across Douglas County from the media and spotters. Snowfall ranged from 6 to as much as 8 inches across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful upper level storm moved out of the southern Rockies and produced widespread rain, some sleet and heavy snow.  Heavy rainfall occurred late on the 12th but ended by sunrise on the 13th.  The precipitation began again during the morning on the 13th and started as rain before transitioning to sleet and finally snow by the afternoon.  During the late afternoon and evening thunder accompanied the snow and became very heavy.  Most of the precipitation ended shortly after midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow of 8.0 inches was measured in Liberal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: D2 severe drought conditions continued for locations in Sherman and Thomas counties south despite above normal rainfall being reported across many of the affected counties.  Precipitation during the month ranged from 0.48 inches below normal to 3.63 inches above normal across the Northwest Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation during the month ranged from 2.75 inches above normal to 3.25 inches above normal across the county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation during the month ranged from 0.02 inches above normal to 0.35 inches above normal across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A well anticipated winter storm ended up taking a track further southeast of the area then forecast which kept the heavier precipitation east of Kansas.  Even so, some areas of eastern Kansas ended up with around one quarter inch of ice along with around an inch of snow and sleet from this storm.  The storm began Sunday night the 27th and lasted into midday on the 28th of December.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: EM reported around one quarter inch of ice along with an inch of sleet and snow.  Sporadic power outages were reported across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: During the latter half of the morning Goodland reported near blizzard conditions due to wind gusts up to 41 MPH and falling snow.  Visibilities ranged from a quarter to half a mile during this time.

D2 severe drought conditions continued for locations in Sherman and Thomas counties south despite above normal rainfall being reported across many of the affected counties.  Precipitation during the month ranged from 0.48 inches below normal to 3.63 inches above normal across the Northwest Kansas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Precipitation during the month ranged from 0.41 inches above normal to 0.56 inches above normal across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a potent upper level storm system moved across the northern Plains on November 25th a sharp cold front slowly moved south through Nebraska and Iowa. This allowed for some of the coldest air of the early winter season to move into the mid Missouri River Valley. As warm and moist air continued to stream northeast across the area over this air the stage was set for a mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow. The mix started early on the morning of the 26th and continued through the day creating some hazardous conditions for holiday travelers, scattered power outages, and some tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local emergency manager reported a quarter inch of ice in Fairbury. There was also some light sleet and snow as the precipitation ended.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a potent upper level storm system moved across the northern Plains on November 25th a sharp cold front slowly moved south through Nebraska and Iowa. This allowed for some of the coldest air of the early winter season to move into the mid Missouri River Valley. As warm and moist air continued to stream northeast across the area over this air the stage was set for a mix of freezing rain, sleet, and snow. The mix started early on the morning of the 26th and continued through the day creating some hazardous conditions for holiday travelers, scattered power outages, and some tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The local emergency manager reported a quarter inch of ice in Wilber, mainly on exposed elevated surfaces.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a potent upper level storm system moved across the northern Plains on November 25th a sharp cold front slowly moved south through Nebraska and Iowa. This allowed for some of the coldest air of the early winter season to move into the mid Missouri River Valley. The mix started early on the morning of the 26th and continued through the day creating some hazardous conditions for holiday travelers, scattered power outages, and some tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Officials at Offutt Air Force Base reported a quarter inch of ice from freezing rain at the base.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On November 26th and 27th, a mixture of sleet and freezing rain spread across most of Central, South-Central, and Southeast Kansas. The primary culprit was a deep mid to upper cyclone that initially set up over the Desert Southwest before moving northeast across portions of Oklahoma and Kansas. During this period, a second storm system surged southeast from Saskatchewan & Manitoba into the Northern Plains. This system aided in pushing a strong cold front Southeast across Kansas that trapped bitterly cold air beneath a layer of moist warm air that was surging north across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread freezing rain caused roads and highways and especially elevated surfaces to become slick and hazardous in and around Russell.  Based on radar trends It would be safe to assume that similar conditions occurred in other parts of the county.

A series of severe storms moved across central Kansas dropping large hail up to golf ball sized.

A strong tornado moved southwest from Rice into Reno county causing significant damage to two different homesteads.  One home was completely demolished while another took a glancing blow.  Numerous trees were uprooted and those that were not had a significant amount of debarking.  Several other storms moved across the area producing severe wind and hail.

A series of severe thunderstorms moved across central Kansas dropping a plethora of hail in many locations across Russell and Lincoln counties. The severe thunderstorms also unleashed damaging winds that reached 80 mph. Two tornadoes were reported with one being rated as an EF1.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No damage was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A small compact complex of severe thunderstorms developed near the border of Colorado and Kansas during the late evening hours of April 2nd, 2015.  This severe thunderstorm continued to develop and intensify as it moved east into Central Kansas and took on bow echo-like characteristics. This bow-echo storm later produced quite a punch with damaging straight-line winds and large hail reported across much of Central and South Central Kansas. As the bow-echo approached Sedgwick and Harvey counties, channeled microbursts developed and caused significant straight-line wind damage.  Power was knocked out to over 28,000 residents in the northern sections of Wichita for almost 5 days. Wichita and Maize schools cancelled classes on Friday, April 3rd, due to the power outages.  This dangerous storm continued to move through South Central Kansas during the early morning hours, and took on supercellular characteristics as it moved into Southeast Kansas producing hail up to the size of grapefruits.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Sedgwick County EMS building had its roof blown off.  Two people that were in the building had minor injuries.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong wind event moved across portions of Greenwood and Chase counties causing some minor structural damage and wind gusts to near 60 mph.  The main story was the heavy rains that moved across the southern half of the state producing widespread minor flooding to virtually every county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reports of minor street flooding were noted in Marion and other locations across the county. Rain reports around 3 inches were noted in Marion.

A strong wind event moved across portions of Greenwood and Chase counties causing some minor structural damage and wind gusts to near 60 mph.  The main story was the heavy rains that moved across the southern half of the state producing widespread minor flooding to virtually every county.

A couple of upper-level perturbations that moved east/northeast across Oklahoma and extreme Southern Kansas interacted with a moisture-laden air mass to generate very heavy rains across South-Central & Southeast Kansas on the 23rd and 24th. Most of South-Central and Southeast Kansas received 2 to 3 inches from the morning of the 23rd through the morning of the 24th. For most areas, the flooding continued well into the 25th. No doubt, most of the rivers and creeks, primarily in South-Central & Southeast Kansas, rose to the occasion with most venturing into Minor Flood Country. However, 2 rivers ventured into Moderate Flooding Country. The more notable, by far, was the Neosho, along which the forecast points at Chanute, Erie, Parsons, and Oswego all achieved Moderate Flood status. The other was the Walnut, on which Winfield achieved Moderate Food status.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding was reported along Highway 166.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow affected a small part of extreme northeast Nebraska from around midnight on the night of December 25th into the daylight hours of December 26th. Accumulations were mostly 2 to 4 inches over Dakota and Dixon Counties, but 6 inches fell in extreme northern Dixon County. North to northwest winds gusting to 30 mph developed on December 26th and caused areas of blowing snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow accumulated 6.0 inches at Newcastle in extreme northern Dixon County, with accumulations 2 to 4 inches over the rest of the county away from the Missouri River.|North to northwest winds gusted to around 30 mph on December 26th, causing areas of blowing snow with visibilities locally below a half mile. The storm affected mainly Christmas weekend travel.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One last period of rain, freezing rain and snow occurred Sunday night into early Monday morning across north central Kansas.  The counties impacted by ice accumulations that approached one quarter of an inch were only a handful including Washington, Marshall, and Clay while the rest of the area experienced enough of a warm up to keep the bulk of the precipitation as rain or as in Ottawa, Cloud and Republic Counties the amounts that fell during this period were too light to verify the last winter storm warning that was issued for those areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from EM estimated another .20 to .25 of ice accumulation from freezing rain Sunday night into early Monday morning. Report was from Marysville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A vigorous storm system moved across the plains states on November 5th, 2015.  As this system moved into the plains, a strong cold front pushed into Southeast Kansas, leading to the development of low topped but fast moving supercell thunderstorms in Northeast Kansas.  The supercells raced northeast into Southeast Kansas, producing hail up to golf ball size in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was reported in town.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The hail was quarter to golf ball size.  There were lots of quarter size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few weak severe storms produced low end severe hail and winds across far south central Kansas.  Minor damage to a couple of structures were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported on local observing equipment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy snowfall developed over Hitchcock and Red Willow counties during the morning, lasting into the night.  Estimated snowfall amounts of 10 inches or more ocurred in southwest Red Willow and southeast Hitchcock counties.  The bulk of the higher snowfall amounts were in Red Willow county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts for the county were estimated by interpolating snowfall reports from the surrounding counties.  Snowfall amounts ranged from a few inches in the northeast part of the county to over 10 inches in the southwest part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy snowfall setup over Northwest Kansas during the late morning through the evening.  Snowfall totals as high as 20 inches were reported under the band of heavy snow, which stretched from Sharon Springs northeast to Colby and  toward Atwood.  In addition to the heavy snow, high winds developed over part of the area.  The highest gust reported was 63 MPH at Tribune.  The combination of high winds and heavy snowfall produced blizzard conditions not long after the rain changed over to snow, and lasted to midnight for some locations.  Many motorists were stranded, with some still stranded after midnight on the 18th, and many semis were jack-knifed because of the icy roads and deep snow.  The snow was so deep Rawlins county had to request help from the Kansas National Guard in order to reach stranded motorists.  The blizzard also closed multiple area highways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals ranged from 5 to 15 inches across the county.  Visibilities of a quarter mile or less lasted through the majority of the afternoon. At least one accident and several slide-offs were reported due to the slick roads.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall amounts across the county ranged from less than 3 inches to at least 10 inches.  Visibility briefly improved above a quarter mile sporadically through the latter half of the afternoon.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the night of December 27 light freezing rain fell across the area, with several roads becoming glazed with ice and accumulating ice on elevated surfaces. Along with a quarter to a half inch of sleet - and in some areas up to an inch of sleet - another 3 to 4 inches of snow fell.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several areas across northeast Kansas and northwest Missouri saw ice accumulations approaching a quarter inch as well as sleet ranging from a quarter to a half inch in most locations, with some locations reporting over an inch of sleet. Once the sleet ended another 3 to 4 inches of snow fell before the system moved out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful upper level storm moved out of the southern Rockies and produced widespread rain, some sleet and heavy snow.  Heavy rainfall occurred late on the 12th but ended by sunrise on the 13th.  The precipitation began again during the morning on the 13th and started as rain before transitioning to sleet and finally snow by the afternoon.  During the late afternoon and evening thunder accompanied the snow and became very heavy.  Most of the precipitation ended shortly after midnight.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow of 6 to 10 inches was measured across all but the northwest part of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One last period of rain, freezing rain and snow occurred Sunday night into early Monday morning across north central Kansas.  The counties impacted by ice accumulations that approached one quarter of an inch were only a handful including Washington, Marshall, and Clay while the rest of the area experienced enough of a warm up to keep the bulk of the precipitation as rain or as in Ottawa, Cloud and Republic Counties the amounts that fell during this period were too light to verify the last winter storm warning that was issued for those areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Report from EM estimated another .20 to .25 of ice accumulation from freezing rain Sunday night into early Monday morning. Report was from Washington.  Additional impacts were modest due to temperatures that continued to warm and thus had changed freezing rain to rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On the afternoon of the 5th a strong cold front moved through the area. Ahead of the cold front warm moist air from the south caused high instability. The strong system provided the shear needed to support a few isolated severe storms.
